PETITION.TITLE: Anzac Rifle Range, Malabar, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That over 67,000 men, women and students enjoy the pursuit of their sport and recreation every year at the Anzac Rifle Range at Malabar and have done so since 1967.

2. The people of Sydney through their membership of 41 clubs headquartered at the Anzac Rifle Range together with a number of other community, school and commercial groups, the police and armed forces will lose this community facility if the Federal Government proceeds to sell the Range to private developers.
3. The Australian Bicentenary Fullbore Rifle Championships are to be conducted at the Anzac Rifle Range in April 1988 as part of the celebration of Australia's Bicentenary.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should ask the Federal Government to retain the Anzac Rifle Range for the continued use and enjoyment of the people of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Michael Baume (from 300 citizens), Peter Baume (from 353 citizens), Brownhill (from 65 citizens), Sir John Carrick (from 524 citizens), Childs (from 276 citizens), Devlin (from 25 citizens), McIntosh (from 353 citizens) and Sibraa (from 477 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights and Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth: that the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill:
1. Offer nothing more than is already available under law.
2. deny some Human Rights and do not include others.
3. give dangerously wide powers to an unelected body, and
4. could cause far more damage than they could possibly cure.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That the Senate should: completely reject the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances, Dependent Spouse Tax Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that: whereas the Federal Government is spending increasing amounts to alleviate damage done to human lives by family break-up, desertion by spouses, divorce, children in `latch-key' situations, juvenile crime and drug addiction, it is most inconsistent for that government to lessen in any way the support that Australian families need to help them to survive.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. reject any proposed cuts to the support now provided to families by way of family allowance;
2. reject any proposal to introduce a `flat-rate' family allowance, but rather keep family allowance fully proportional to family size; and
3. reject any proposal to abolish or diminish the dependent spouse tax rebate.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. Its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors.
2. Its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs it imposes.
3. Its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance.

4. In that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy Tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned shows: That we urge you to rescind the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986. The Fringe Benefits Tax Act 1986 (Application to the Commonwealth) Act 1986 and the Fringe Benefits Tax (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1986 because:
1. It will increase both personal and company taxation.
2. It will undermine employment levels through reducing profitability and international competitiveness of industry.
3. It will result in price increases.
4. It will force employers to withdraw voluntary incentives to employees paid over and above existing payments.
5. It endangers stable industrial relations because of the potential for forced withdrawal of Fringe Benefits.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should rescind the Act, and seek a genuine public debate on equitable reforms of the Taxation System.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap Defence Space Research Facility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

1. The Agreement between the United States of America and Australia concerning the Joint De- fence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap may be terminated by either Government on one year's notice from 19 October 1986.

and your petitioners humbly pray that:

3. Any agreement concerning the future use of Pine Gap be referred to Parliament for ratification.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the annual report of the Australian Industry Development Corporation and seek leave to make a statement relating thereto.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Industry Development Corporation achieved a record after tax net profit of $19.1m in the year ended 30 June 1986. This is an increase of almost $3m on the previous year and a return on capital of 21.8 per cent. The Commonwealth will receive a payment from the Corporation of $8.6m, representing 50 per cent of the parent Corporation's profits. The Corporation's new commitments during the year were a record $1,599m and total assets of the Corporation at year end were $2.2 billion. These results reflect a most successful year for the Corporation in a difficult economic environment and demonstrate the Corporation's effectiveness in financing industries vital to the Australian economy. All of the Corporation's activities, both debt and equity, are contributing to the growth of manufacturing, resource and service industries, with the emphasis on exports and international competitiveness.

SPEECH.PARA: In June 1985 the Corporation established a new industry restructuring unit and during the year development investments with significant benefits in restructuring and revitalisation of sectors of manufacturing industry were made. In addition to these commercial activities the Corporation is continuing to work with government and industry bodies towards finding solutions to problems in more difficult industries. The Corporation is co-operating with the newly established Heavy Engineering Advisory Group in the administration of a concessional loan finance scheme expected to support more than $130m of new investment in revitalisation of the sector over the next three years. The Government has for the first time also utilised the national interest provisions of the Australian Industry Development Corporation Act to support AIDC in injecting $9.2m into a joint venture project to develop an anti-malaria vaccine.

The Corporation's 1986 annual report shows that it is well placed to respond positively to Government initiatives in industry policy. The Board of Directors of the Corporation has informed me that the Government's intention of levying a charge in respect of the guarantee of borrowings by the Commonwealth's business enterprises would adversely impact on AIDC as a financial institution and that a statutory guarantee of AIDC's borrowing is not necessary for the commercial operations of the Corporation. The Government has therefore decided that all new borrowings made by the Corporation on or after 8 October 1986 will not generally be guaranteed by the Commonwealth. The Corporation will nevertheless have the option, at its discretion, for the Commonwealth guarantee to apply to individual borrowings made by it after today. The statutory guarantee of the Commonwealth will of course continue to apply to all borrowings and other liabilities of the Corporation entered into prior to 8 October 1986. These new initiatives acknowledge the commercial strength of the Corporation and its ability to stand on its own feet as a successful government-owned development bank.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I do not wish to speak at length on the motion. I will shortly seek leave to continue my remarks later on the understanding that Senator Siddons wishes to make some comments on behalf of the Australian Democrats and that he will do that by leave under the practice which seems to have developed in these matters over the last year or so. Having had a quick look at the report of the Australian Industry Development Corporation since I received it this morning, it seems to reflect a very successful year for the Corporation. The report touches on some activities which are of very great importance to Australia in 1986. I refer in particular to the role which the Government has given the Corporation with respect to industry restructuring. It is common ground in this chamber that the restructuring of Australian industry with a view to its becoming internationally competitive and more outward looking is essential for our long term welfare. It will be a matter of interest, not only to the Opposition but also to the Parliament generally and to the community, to see to what extent the role which the Australian Industry Development Corporation has been given by the Government facilitates the very necessary changes which are being made.

I express a word of caution about the reliance upon providing concessional assistance to industries as a road out of their present difficulty. The statement of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) specifically refers to the assistance which is being given to the heavy engineering industry. Again, it is common ground that that industry has fallen on very difficult times, not least because of the significant reduction in the demand for heavy engineering services in Australia. The provision of concessional finance in those circumstances which will support restructuring and which will put the industry generally in a position to be more competitive on the face of it appears very sound. However, the Opposition expresses the general view that, as far as possible, industries in that situation should be assisted to restructure, not so much by providing further concessional assistance as in trying to ensure that the general conditions under which the industry operates are such that it is able to make the necessary changes itself without further assistance from the taxpayer.

In that regard I suggest to the Government that the addition of new taxes to the business sector generally, which has been a feature of the last 12 months, sits very oddly with the need to provide concessional finance to those same industries to enable them to operate. There appears to be an element of the absurd in a situation where the Government has put such heavy and obviously new imposts on industry generally and, at the same time, has to provide subsidies which will in some way reduce the impact of those imposts and the other disadvantages which are suffered. In exactly the same way, whilst no one could quarrel with the Government's objective of removing restrictive work practices in the heavy engineering industry, one would question the three-year timetable and the heavy bureaucratic mechanisms discussed by the Senate Estimates committees which we hope will give rise to change in this area. We suggest to the Government that it should be looking for rather less bureaucratic and more direct approaches along the lines of what seems to have been embraced by it in its more recent initiative on work practices. This has thrown the emphasis very much back into the work place with direct dealings between management and the work force of an enterprise or the trade unions involved in that enterprise rather than a reliance upon outside bodies.

That has taken me a little way from the AIDC report. The Opposition welcomes the move towards some equalisation of the position of the AIDC and its private competitors in the decision which the Government has taken that all new borrowings made by the Corporation on or after 8 October 1986 will not generally be guaranteed by the Commonwealth. The effect of that guarantee has been to give the AIDC some commercial advantage in what is a very competitive market-place. It enables the Corporation to obtain some concessions on interest rates on its own borrowings. It is, of course, a preferred borrower because of the interest rate guarantee. It is to be noted that the Government is moving away from that preference, although the Corporation is to retain the option, which will be exercised at the discretion of the Corporation and not the Government, for the Commonwealth guarantee to apply to individual borrowings made by it after today. The statement of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce points out:

The Board has taken the view that the Government's intention of levying a charge in respect of the guarantee of borrowings by Commonwealth business enterprises would adversely impact on AIDC as a financial institution and that a statutory guarantee of AIDC's borrowings is not necessary for the commercial operations of the Corporation.

If that is so, if that is an indication that the Corporation will not be calling upon the Commonwealth, I think the AIDC will be operating in a more acceptable way in terms of its competitors who have to put up with the burdens of the market-place and in view of the general attitude which is adopted by the Opposition to government bodies of this sort. It would be my intention to discuss directly with the AIDC its attitude towards its future borrowings and the extent to which that is likely to inhibit the very rapid rate of growth of the AIDC's borrowings and subsequent lendings over the period reported on in this report. It is a notable rate of growth and it is not clear to me on my early examination of this report whether the Corporation believes it can sustain that same rate of growth given the changes in the way it intends to operate and the removal of the Government guarantee.

The question of whether there is a need for a specific government-owned agency to facilitate the process of restructuring in Australia is an important one and not one on which I would make any pronouncement at this stage. I do not think any of us are under any illusions about the very real difficulties that Australian industry faces in changing not only its habits but also its cast of mind. The role which the AIDC is assuming, therefore, is one which is important to this country. The Opposition will watch its progress with great interest and, of course, hopes that the work of the Corporation will be successful, as have many of its actions to date. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-If Australia is to pass through the economic problems in which it currently finds itself, positive action must be taken to encourage and to expand its manufacturing industries. One effective way of doing this is to invest along the lines set down in this report in the policy statements of the Australian Industry Development Corporation. It has the opportunity to be Australia's best and most innovative bank, and I believe that it has gone a long way in this regard.

SPEECH.PARA: AIDC has expanded rapidly but if we are really to encourage Australian industry through selective investment in those industries which have export potential and which are efficient, we must encourage further expansion of banks such as the AIDC, which exists to encourage greater Australian ownership of export oriented industries and to seek to raise funds largely from within Australia. It is significant that by and large the Corporation makes a point of borrowing funds in Australia, and not overseas. That is exactly what is needed at the moment with our critical balance of payments problem.

The investment policy of AIDC is in stark contrast to the practice of many of the foreign banks which the Government recently encouraged to set up in Australia. Their record shows that enormous amounts of money have been lent for purely speculative investments such as defending or taking over the Broken Hill Proprietary Company Ltd. Those banks have borrowed money overseas and have encouraged speculation and takeovers. On the other hand, AIDC carefully assesses where its investments are made. It invests to develop our manufacturing base.

I put it to the Senate that in the interest of rapidly developing Australia's export potential and manufacturing base we must find ways and means of encouraging AIDC to expand even more rapidly than it has in the past. I want to draw attention to the page in the AIDC report headed `Australianisation'. In doing so I declare my interest as the non-executive Chairman of Siddons Industries Limited. The AIDC last year invested in our company to the extent of owning 11 per cent of the capital. I read from the report:
The Corporation's two primary functions are to promote development of Australian industry and promote Australian ownership and control in industry.
The report goes on to list two of the Corporation's activities in that area. The report states:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Student Assistance Act 1973, and for related purposes.
Bill presented by Senator Ryan, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1986 seeks to amend the Student Assistance Act 1973, which since 1974 has provided the legislative basis for the tertiary education assistance scheme-TEAS-and the postgraduate awards scheme. The Bill will not alter the existing arrangements for postgraduate awards but by including secondary education in the principal Act will allow for the introduction of the Government's new age-related student assistance scheme, Austudy. Austudy, which will replace TEAS, the secondary allowances scheme, or SAS, and the adult secondary education assistance scheme, or ASEAS, will provide benefits to both secondary and tertiary students.

The underlying principles of Austudy were announced last year by the Government as part of Priority One: Young Australia. Austudy is the student assistance element of the Priority One package and is a carefully planned initiative to improve the income support arrangements for young people. Austudy benefits, of course, will still be available to older students as they were under TEAS and ASEAS. Austudy benefits will be progressively aligned with the unemployment benefit rates for young people aged 16 to 20. As with unemployment benefit a higher rate will be payable from age 18. Rates of benefit will be increased each year and by 1989 Austudy and unemployment benefit rates for young people in this age range will have come together.

In 1987 the first alignment will be established between Austudy rates for 16- and 17-year-old tertiary students and unemployment benefits for people of the same age. Once parity of rates is achieved both allowances and income test levels will be indexed to protect their real level. Student organisations and parents have been seeking indexation for many years. When we came to Government in March 1983 young people were losing confidence in the education system and participation rates in schools past the compulsory years were unsatisfactorily low. Young people were faced with an ad hoc collection of benefits and allowances which was riddled with inconsistencies and which left significant numbers of needy young people without support, or without adequate support.

The Government's reaction was two-fold. We recognised the immediate plight of students by increasing student allowances in each of our Budgets and at the outset set in train a fundamental review of youth income support. In 1983 we invited a team of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development experts to come to Australia and review Australian policies and programs affecting youth. We also in that year asked the Office of Youth Affairs and the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat to review jointly the area of income support. It was from this informed basis that we established the Task Force on Youth Allowance Administration in 1985 which has provided the detailed advice necessary for the Government to introduce Austudy in 1987.

Austudy is not a quick fix solution but a carefully planned initiative which addresses the fundamental problem of ensuring that young people have the opportunity and the incentive to study until they have completed a full education. The scheme with its much improved allowance structure for secondary and tertiary students will remove the disincentive to study which arose because unemployment benefit out- stripped the basic rates of education allowances for young people. This was a legacy of the Liberal Government from 1975 to 1983.

The Bill, strictly speaking, has no direct financial impact in that it does not provide for increases in allowances. The increases in allowances and progressive aligning of them with unemployment benefit rates will be achieved by amending the regulations to the principal Act. The financial implications of the Government's Austudy initiative are, however, significant. In 1985-86 the expenditure on the three student assistance schemes, TEAS, SAS and ASEAS, that Austudy will replace was $401.5m. In 1986-87 it is expected that expenditure on TEAS, SAS and ASEAS recipients up to 31 December 1986 and Austudy recipients from 1 January to 30 June 1987 will be $487.7m. The estimated cost of Austudy in its first full year of operation in 1987 is $528.5m compared with $439.2m for TEAS, SAS and ASEAS in 1986. The full cost for Austudy in 1986-87-that is for the six months 1 January to 30 June 1987-is estimated to be $271.2m.

Austudy is a tangible demonstration of the Government's commitment to education. Despite the financial restraint exercised in this year's Budget, extra funds have been provided in a planned and considered way to help the young people of today and those of the future become useful, productive Australians. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to make provision for more liberal rights of standing and for related purposes.
Bill presented by Senator Vigor, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
PURPOSE

This Bill is aimed at fulfilling a commitment to provide access to the processes of justice to all Australians and to move the emphasis of our legal system from almost total concern for protection of financial and commercial rights (property) towards the consideration of social, environmental and human rights.

The new rules of standing set out in this Bill in conjunction with the Judiciary Amendment (Class Actions) Bill 1986 allow individuals to get justice in dealing with large institutions, including government and the judiciary, allow social and personal reasons to be considered justification for participation in legal action, and allow environmental and public interest wrongs to be righted through the judicial process.

One mark of an open and tolerant society is the readiness with which justice, including effective remedies for wrongdoing, can be invoked by ordinary citizens. I believe very strongly that every human being has a natural right to seek to correct wrongs and to resolve conflicts through an effective judicial system.
NEED FOR REFORM

As a parliamentarian, I place the greatest priority on justice being available to all people, regardless of their position in society. Our legal aid mechanisms partially address this problem. I introduced my Judiciary Amendment (Class Actions) Bill earlier this year to enable courts to deal efficiently with matters where the interests of many people with limited financial resources may be adversely affected.

The Law Reform Commission report-No. 27-on the subject has canvassed the issues in considerable detail. The conclusion of that Report-and the recommendations for reform-are excellent and are worthy of immediate implementation. Unfortunately, it seems that Government action will take some time if not forever. I believe we can no longer wait any longer for the much needed changes encompassed in the Bill.

I am now addressing another major problem in our legal system, that of people being excluded from justice because of some obscure doctrine or some previous court finding that they are not fit and proper to bring an action. We have to turn our legal system back to one which is not bound up inordinately by the protection of commercial or property interests, to one in which the ordinary person may rely on the rule of law.

I believe that our courts should be spending their time on the merits of issues, and not on splitting hairs about whether or not the bringer of an action has an `appropriate' interest in the matter. I agree with Ralph Nader, who said:
A law which is not enforced against a Government official because courts deny citizens standing to sue is the equivalent of no law at all.

We cannot talk about equality before the law or the rule of law if in practice unlawful or illegal behaviour can go unchallenged because no-one is in a position to do anything about it. This may occur either because those who are affected most directly do not have the financial means, or it may happen because those who do have the financial means do not qualify to bring on a case because of some artificial legal barrier.

The thrust of this Bill and of its earlier companion, relating to class actions, is a strong desire to restore some of the original elements of natural justice to our highly complex society, and to make it possible for every citizen to have confidence in the decision-making and conflict resolution process.

The alternative solution of violent social revolution if justice is beyond the legal and economic means of ordinary citizens is unthinkable. Restrictive legal interpretations which deny access to justice must be broken down. If citizens cannot be heard, they will be justified in believing that the legal system is geared to protect dominant economic and political interests, and does nothing for those who are outside that charmed circle of privilege.

I believe that the only real obstacle to being able to initiate legal proceedings on public interest grounds should be competence to handle the matter. If there is no appeal on this ground, or if the court decides the question need not be settled at the outset of proceedings, the substance of the case can be the dominant matter before the courts.

Lawyers should not be encouraged to devise tactics aimed at thwarting a hearing of the issues at the centre of a dispute. They should instead devote more effort to ensuring that the matters at the heart of the conflict are talked out and resolved properly, justly and efficiently.

Unless we can unclog the courts and focus their efforts on the substantive issues in each case, more and more people will resort to extra-legal techniques to achieve justice, bringing the law into further disrepute.
HISTORICAL BACKGROUND
The law of standing as it is today has developed since mediaeval times in many ways as a result of historical or accidental factors. It is arbitrary, discriminatory, and in short, it is a mess.
The rules which determine whether or not a person initiating legal proceedings is an appropriate party to do so, vary according to the type of proceedings brought or the type of relief sought.
Where there are matters of public interest at stake, there should not be a major legal maze for negotiation before the substance of those matters can be addressed.

Where the theory that the Attorney-General is the legal representative of society appears to break down for party political or any other factors, there should be an effective remedy whereby individual citizens can take the action needed to keep the system above suspicion of favouritism, or of political cowardice in the face of sensitive issues which may damage a government.

If we are to make access to justice more than just a catch-phrase, we must also have mechanisms to allow, where it is appropriate, matters to be pursued even when their initiators have not the financial resources to carry them through to conclusion or resolution.

These points are all addressed effectively in this Bill. Honourable senators will I hope by now have had a chance, or will take the opportunity, to study the lengthy report by the Law Reform Commission on `Standing in Public Interest Litigation', completed last year.

The Commission got off to a flying start with the issue of a discussion paper during the course of 1977, the year in which former Attorney-General Ellicott gave standing and class actions as a reference to the Commission. However, for a variety of reasons, the actual report was not concluded till last year-nine years later-and the class actions reference has still not been completed.

This Parliament cannot afford to sit around for years contemplating the generally excellent recommendations of the Commission, and denying Australians access to affordable justice through this substantial delay. The Commission itself has this to say in the summary of its report:
The law of standing is ripe for reform. The High Court has held that reform cannot come from the judiciary. It is up to parliament to reform the law.
I have followed the Commission's draft Bill in many respects and I acknowledge the assistance that its work has given me.

The significant difference is that I believe that any criticism seeking to cut out those people who are `merely meddling' will continue to switch the energies of lawyers from the substantive issues into unproductive sidetracks. We should be ridding our legal system of as many barriers to achieving justice as are possible to be removed. Access to justice must be available where there are public interest matters at stake. We must not set up new barriers as we pull down the old. This Bill leaves to the courts the discretion to strike out an action if the court does not believe it can competently be brought by the proposed initiator.

Apart from the question of competence and the matter of financial discipline in taking on proceedings, we need brook no diversions away from the issues to be resolved. Lawyers will always test such diversions if given half a chance, and we should in no way leave that particular stable door open.
CASE STUDIES

I want to deal with some case examples before dealing with the principles of this Bill in detail. It is worth noting that the enactment of the Judiciary Act in 1903 abolished the Crown's immunity from suit and made the government amenable to the jurisdiction of the courts, in the same way as are people and corporations.
1. Accountability of government

The creation of an Ombudsman and an Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and the enactment of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 were designed to force greater government accountability. While there have been improvements as a result there are still gaping holes. This Bill seeks to give Australians a means of plugging some of those holes.

At a time when government expenditure is under increasing scrutiny, it is interesting to note that Canadian taxpayers have a right to challenge the constitutional validity of legislation or of an intergovernment agreement, and hence can seek the prevention or the recovery of unlawful government expenditure. Australians do not have this right.

This is a consequence of a decision in Anderson v. Commonwealth. In this case a consumer sought a declaration that an agreement entered into between the Commonwealth and Queensland over sugar marketing, and whose effect was to increase the price of sugar, was unconstitutional. The High Court ruled that the applicant did not have the standing to seek the declaration because he was just a consumer of sugar and not affected more than anyone else.

The most direct route for allowing Australian citizens to test the lawfulness of government behaviour is by changing the rules of standing to give people more access to all the processes of law even when dealing with government or its instrumentalities.
2. Protection of the environment
A very important area in which the rules of standing have failed badly in the past is in the protection of the environment from public or private action which puts it at risk.

Concern for the environment is a relatively recent phenomenon even though it is a central plank of Democrat policy. Arguably the courts, given time, could adjust to new concerns and develop machinery to cope, but there is little evidence of such adjustment to date in Australian legal practice.
We uphold that a strict interpretation of standing requirements should not be able to be used by the courts to opt out of difficult issues concerning the protection of the environment.

For example, in Stow v. Mineral Holdings (Australia) Pty Ltd, the Supreme Court of Tasmania and the High Court confined the interpretation of `interest' in section 15c of the Mining Act 1929-Tasmania-to its traditional pro- prietary context. The appellant objectors-the Launceston Walking Club, the Tasmanian Conservation Trust and the South West Committee-argued that they had an interest in land which they used as members of the public. This was rejected in the High Court in the following terms:

The fact that some of them are more disposed to go upon the land than others, derive more benefit therefrom and use the statutory rights more often than others does not elevate that which is a public right enjoyed by all members of the public equally into a private right capable of being described as an estate or interest in the land. (Aickin J)

Comparable difficulties arose in Johnson v. Kent-the Black Mountain Tower case. The argument that a public trust arose out of the declaration that Black Mountain was a public park which required maintenance of the environmental quality of the mountain was dismissed. The additional argument that disfigurement of the skyline constituted a public nuisance was also dismissed in the same case.

In the Australian Conservation Foundation Inc. v. Commonwealth of Australia, for instance, the ACF challenged the Federal Government approval of the Iwasaki-Sangyo Corporation's development at Yeppoon in Queensland. The ACF based its standing on the nature of the Foundation and its objects and the fact that it had sent written comments when the draft environmental impact statement was made available, under the Commonwealth Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. When the matter came before the full High Court, only Justice Murphy accepted that the Conservation Foundation had the necessary standing. Justice Gibbs made the following comments when justifying his reasons for rejecting standing:

I would not deny that a person might have a special interest in the preservation of a particular environment. However, an interest, for present purposes, does not mean a mere intellectual or emotional concern. A person is not interested within the meaning of the rule, unless he is likely to gain some advantage, other than the satisfaction or righting a wrong, upholding a principle or winning a contest, if his action succeeds or to suffer some disadvantage, other than a sense of grievance or a debt for costs, if his action fails. A belief, however strongly felt, that the law generally, or a particular law, should be observed, or that conduct of a particular kind should be prevented, does not suffice to give its possessor locus standi.

Justices Stephen and Mason stated their agreement with these views. This was despite the fact that the ACF had 6,500 members, was partly funded by the Federal Government, and had pursued its objectives by participating in the environmental impact assessment process by making written submissions. With one reservation as to the constitutionality of legislation extending standing, the High Court clearly felt that any change would need to be by way of legis- lation.

It is important to remember that the rules of standing are only one aspect of remedial law and their effectiveness has to be measured against that yardstick. A rule of standing is, in effect, meaningless apart from the remedial uses to which a given relationship between plaintiff and subject matter may be put.
3. Public interest

The Law Reform Commission report has drawn attention to the serious deficiencies among the confused, unclear and restrictive rules which place an unreasonable burden on a plaintiff see- king to act in the public interest. There are, for example, different tests of standing, depending on whether the plaintiff is seeking a declaration, or injunction or some other order from the court. Briefly, the effect of these different rules is that the plaintiff generally has to show some special connection with the subject matter of the proceedings-an interest going beyond the interests of ordinary members of the public. The decision in the Australian Conservation Federation case shows how difficult it is to get over that hurdle. Plaintiffs who have no such interest can approach the Attorney-General for a fiat, of course, but fiats are often not granted and obtaining them may cause delay.

For example, the `relators' in the Defence of Government Schools case sought to challenge the Commonwealth's funding of non-govern- ment schools on constitutional grounds. Their efforts have been described as `a long, hard pilgrimage to court' and as `an obstacle race'. The first attempt to gain a fiat was in 1957, when an application was made to the Commonwealth Attorney-General and was refused. The challenge which ultimately resulted in a High Court action was launched in 1971. The 1972-73 requests for fiats to the Commonwealth and all State Attorneys-General were refused, except for the Victorian Attorney-General, who granted a fiat in November 1973 subject to a number of conditions. Compliance with these conditions and with others set down later caused further delay and the relators were almost deterred from proceeding. In the event, the first hearing did not take place until June 1979.

Similarly, in 1972 the Tasmanian Hydro Electric Commission proposal to flood Lake Pedder caused a major controversy. Conservationists, having been advised that the proposed action was illegal, sought a fiat from the Tasmanian Attorney-General. Although the Attorney-General said that he would grant a fiat, his Cabinet intervened and instructed him not to do so. The Attorney-General resigned and was replaced by the Premier who refused a fiat. Again, public interest was thwarted and the courts were given no opportunity to rule on the legality of the work.

In the Black Tower case, delay in granting the fiat nearly prevented the relators from instituting proceedings before work on the tower had begun. The Attorney-General's insistence that an interlocutory injunction be obtained before a final injunction was sought also raised the prospect of the relators having to pay heavy damages for delaying the tower's construction if the final injunction was ultimately refused.
DIFFICULTIES FORESEEN IN
REFORMING RULES OF STANDING
Those who argue against the liberalisation of the rules of standing advance a number of arguments which in my opinion do not stand up to close examination.
1. Inadequacy of courts to decide

It is sometimes said that less restrictive standing rules would impose a task on courts for which they are inadequately equipped, as they generally are dealing with private rights. In fact there is little evidence to support this assertion. For instance, the courts have come more and more to realise the profound differences between the tenets of administrative law which deals with the appropriateness of decisions, and the private interest principles with which they are more familiar. If there are areas where the courts are still badly equipped, the appropriate response is to legislate to limit the type of case in which the courts can intervene. The rules of standing should not ever be misused to effectively deny some plaintiffs the right to approach the courts.
2. Increased litigation because of liberalised standing

It is also claimed that if the rules are changed the floodgates of litigation will open. Again, these claims are unfounded. Liberalisation of standing in certain areas has not produced a flood of litigation. For instance, in New South Wales section 123 of the Environmental Planning and Assessment Act 1979 permits `any person' to bring proceedings to remedy or restrain a breach of the Act. According to the Law Reform Commission about 35 actions were commenced between 1979 and 1984, and in a significant proportion of them the plaintiff would have had standing at common law. In addition, the courts possess a number of powers to prevent frivolous claims.
PROVISIONS OF THE BILL
This Bill is based on the Draft Standing (Fe-deral and Territories Jurisdiction) Bill 1985 in Appendix A of the Law Reform Commission report No. 27 on `Standing in Public Interest Litigation'.

Its purpose is two-fold: To give people and organisation the ability to resolve issues of public interest by legal means through widening the standing rules that presently apply in `public interest litigation'; and to improve the accountability of the Government and of law enforcement agencies by allowing private prosecution of indictable offences when the public prosecution has not been followed through, subject always to the right of the Attorney-General, the Director of Public Prosecutions and special prosecutors to take prosecutions over and terminate them.
1. Remedies available

In line with the purpose of the Bill to improve access to the courts in matters of public interest, the types of remedies available under this Act will be those of a `public' nature. Litigation under Commonwealth and Territories laws will only fall under the aegis of this provision for standing, where the relief sought is a declaration, an injunction or a prerogative writ. This includes writs such as certiorari, prohibition, mandamus, habeas corpus and quo warranto.
2. Exclusion of meddlers

The negative definition of the concept of `merely meddling' has been excluded from the Bill, but the formula to determine whether a plaintiff has standing will give effect to the Law Reform Commission's intentions to exclude med- dlers.
The time of the courts should be taken up with substantive matters really in dispute, and not with sideshows about who does or does not have the special interest required to bring an action.

A proper balance is struck between excluding incompetent meddlers and allowing access to those who can represent in a capable manner a class or group of individuals in the community whose legal rights or whose interests, in a general sense, are directly involved in the proceedings.

The fact that a plaintiff is a representative organisation rather than an individual would normally operate in practice to strengthen its claim to standing because of its improved ability to present the issues to the court and the greater financial resources available to it.
3. Open access to the courts for all citizens

In order to protect the right of all citizens to have access to the courts, this Bill provides that a court will be bound to accept that a plaintiff has standing in the absence of compelling arguments put forward by other parties to the proceedings. The only exception to this rule is where a plaintiff has no personal stake in the subject matter before a court, and lacks the motivation and capacity to conduct the case adequately in the public interest. The court will be able to strike the action out once it determines that inability.

The court need not determine standing as a preliminary to hearing the case, but may reserve its determination on the standing question along with the merits of the case. This will give it greater opportunity to determine whether a party to the case is basically frivolous or incapable, rather than having to waste time unnecessarily trying to decide in advance of hearing their case.
4. Rights to intervene or to present an argument in a case

As well as the right of standing to be joined with the plaintiff or defendant, this Bill also gives rights to interested parties and to the Attorney-General to intervene in proceedings, or to present a submission to the court as amicus curiae. In this way access to the court is open to all, and a person or public interest group can take a less expensive role in proceedings by participating as amicus curiae. This is because amicus curiae is not responsible for the costs of either of the originating parties, nor is he obliged to pay court fees.

The right to intervene allows people or groups who may be affected by the outcome of an action to present their point of view before the issue has been decided. This protects the courts against a series of actions when a result of a current case may be unsatisfactory to another potential plaintiff with possibly opposed interests. By allowing intervention in the first action, so as to become a party to it, the intervening plaintiff or defendant is bound by the outcome and cannot relitigate the point.

There is also considerable advantage to a court in receiving evidence from an amicus curiae, as this extends the evidence available to the court in reaching a decision. Particularly in public interest litigation, the courts can take the wider implications of the case into account.
5. Costs

This Bill gives the courts power to make an order for costs against the Attorney-General, whether or not the Attorney-General is a party in the case. They can also order that the plaintiff is not liable to indemnify the Attorney-General for costs, or that any security for costs held by or for the benefit of that Attorney-General is not enforceable.

The reason for this is that all cases proceed to trial by the Attorney-General granting a fiat, and in many cases it is in the public interest that the issues should be resolved. The fact that the Attorney-General does not prosecute the case or intervene in the case in no way diminishes his or her responsibility for allowing the case to be heard. The Attorney-General has the right to intervene in any case where he or she wishes to state government policy, or to argue a constitutional matter. Whether or not this right is exercised, the supervisory interest is present in all cases.

The power of the court to order costs against the Attorney-General gives a court the right to do so when it perceives that it was in the public interest that the case be heard, rather than in the particular interests of either party to the case.
This is an important step towards ensuring that people have greater access to the law in matters of public interest.
This Bill also permits financial support of an action by members of the public who are not themselves party to the action, provided that they do not seek to share in any of its financial proceeds.

The exception of champerty protects our courts against the legal excesses apparent in United States courts where ``contingent fees'' for lawyers encourage them to seek out actions in order to generate income for themselves.
6. Private prosecutions

While enforcement of the criminal law is usually carried out by public officers of the police or Crown, private individuals have the right, under the Commonwealth Crimes Act 1914, section 13, to prosecute offenders against a law of the Commonwealth.
This protects the right of citizens to access to the courts in cases where public officers fail to enforce the criminal law.

In particular, cases of personal assault are seldom prosecuted by the police, particularly when they arise from domestic or neighbourhood disputes. Prosecution is left to the person assaulted or to a person acting on the person's behalf and with that person's consent.

Where an offence is indictable, a private individual is not in practice able to prosecute, since the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Attorney-General effectively control the initiation and termination of such actions, and also because the costs are often not eligible for subsidy from legal aid funds.

The standing of a private person to prosecute before the courts is an important safeguard of civil liberty. As long as discretion to prosecute rests only in the hands of the police, the Attorney-General and other public prosecution authorities, there is no adequate public scrutiny, accountability or review possible in cases which involve the police themselves, or other politically influential people, or where the publicity given to the offence may be considered to be politically damaging.

This Bill allows any person to prosecute an offence by indictment in his or her own name, if public prosecution has not proceeded within three months of committal of a person for trial in relation to an indictable offence.

This is a valuable safeguard for accountability of our law-enforcement agencies. Nuisance and vexatious prosecutions are avoided by not removing the right of the Attorney-General, the Director of Public Prosecutions or a Special Prosecutor to terminate such prosecution. Since such decisions not to proceed further in the prosecution are open to public scrutiny, the rights of citizens remain fully protected.
NEED FOR WRONGS TO BE SETTLED
JUDICIALLY

It is the function of courts to resolve conflicts of interest. The current situation is clearly unacceptable. What really lies behind the allocation of judicial resources argument and the floodgates claim could simply be unwillingness to get involved. However, inadequacy of judicial remedies leaves concerned individuals with two choices-resort to extra legal means, such as green bans in the environmental area, or have no remedy at all.

We may with a proper efficient and effective judicial solution available, be able to dispense with green bans and similar measures. Such bans do not produce lasting solutions nor are they a desirable means for resolving matters of public interest. We cannot accept the current lack of public access to the courts which causes injustice to flourish through lack of private remedy.
Responsibility of Parliament
The High Court has shown its unwillingness to extend standing in public interest litigation and it therefore falls to Parliament to solve this impasse.

As the Law Reform Commission report said, the law of standing is ripe for reform. I have indicated in some detail, why it is up to the Parliament to act if we want reform in a reasonable period of time. As a community we can no longer allow outdated, unclear, restrictive rules of standing to hamper and often defeat genuine public interest litigation. As a Parliament we have the responsibility and power to remedy the situation within our jurisdiction and we should do so quickly.
CONCLUSION

I urge honourable senators to support the Standing (Federal and Territory Jurisdiction) Bill 1986, thus affirming their commitment to the interests of all Australian citizens, to providing a conflict resolution process which works, and to thus establishing an effective, affordable and efficient system of justice.
