TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Assembly (Election) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Australian Capital Territory Regulations 1986 No. 10 and made under the House of Assembly Ordinance 1936, be disallowed.

The effect of these regulations is to allow the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) to sit back and do nothing on the self-government question until the end of this year. The regulations are being gazetted in part because the Government is looking around for some policy on the Australian Capital Territory which it has not been able to formulate. We have now before the Senate the Government's Australian Capital Territory Council Bill 1986 and its consequential provisions companion. They are listed at the bottom of the legislative section of the Notice Paper, along with the National Capital Development Commission Amendment Bill 1985, which was abandoned last year just as the Australian Demo- crats and the Opposition were about to improve it out of sight.

The Australian Capital Territory Council Bill was, of course, described in March this year as an `insulting imposition' and `not half a loaf' by the well-known champion of self-government, the Canberra Times. Eventually the Government came out of its non-negotiable closet with nine printed pages of amendments that it intended to move. These have not been debated in the Senate. It is apparent that the Government's intention is that they never will be debated. That is quite extraordinary behaviour from a government and, indeed, should be brought to the notice of the people of Australia. The only possible conclusion is that the Hawke Government has never been serious about its commitment to Australian Capital Territory self- government. This conclusion is supported by the amazing antics over the mooted appointed advisory body. This attempt to defer for six months the acknowledged need to hold House of Assembly elections is yet another example of the Government hiding behind small measures. I shall come back to that point in a moment.

What must be stressed is this: The Government knows that its Australian Capital Territory Council Bill would be passed by the Senate, with amendments, if it were to bring it on. That is presumably why it does not want to bring it on. It does not want to bring these two Bills on for debate. The last thing that this Government wants is a debate about effective self-government for the Australian Capital Territory. That is one reason why I introduced my Australian Capital Territory Effective Self-Government Bill during the week of sittings in August. It is now dawning on more and more people in the Australian Capital Territory that my Australian Capital Territory Effective Self-Government Bill 1986 has addressed the issues of concern to Canberrans. In part, this is because I consulted widely with Australian Capital Territory people in the drafting of that legislation, as distinct from the head-in-the-sand attitude of the Cabinet when it concocted its outrageous package.

The sorts of issues which the effective self-government Bill addresses are those that the Hawke Government does not want the people of Canberra to discuss openly. That is why we have before us this attempt to put the due process of law on ice for six months. The explanatory memorandum attached to the regulation that I am seeking to disallow states:

Regulation 25 of the House of Assembly (Election) Regulations requires the Minister for Territories to order an election of members of the House of Assembly to be held whenever necessary. On 30 June 1986 the terms of office of members of the Assembly expired and, accordingly, the Minister is under an obligation to direct the holding of an election.

Nothing could be clearer than that. The Minister is under an obligation right now to direct the holding of an election. Why would the Minister want to evade that obligation through some type of interim regulations? It is not as though he did not know what was coming up because the Government's Australian Capital Territory Council Bills have been before us for a number of months.

Honourable senators will recall that during the last week of the Senate sittings in June the Australian Democrats put forward as a compromise a practical solution for a swift transition to self-government. At that stage, the House of Representatives had packed up for winter; so the only legislation that could have been passed by both Houses was the Government's universally condemned original attempt at self-government, the attempt that required nine pages of proposed Government amendments. The Democrats suggested that an election date be announced immediately for the House of Assembly and that powers be transferred to it while other matters were resolved. The telegram sent to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) by Don Chipp, then Leader of the Party, on 10 June said:

Democrats believe ACT House of Assembly election date should be announced immediately. Elections to be held under current ordinance. Will support transfer of powers and responsibilities to those elected. Opportunity to conduct referendum simultaneously with administrator, single-member, mixed-system, Senate and Hare-Clark options. Alternatively, conduct another public inquiry even though both Craig task force and 1974 Joint Committee endorsed continuation of proportional representation after extensive hearings.

This was a realistic opportunity for the Government to establish its bona fides on the self-government issue. What did the Government do? It wound up the Assembly. It was an Assembly for which it had promised great things in 1983. However, the Government delivered very little. It canvassed the possibility of an election to a smaller and more flexible advisory body, then it showed its true colours. What could be more comfortable than a hand-picked advisory body? Why go through all the trauma of an election when one could just appoint a group of people to somehow represent the Australian Capital Territory? After all, had not guided democracy worked in Third World areas in the past? Could we not learn something from Indonesia in the 1950s and 1960s or from the Soviet Politburo's processes?

In any case, the latest proposal of the Government for an appointed advisory body takes the clock back beyond 1930. Honourable senators who have given any serious study to Australian Capital Territory matters, as I have, will recall that on 9 April 1930 Governor-General Stonehaven signed the ordinance relating to the establishment of an advisory council. That original advisory council had seven members of whom three were elected at large by the people of the Territory. Since that time, the people of the Australian Capital Territory have had some elected advisory input into the running of Canberra. It is unfortunate that the Australian Public Service, the Ministers and the Government have wanted to keep such a tight rein on things that they will now go back to the propositions which were current in the 1930s. The Hawke Government has been as contemptuous of local feeling as has been any other government. The remarkable incompetence over the Trading Hours Ordinance 1962, the establishment of the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority and the disregard for the proposed Nuclear Activities (Prohibition) Ordinance 1984 are examples that immediately come to mind. There are many more instances in which the House of Assembly was bypassed or ignored, despite the following statement of the Governor-General at the opening of the Parliament after the 1983 double dissolution:
My Government is committed to bringing self-government to the Australian Capital Territory. As a first step, a broad range of local government powers will be transferred to the House of Assembly.

That solemn undertaking by the Hawke Government proved about as reliable as a number of its other pre-election policies, such as the promise to save the Belconnen Mall from privatisation. No local government powers were ever transferred to the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly. The closest the Assembly came to having any real powers was an enhanced role in disbursement from the Community Development Fund but, as always, Ministers had the last word and could and did substitute their own political judgments where they felt that they should. So overall the House of Assembly was treated with contempt and no serious attempt was made to give it any responsibility in phasing in the process of self-government. In retrospect this may have been to ensure that the people of Canberra did not start coming forward with ideas about how the Australian Capital Territory should be run. Basically the Government believes in the paternalistic approach of the British Raj. The natives would have to learn to live with what was offered and steps would have to be taken to ensure that they did not get ideas above their stations in life. Unfortunately some of the natives developed the tunnel vision that restricted their view of what could be done to keep them in local prominence. It was left to others to warn about the problems in the administration of the Australian Capital Territory and about how the thorny process towards self-government had developed in the Northern Territory. That comparison is quite useful.

The agenda remained well and truly within the bureaucracy until some troglodytes in Cabinet had a go at devising a more unworkable form of self-government for the Territory-quite an insulting imposition overall. Just as the Government is now preparing to institutionalise its ignorance, or ignoring, of the people of the Australian Capital Territory, it took remarkable steps to evade contact when preparing its Australian Capital Territory Council Bills. We have this on good authority from the various bodies in Canberra which we consulted. This was taken up in an excellent article in the Canberra Times on 6 March by John Wood, President of the Australian Capital Territory Council of Social Service. Mr Wood was a member of the task force on the implementation of self-government, which reported in 1984 to the previous Minister responsible for the Australian Capital Territory. That splendid report of the Craig Task Force on Self-Government for the Australian Capital Territory, coming as it did after extensive public hearings, was consigned to the rubbish bin while the Cabinet went about its work on proposals for avoiding effective self-government. In Mr Wood's article, headed `Canberra Self Rule: The Real Agenda', he quoted some of the choice reasons privately advanced for not wanting to grant responsible self-government to the Australian Capital Territory. I have selected the following revealing ones that indicate true party solidarity:
Why would we want the Australian Capital Territory Branch of the ALP given any responsibility?
Who wants a proper Government on your doorstep nipping at your heels?
Why should we let those members run those valuable assets?
There might be a backlash and our vote would go down.
How would we be able to control the place?
The Northern Territory is bad enough!

With these prejudices running rampant, it is not hard to see how the Government arrived at such an abysmal package and how it is now running further away from effective local input in decision making. The moves to do away with the elected representatives and to back away from a phased transfer of powers to a local body are totally in keeping with the spirit of the Hawke Government's original and revised offers. There just has not been a commitment to effective self-government for the Australian Capital Territory.

The Hawke Government now wants to induce an atmosphere of political amnesia. This charade, as expressed in this regulation, I believe does not have any hope of succeeding. Australian Capital Territory residents will remember the insult contained in the original proposal for a council with limited powers and whose most remarkable feature was that the ALP hoped to win virtually all the seats with 40 per cent of the vote. The revised plan still unduly restricted the renamed Assembly's powers of investigation. Financial arrangements were not included in that legislation. The Commonwealth retained the right to dismiss the Assembly although it gave up the outrageous plan for the Attorney-General to vet and approve all Assembly laws even before they came into effect. Of course the ALP was hoping to win two thirds of the seats with 40 per cent of the vote. That has always been a constant feature of the ALP's negotiations and plans until now. Any system which needed more than 40 per cent support to create a majority was dismissed out of hand in my discussions with them.

In this regulation the Government does not even want an election. It certainly does not want detailed public discussion of the most appropriate funding arrangements for the Australian Capital Territory. This is one of the major reasons why many residents of the Territory are sceptical about self-government. Those residents believe that under self-government they will be up for enormously increased payments. I believe they will be up for them anyway. Whether that happens will depend very much on the way in which Canberra's regional and national roles are assessed. Those considerations are in fact canvassed extensively in my Australian Capital Territory Effective Self-Government Bill, and a fair formula is arrived at for administration after triennial reports by the Commonwealth Grants Commission. Such financial questions are the last thing that this Government wants discussed at length within the Canberra community, but those questions are uppermost in the minds of Canberrans. It is not surprising that the Government is so completely out of touch and so overrun by some of the Stone clones in the De- partment of the Treasury that it will stop at nothing to keep these issues off the public agenda. This is undoubtedly one reason why the Hawke Government wants to avoid Australian Capital Territory elections, for at least six months and probably for as long as it can get away with. It will certainly be interesting to see at what point the Human Rights Commission or some appropriate overseas body, such as the International Court of Justice, is approached about the impending denial of basic democratic rights in the Australian Capital Territory.

Another reason why the Government wants to avoid an election is that the appalling policy free administration of the Australian Capital Territory might come under some type of scrutiny. Already the Government has reneged on its commitment to transfer legislative drafting staff to the Department of Territories. This would mean the continuation of the inordinate delays which attend the revision of any Australian Capital Territory legislation. Updating of the Tobacco Ordinance 1927 is months behind schedule. But then the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority is still to come to grips with its approach to the Merit Protection and Review Agency to transfer its promotion and other appeal processes to that body. Given the Minister's guarantee when the antiquated provisions of the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority Ordinance were under consideration in the Senate earlier this year, the transfer should have been completed by now. We were promised that, yet serious discussion has still not begun. Currently before the Senate are provisions relating to credit unions which have been taken holus bolus from the regulations of co-operative building societies after four years of sitting still by the Department.

Looming large is the Government's unprecedented attack on contractual arrangements with the attempt unilaterally to abrogate the conditions of mortgage agreements entered into before September 1983. I understand that the Government has seen the light and has pulled out of that today. One reason advanced-I am not sure how serious the Department is-is that the Department was having administrative difficulties keeping track of all the different interest rates. On the front page of the Canberra Times last weekend were references to equipment lying idle at the Royal Canberra Hospital. We could go on and on. The Chief Magistrate of the Australian Capital Territory estimated that three months of full time work would be needed to do a proper cut and paste job to get an up to date traffic ordinance. His pleas to the Minister for another reprint have gone unanswered and the buck has been transferred to the Attorney-General's Department. Given that it took 13 years for the Department to turn up with its disallowed New South Wales Acts Application Ordinance of last year, it may require drastic action from the Bench to get things really moving. The point is that, while the people of the Australian Capital Territory have no responsibility or control over their own affairs, such preposterous episodes will continue.

The Government, in this regulation, wants to make certain that the people of the Australian Capital Territory will not elect representatives who can have scrutiny over what is happening in the Department. That is what the Government is encouraging by its election-free, discussion-free approaches. On the other hand, my effective self-government Bill puts forward a workable plan for the thorough overhaul of Australian Capital Territory legislation. During the first five years of local decision-making, self-government will find it difficult to survive if it has the albatross of past government and departmental legislative incompetence around its neck. There has been no attempt to provide resources to clear the legislative slate. People will realise that they have been had and their attitude will be surely as a result of all the chicanery. Unless a searching, independent probe of the Australian Capital Territory administrative mechanisms occurs, the situation will continue to creak along until such time as another spate of ministerial or administrative mishaps occurs. It is not useful for the Government to pull down the shutters around the Department and to remove it from beneficial exposure to active local questioning. I call upon the Government now to call an election for the House of Assembly under the proportional representation system. This is why I believe that we should should not allow the Minister an out. I hope that the Opposition will support the measures I put forward and support the Democrats in disallowing this amendment.

In summary, the Craig Committee completely upheld the continuation of proportional representation and thoroughly dismembered the artificial proposals for a mixture of single member districts and proportional representation. In June we suggested a referendum if the Government was adamant about wanting to ignore what has happened in the past and what has been recommended after exhaustive public hearings. Now the Government does not ever want an election at all. It reminds me of a brilliant cartoon by Pryor in the Canberra Times about the two options that were being offered-no self-government or no self-government at all. I conclude my contribution with a quotation from the Department's `Answers to your questions on self-government' of March 1986:
The ACT is the only Federal capital in the western world which does not have a local representative form of government.
A little later on it states:

The House of Assembly has only advisory powers and cannot fill the gap. Currently ACT priorities are determined by a Minister who is part of a national government and who is not accountable directly to the voters of the ACT electorate.

In the Government's view, that is unsatisfactory, and the House of Assembly will go as a result. Debate on effective self-government is to be stifled. I do not believe that this ploy will succeed. The Senate can help the cause of effective self-government by tossing out these regulations and placing the ball fairly and squarely into the Minister's and the Cabinet's court. When the Government tires of cleaning up the mess of its failure to take the people of the Australian Capital Territory into its confidence, perhaps it will deign to hand over decision making to Canberrans. I commend the disallowance of this amendment to honourable senators.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the next speaker, I draw the attention of the Senate to standing order 406, which is quite comprehensive. As it is very short I shall read it to the Senate. It states:

INTERJECT.PARA: No senator shall read his speech.
I am prepared to accept that Senator Vigor was using copious notes, but I draw everyone's attention to that standing order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even if all the criticisms that Senator Vigor just levelled at the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes), the Government, the Department of Territories, the Australian Capital Territory Health Commission and everybody else were completely true and we agreed with them, to vote with him in relation to this disallowance would not solve any one of the problems. That is the point of the debate this morning. I could go through the same issues Senator Vigor has raised and the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), who is at the table, could also canvass and answer them, but I do not think that that would advance the cause in the slightest.

SPEECH.PARA: Self-government has a very long history in the Australian Capital Territory, as we all know; it certainly goes back to 1927. We heard this morning of the reference in 1930 to the setting up of the Advisory Council, when the Minister at the time referred to the likelihood that within a few years we should be able to give full civic control to the city, to the people themselves. And so it has gone on. In 1969 the Advisory Council members resigned in protest over there being no movement towards self-government. We had a very strong commitment to self-government from the Whitlam Government, but that came to nothing. Our Government was committed to self-government by July 1976, but that came to nothing. We have had numerous inquiries and reports from all sorts of committees. I think the conclusion which has to be drawn is that it is difficult to sort out the relationship between the national capital and the government of the people of Canberra. We cannot forget, and this was not referred to by the Australian Democrats speaker, a referendum where 63.75 per cent of the people of Canberra very clearly voted for things to remain as they were-what we might call a ministerial dictatorship. As I said, if all these other things which are wrong with Canberra could be corrected it would not be by the disallowance of this particular regulation. We had a commitment in May 1982 that the Australian Labor Party would bring in self-government within 12 months of being elected federally. It said that that commitment was without equivocation-but that was not so.

We got the Bill this year for the first time and found for the first time that the electoral system was not negotiable. In all the years I have been in Canberra, in all the years I have heard self-government being discussed, that had never been an issue. There were a number of things wrong with the Bill in other respects, even for those strongly committed to self-government, but those issues were never really debated because the electoral system dominated the debate. I have to say that only a couple of people contacted me urging my support for self-government. The Canberra Association for Regional Development certainly has a fairly strong commitment to it, but I understand that it is not universally agreed to even amongst its membership. The fact is, as I read the electorate, that most people do not want it. They may be wrong, but I believe that to be the case. Some certainly do want it, but they have not yet raised the level of debate to such an extent that the politicians-the senators, the Government, the Liberal Party of Australia, everybody concerned who might be making the decisions-have been sufficiently impressed electorally to see it as something that must be done.

We saw last night what can happen when a government perceives the electoral wind blowing in a certain direction. The decision on the low interest mortgages was changed. That was because of public demand. Meetings were held in Canberra at which hundreds of people turned up demanding something. We have not seen hundreds of people turning up at public meetings demanding self-government. If we held a referendum we would probably get the same result as we got in 1977, I think it was. I repeat the point that even if all the problems could be corrected, the disallowance of this regulation would not do it. To extend the life of the House of Assembly really flies in the face of the concept of self-government and the handing over of powers if that is what is wanted.

I say in passing, without taking too much of the Senate's time, that those who were on the House of Assembly worked hard. They put a lot of time into their committee work and into their electorate and constituent work. As a consequence, the four Australian Capital Territory members of the House of Representatives and the Senate now have a considerably increased work load. We accept that that is a consequence of the House of Assembly disappearing. But that is not the answer to self-government, if that is the direction in which Senator Vigor wishes to move. Many decisions did not go to the House of Assembly; it did not have legislative power.

This legislation certainly removes the obligation to hold another House of Assembly election. It refers also to the fact that the Minister intends to have an advisory council or an advisory body. He is certainly welcome to do so if that is what he wishes or if he thinks it will be of any benefit to him. He is not obliged to take the advice of an advisory body seriously or to act upon it at all. I was dismayed to see in the explanatory statement to this regulation that the Minister proposed a new elected advisory body. I strongly urge him not to proceed in that direction because I regard the $200,000 to $300,000 which would be required to mount such an election as a gross waste of money. Even if the advisory body were elected the Minister would not be obliged to take its advice. I have no doubt that the Minister would go to great lengths to select a group of people to advise him who would represent the community widely. I do not for a minute think that he would select them all from one corner. Even if he did, it would still be his choice as to whether he accepted their advice or not.

Many things could be said about this matter. I do not think it is an appropriate time to answer all the matters that have been raised by the Democrats' argument in support of this motion which relates more to their Bill for self-government than to the consequences of re-establishing a House of Assembly with no legislative power. The Opposition will not be supporting the Democrats' motion for disallowance because we cannot see, whether one is for self-government or against it, how proceeding to re-elect a House of Assembly, as there was prior to 30 June this year, advances the cause of self-government one way or the other. As I said, we have a benevolent and friendly ministerial dictatorship. It is not necessarily doing everything we might want. But until the people of Canberra start going to public meetings and demanding another form of government and the right to govern themselves, it is a long way before the issue of self-government will again be raised.

Nobody has denied self-government. There is a right for people to govern themselves. I do not think it is necessarily a situation people should be forced into. Until they demand that that should be the case, there will be more and more of these sorts of debates and more and more time spent on inquiries with fewer and fewer consequences as far as the government of Canberra is concerned. We will not support this motion for disallowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the disallowance motion moved by Senator Vigor on behalf of the Australian Democrats for a variety of reasons, some of which have been outlined by Senator Reid. The Government has a philosophical commitment to the principles of self-government. It has always moved towards the principles of self-government, not only with respect to Australia but also with respect to its attitude to the Pacific nations, to the granting of independence to Papua New Guinea and to self-government for the Northern Territory. It has clearly expressed its desire to grant self-government to the citizens of the Australian Capital Territory. The Whitlam Labor Government established the House of Assembly which we saw at that stage as the first step in preparing Canberra for self-government. However, the Government now takes the view that the Assembly has outlived its usefulness. The Government cannot be blamed for the failure of its legislation proposing the establishment of the Australian Capital Territory Council to pass the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vigor went to great lengths to criticise the Government's approach to self-government. However, as he is aware, there was extensive negotiation, consultation and compromise with respect to that legislation. It was not the principle that was at stake in the way in which the Government approached the proposals for self-government; the electoral system was the stumbling block. The Government takes the view that it was elected to govern. Nevertheless, it accepts that the Senate and the other political parties are entitled to express their views on the matter. However, it is the Government's responsibility and obligation to govern. The House of Representatives passed a Bill but the Government was frustrated by the view-which some people might say was dogmatic; it was contested very strongly, particularly by the Democrats-about the form in which the new council would be established in the Australian Capital Territory.

The Government has to accept a number of complexities, as do Canberra citizens, in respect of the granting of self-government to the Australian Capital Territory such as what role local government is to play, the role of the National Capital Development Commission and the differences that obviously would exist in respect of the powers of the Australian Federal Police and the local police. There are a whole range of complexities in this area on which the Government has a view. The Government was prepared to accept that it had to make provisions for any new function or role involved in self-government in the Australian Capital Territory. We accepted our responsibilities in that area and put a Bill through the House of Representatives, then for the consideration of the Senate. But it has been stymied. The Senate was not able to reach an agreement so the Government did not proceed. So any blame in this area should be placed at the Bar of the Senate rather that with the responsibilities of the Government.

The Government has been forced to go back to the old advisory committee which Senator Reid has correctly stated has been with us for a great number of years-with the exception of the Assembly-in excess of 40 years. The Government finds itself in a dilemma because of the Senate not being prepared to agree to the Government's proposals. It has very correctly canvassed public opinion in the Australian Capital Territory. Public opinion is opposed to going back to the old House of Assembly. That is how I am advised and how I read the issue. The Government is, therefore, obliged to take steps so that the Minister does not become the sole decision maker and arbiter, not taking into account the views of the residents of the Australian Capital Territory. So the Government proposes to appoint an advisory body. It believes that in doing so it has the support of the citizens of the national capital.

I am advised that Senator Lewis, who has shadow ministerial responsibility for the Australian Capital Territory, supports this view. I am drawing from Senator Reid's contribution that that is the opinion of the other major political organisations in the Territory. Therefore, the Government does not feel that it is acting outside the general range of public opinion in taking action which is the only course of action available to it now. It is important in the absence of self-government for the Minister responsible for the Australian Capital Territory to have the benefit of the advice of the Canberra community to help him properly run Canberra. That is the alternative to the failure of the Senate to pass the original proposition that has been on the agenda for the last six months or more. This body is designed to achieve that and it is obviously the way in which the views of the Canberra residents can be placed before the Minister.

The Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes), to help decide on the most appropriate advisory body, wrote to a wide cross-section of community groups seeking their opinion and advice on the form that that body should take. The Minister has advised me that the clear majority of these bodies supported the abolition of the House of Assembly and the appointment of a smaller advisory body. I and the Government would support the establishment of a council charged with the responsibility of governing the Australian Capital Territory, but that is not feasible in light of the view that has been so strongly expressed by the Australian Democrats. I remind Senator Vigor that there were differences of opinion in the electoral area among the Government, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. The Government finally came up with a compromise that it felt was suitable in the circumstances, which was to accommodate part of the philosophical position of the Australian Democrats in respect of proportional representation. But that was not acceptable to the Democrats, who insisted upon a form of election that was not acceptable to the Government. So the Government is moving, as a matter of priority, to introduce such a body which will ensure not only that the Minister receives proper advice from the community but also that the taxpayers are protected from unnecessary expense.

Whilst there are properly and genuinely held views on these matters on the part of not only the Democrats but also other sections of the Australian community, the Government is confronted with having to make a decision and to accept its responsibility to govern. To that extent, it cannot accept the disallowance motion moved by Senator Vigor and is going down the road of appointing a representative body to advise the Minister. I hope that that body will work in unity with the Minister in the interests of fulfilling the important functions of proper government for Australian Capital Territory. To that extent we urge the Senate not to support the disallowance motion.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Vigor's) be agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON HUMAN EMBRYO EXPERIMENTATION BILL 1985

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to order, I present the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I understand that by arrangement with the Whips and with the concurrence of the Senate it is intended that I should speak for 15 minutes and the other members of the Committee should speak for 10 minutes each.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not an enforceable order, but I order the clocks to be set to indicate as you have suggested, as a guide to speakers in the debate on the time remaining available to them. But I make it clear that I cannot enforce such an arrangement.

—Mr Deputy President, Australian society has been fortunate to have within it skilled practitioners of reproductive technology who in very recent years have helped many infertile couples achieve a pregnancy which would have been impossible without clinical intervention. Amongst those applications of medical technology is in vitro fertilisation and embryo transfer. This is a process in which a mature human egg is taken from a woman's body and fertilised with sperm in a glass dish. Twenty-four hours later, when the fertilised egg has divided to the two to four cell stage, it is transferred back to the woman's uterus. The Committee welcomes the creative aspects of this technology which has enabled children to be born of some otherwise infertile parents.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been some concern within the community about the process of IVF and its implications for society, particularly because such clinical practice has involved experimentation with human embryos. This Senate Committee has sought to grapple with these issues and it is, I believe, the first committee of parliamen- tarians, at least in the English speaking world, to call for submissions and hear witnesses before discussing the issues. In the event, the report which I present was signed by five of the seven members of the Committee-Senator Sir John Carrick, Senator Harradine, Senator Macklin, Senator Walters and me. Senator Crowley and Senator Zakharov attached a dissenting report and Senator Harradine attached some qualifying comments.

The Committee needed first to reach an understanding of the word `embryo'. The Committee decided to adopt the word `embryo' to describe the entity which results from the completion of the fusion of egg and sperm; that is, from the sequence of events described as fertilisation. Our working definition came to be that the embryo is `genetically new human life organised as a distinct entity oriented towards further development'.

It must be emphasised that the conclusions of the Committee do not depend on the label applied to the entity. The Committee became aware very early that apparently simple descriptions can operate as behaviour governing terms. But in answering the question most commonly posed before the Committee, `What respect is due to the embryo?', the Committee found the language of stages and development inseparable from its consideration both of the proper description of an embryo and consequently of the respect due to it.

In trying to answer that key question this Committee recognised it was operating in a pluralist society and therefore was never attracted to some of the dogmatic certainties which were sometimes put to it. Rather, it looked to certain features of international biomedical ethics and the domestic notion of guardianship to gain some insights and to find some models for the way in which the Australian community might treat the early human embryo.

Medical scientists in Australia subject themselves to considerable constraints on possible experimentation in deference to international ethical principles which have been promulgated in several agreed international codes. The Committee considered that the same principles underlying the Declaration of Helsinki of 1964 should, as a matter of prudence, apply in this area. Thus the Committee adopted as fundamental the distinction between therapeutic and non-therapeutic experimentation and agreed with a basic principle of the Declaration of Helsinki, which states that `concern for the interests of the subject must always prevail over the interests of science and society'.

The Committee does not pretend that the words `human being' or `subject' as used in the various declarations were adopted by those drafting them in such a way as to specifically include embryos. Nevertheless, prudence dictates that until the contrary is demonstrated beyond reasonable doubt, to use an expression well known in our community, the embryo of the human species should be regarded as if it were a human subject for the purposes of biomedical ethics.

The Committee indicated the necessarily developmental language of stages and process which accompany any lively description of the embryo. It is in the embryo's orientation to the future that the Committee finds the feature of the embryo which commands such a degree of respect as to prohibit destructive non-therapeutic experimentation. Points and stages, sometimes called marker events, in the development of the embryo-such as implantation, appearance of the primitive streak and neural groove, cerebral and organic development, consciousness and pain awareness-are significant because they are critical stages in development. Their significance lies precisely in their being stages.

The Committee is of the view that no one event succeeding fertilisation is such that the embryo prior to that event should not be accorded respect by way of protecting its development to a succeeding stage.

The Committee supports therapeutic experimentation on an embryo; that is experimentation carried out with the aim or object of acting in the best interests of the embryo which is the subject of the experimental procedure undertaken-for example, improving culture fluids or transfer techniques. The freezing of embryos awaiting implantation is in certain circum- stances, by the same reasoning, also desirable and indeed necessary.

But the Committee does not support destructive non-therapeutic experimentation which does not directly benefit the embryo undergoing treatment. It may ultimately benefit future embryos or may benefit some aspects of medical science. For example, it was claimed in evidence before the Committee that such experimentation might include research on genetic and development abnormalities, teratogenesis, carcinogenesis and reduction in the number of spontaneous abortions.

Non-therapeutic experimentation on an embryo is, at least at the present, destructive of that embryo. It is that which is beyond the pale. In the future, non-destructive, non-therapeutic procedures may be developed, such as cell biopsy. This conclusion of the Committee, differentiating therapeutic experimentation from destructive non-therapeutic experimentation, accords with the Helsinki Declaration's basic principle that `concern for the interests of the subject must always prevail over the interests of science and society'. The Committee found no ethical or practical basis to distinguish embryos surplus to an optimum implantation regime for a woman from embryos created specifically for experimentation. In the Committee's view neither should be subject to destructive non-therapeutic experimentation.
So, too, the Committee found some guidance in the notion of guardianship, agreeing with the Waller committee reference to the rights of gamete donors:

The Committee does not consider that those rights are absolute just as the rights of parents are limited by the rights and interests of the child, and by the larger concerns of the community in which they all live.

Thus, for the Committee the preferred model is to regard the embryo existing in its glass dish not as property belonging to, but as an entity enjoying the protection of, a guardian. Under this model the property rights of gamete donors are exhausted on fertilisation when an embryo comes into being. At that point guardianship arises and would be ordinarily and properly exercised by the intending social parents, whether or not these are the same persons as the gamete donors.

This approach contrasts markedly with the approach of the dissentients, who move from the fact that society would not commit the gross assault and battery of compelling a woman to accept the transfer of an embryo into her uterus to the conclusion that a woman, or sometimes the joint donors of sperm and egg, has an absolute right to decide to submit the embryo to destructive non-therapeutic experimentation in a situation in which the embryo is simply lying in a glass dish quite independent of any relation to her body.

This thesis of the dissentients cannot deal with the specific creation of embryos for the sole purpose of experimentation, about which they have severe misgivings, nor with a dispute between the donors of egg and sperm as to the fate of the embryo where they are the decision makers.

More fundamentally, the Committee recommends the protective role of the law for the embryo as a matter of caution and prudence until the onus of proving that it should not be treated as a human subject is successfully discharged. It seems to me, with respect, that the dissentients idolise choice and decision by the intended mother as an absolute principle without in any circumstances giving any weight to the countervailing right of the embryo to move to its next stage of development.

Thus the Committee, drawing on these models of international medical ethical principles and guardianship as useful guides, recommends that a Commonwealth statute, whether standing by itself in its limited field of power or, preferably, in company with legislation of the States and the Northern Territory, should set down a broad declaration of principle supporting the creative aspects of reproductive technology, indicating the acceptance of the need for research, including therapeutic experimentation on the human embryo, but making unlawful any destructive non-therapeutic experimentation which frustrates the development of the human embryo.

We recommend that a national body elaborate this broad principle and give it practical application by attaching conditions to licences permitting experimentation within the limits of the broad declaration of principle. It will be apparent that the Committee does not consider that the present system of institutional ethics committees giving voluntary adherence to guidelines nationally promulgated by the National Health and Medical Research Council is adequate. It is highly desirable that the whole Australian community observe uniform ethical standards in a matter as crucial as human embryo experimentation.

Given the need for Commonwealth-State co-operation in this field, the Committee has recommended the adoption of an accreditation and licensing scheme as the most appropriate legal mechanism for regulating experimentation in the field of medical biotechnology. This collaborative Australia-wide model is likely to be more effective than the prohibition model put forward by Senator Harradine with its dependence on the criminal law and the obtaining of injunctions as the sole method of regulation and enforcement.

Therefore, the Committee does not recommend the passage of the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985. The approach of that Bill gave rise to the most persistent theme running through the evidence of most clinicians and scientists appearing before the Committee. The oft expressed fear of those witnesses was that they, and/or their institutions, would be constantly running the gauntlet of expensive and disruptive criminal trials or actions where injunctive relief was sought.

The Committee preferred a scheme whereby approval by a national body of a research protocol, and scrupulous adherence to the conditions of a research licence, should give some assurance to the licence holder that he or she could proceed without being exposed to legal action.

I have no time to elaborate on the structure of the national body which the Committee favours, amongst other things, to issue licenses subject to the broad statutory charter recommended. Time taken to establish it should not preclude an interim licensing mechanism being established by the Commonwealth-State ministerial councils of Attorneys-General and Health Ministers.

It may be with some lack of modesty that I say that I believe this Senate Committee has produced a report which will set new standards in its consideration of these literally vital issues. It has not shirked any of the ethical issues. It has come to hard conclusions. It has devised a practical licensing scheme which will ensure on the one hand that IVF clinics and accompanying research continue to play a role in the treatment of some infertile couples in Australia, but on the other hand it has put beyond the pale certain experiments on the human embryo of a destructive non-therapeutic kind.

I thank the secretariat-Pippa Carron, Glenys Roper and Fiona Hendy-for their assistance in the compiling of this report. But it is to my colleagues in the Senate serving on this Select Committee that the highest tribute is due. As politicians elected by and accountable to the Australian community they have worked under considerable pressure to produce this report. We hope and trust that the report will serve infertile couples and the whole community well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985, of which I am a member, was given seven terms of reference by this Senate. Abbreviating them, they were, firstly, to decide whether, for the purposes of in vitro fertilisation, it is necessary or desirable for research to be done on the human embryo by way of manipulation, dissection or administration of drugs; secondly, if that is so, whether there should be guidelines; thirdly, if that it so, whether it is necessary and desirable to freeze embryos; fourthly, whether it is necessary and desirable to discard embryos, and, if so, under what conditions; fifthly, whether the Harradine Bill requires amendment; sixthly, whether there ought to be sanctions or prohibitions for breaches of research limitation; and, finally, whether legislation is desirable.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek very briefly to examine those terms of reference and I do so against the background of three main thrusts: Firstly, the very understandable desire of otherwise infertile couples to have families and, against that background, the need, wherever possible, to help them to achieve that goal; secondly, the very great successes that Australian scientists, medical scientists in particular, have had in aiding the overcoming of infertility, whether by a range of other means or by what has now become known as in vitro fertilisation and embryo transfer; and, thirdly, and most importantly, the eternal search for knowledge by all scientists and human beings, particularly in the field of genetics, in the field of understanding of the chromosomes, of the genes they contain, in the frontier work that is being done on the double helix, and in seeking to understand DNA and its effect on the origins and course of human life.

I believe that against that background the Committee has approached its task sensibly and thoroughly. As to the first term of reference, the Committee has commended the approach to over- coming infertility and has recognised that there is a need and a desirability for research, but that that research should be therapeutic research aimed at the benefit of the subject and that, therefore, there is a need for some manipulation and, indeed, perhaps for some drug therapy, such as adding potassium or other chemicals to the culture. Secondly, the Committee has found that it is necessary to have guidelines so that there is uniformity throughout Australia. I have to say that if there was one common theme of virtually every witness before the Committee, it was the desirability for a national and uniform approach to the whole of this procedure.

Thirdly, the Committee looked at the question of freezing embryos. It knew that under the present process of super-ovulation by the use of hormone stimulation there were likely to be embryos that would not be needed for the first implantation, which would be of approximately three embryos, that the first cycle of implantation might not succeed due to a hostile condition of the uterus and that therefore there was a desirability to hold, in frozen form, embryos for a second or further implantation. The Committee looked at the relatively new procedure of freezing ova, or female eggs. It noted that there had been some success in Australia, particularly with Dr Chan, noted the announcement of the birth of twins from frozen ova, and expressed the view that should this procedure be proven, it would largely, if not totally, eliminate the need for freezing embryos. It would then be possible to freeze ova and simply to inseminate them when necessary, in terms of implantation, so that there would not be a necessity for frozen embryos. However, the Committee noted that one should try to reduce the number of frozen embryos and/or the concept of spare embryos to an absolute minimum.

The Committee looked at the question of discarding embryos. It revealed that in the final event a procedure should be set up where the number of so-called spare embryos should be at an absolute minimum, if possible, none at all, but realising that due to a whole series of events-the breakdown of a marriage, accident, illness, divorce, death, or indeed the absence of another willing parent-there could be some spare embryos. Therefore, the Committee concluded that they should not be subject to adverse experimentation and concluded that they should be allowed to succumb. The Committee concluded that the Harradine Bill contains some disabilities and should not be the instrument for regulation in this area. It recognised that if there is to be a national approach there would need to be sanctions and prohibitions. It has put forward such thoughts and has suggested a form of legislation.

The Committee looked at the definition of an embryo and, as Senator Tate has said, it came forward with a universally accepted definition for all members of the Committee recognising the fundamental basis of the embryo being a genetically new human life organised as a distinct entity oriented towards further development. The Committee looked at various marker events. It was suggested to the Committee by a number of people that there were marker events of such significance along the journey that there would be a major change in the respect that society or the individual should direct towards an embryo. It was suggested that such a marker event was implantation. Various periods were prescribed by other committees around the world. It was suggested by some that 14 days would be a suitable period, that up to that period experimentation could take place but after that period it would not take place at all.

The Committee noted an interesting factor. In the early days of the embryo-the first five, six or seven days-it had the potential for implantation but after that number of days had passed implantation was impossible and the embryo could no longer take a course of evolution of life. The Committee puzzled at those committees that recommended, curiously enough, that one could experiment on an embryo during that period that it had a potential for life but not after such potential had gone. Therefore the Committee believed there was no particular marker event of sufficient significance to alter the degree of respect an embryo should receive.

The Committee noted one other point. The real probing of genetics to discover diseases is done by taking cells from living human beings-children and adults suffering from defects. The probing of genes in order to discover disease is not done on the embryo. In its first 14 days it is undifferentiated in its cells, tissues and organs and therefore much cannot be done. The availability of tissue on others allows the development of unrestricted research in probing genetic defects. If cell biopsy can be proven as it is in mice at the moment it will enable that detection without disturbing the embryo. I believe that the Committee has approached this subject, which is enormous in its moral, ethical, religious and scientific aspects, with a sense of responsibility and that it has made sensible recommendations and conclusions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I introduced the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill in April last year because of my concern, based on a substantial volume of information, that experiments detrimental to the human embryo were being undertaken both in this country and elsewhere. The Bill was referred to a Senate select committee. I say here and now that I have worked on a number of committees, and I agree with what Senator Macklin has said. The Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill has worked extremely hard. The Chairman has attempted to meet the deadlines placed on this Committee by the Senate, and I believe that all members of the Committee and its staff have discharged their responsibilities in the traditions of this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the report of the Senate Select Committee. I am pleased that it recommends a legislative ban on any experiment which would frustrate the development of a human embryo from fertilisation onwards. I am honoured that the Committee found that the central principle of my Bill was quite basic to its own ultimate response to the reference given to it by the Senate. I should like also to pay tribute to the 132,000 people throughout the length and breadth of Australia who petitioned Parliament in support of the Bill, and the many persons eminently qualified in the fields of science, medicine, ethics, political life, community life and the law who recognised that human embryo experimentation poses grave problems for the whole world, and needs to be resolved on the basis of a fundamental premise.

The Committee concluded that its major findings and recommendations accord with and help sustain the principles underlying medical bioethics as understood in the international community, and the institution of guardianship as understood in our domestic legal system. The report referred to the international agreements concerning biomedical research which arose primarily from the concern of the international community over the eugenics programs advanced by the Third Reich and inhuman experiments conducted by doctors in Nazi Germany. At the heart of these agreements was the principle that in any biomedical procedure involving human subjects `the interests of the subject must always prevail over the interests of science and society'. The report makes it clear that, for the purposes of biomedical ethics, the embryo of the human species must be regarded as a human subject.

In firmly rejecting the concept apparently followed by the National Health and Medical Research Council that a human embryo can be treated as property, the Committee recommends that the concept of guardianship is the most appropriate to indicate the respect due to the human embryo. The Committee also noted that, in any guardianship, the welfare of the ward is paramount and that, in this instance, the rights of the guardian are to be exercised on behalf of, and in the best interests of, the embryo resulting from in vitro fertilisation.

The Committee report challenges the basis of the National Health and Medical Research Council's guidelines which allow for any type of experiment up to the state at which implantation would normally occur. Such guidelines have generated a permissive atmosphere for human embryo experimentation in Australia. The Committee reported that it could see nothing which marked the National Health and Medical Research Council marker event as other than a significant event in a continuum of development until birth. The Committee found that the present system of institutional ethics committees, voluntarily adhering to nationally promulgated NHMRC guidelines, was not adequate. Instead, the Committee advocates legal protection for the human embryo. As the Committee stated, there should be a `protective role of the law for an embryo, such that obligations are cast on persons not to knowingly frustrate its development by destructive non-therapeutic experimentation'.

The Committee recommends that Parliament adopt the chief recommendations of the report as the basic statutory principles underlying research on human embryos in Australia. These principles would make unlawful any destructive non-therapeutic experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo. Because power over clinical medicine and biomedical research rests largely with State parliaments, the Committee recommends Federal-State co-operation to establish uniform accreditation and licensing processes for institutions within which human embryo experimentation might occur. A national body would be established which would draw up guidelines consistent with a statutory principle protecting human embryos from damaging non-therapeutic experimentation. Research would be unlawful unless the institution concerned submitted a research protocol to a national body and a licence was issued. The national body would be required to establish and to act within guidelines consistent with the statutory principle protecting human embryos from injury which frustrates their development.

I point out that, whilst the Committee goes beyond the Warnock and Waller reports, it builds on the reports of the Waller and Asche committees. The Senate Committee's report is, I would think, more like the decision of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe which was taken on 24 September last and which I have only just received and scanned. In fact, as the Chairman of the Committee would appreciate, we had put our report to bed well and truly before then. I seek leave to have the decision incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

RECOMMENDATION 1046 (1986) (1)
on the use of human embryos and foetuses for diagnostic, therapeutic, scientific, industrial and commercial purposes
The Assembly,

1. Recalling its Recommendation 934 (1982) on genetic engineering, proposing a range of measures including in particular the recognition of the right to a genetic inheritance which should not be artificially interfered with except for therapeutic purposes;
2. Considering that recent progress in the life sciences and medicine, in particular in animal and human embryology, has opened up remarkable new scientific, diagnostic and therapeutic prospects;
3. Considering that, by the technique of fertilisation in vitro, man has achieved the means of intervening in and controlling human life in its earliest stages;
4. A. Considering that the exploitation of technological opportunities not only in science but also in medicine must be governed by clear ethical and social guidelines;

B. Considering that future benefits from the advance of medical science and technology must be carefully assessed in deciding when, and how, and on what grounds, to restrict the exploitation of technological opportunities;

C. Welcoming the contributions of the Council of Europe's ad hoc committee of experts in the biomedical sciences, and of the European medical research councils operating within the framework of the European Science Foundation;
D. Noting the statement issued by nine European medical research councils following the meeting convened in London 5-6 June 1986 under the auspices of the European Science Foundation;

5. Considering that, from the moment of fertilisation of the ovula, human life develops in a continuous pattern, and that it is not possible to make a clear-cut distinction during the first phases (embryonic) of its development, and that a definition of the biological status of an embryo is therefore necessary;
6. Aware that this progress had made the legal position of the embryo and foetus particularly precarious, and that their legal status is at present not defined by law;
7. Aware that adequate provisions governing the use of living or dead embryos and foetuses do not at present exist;

8. Convinced that, in view of scientific progress which makes it possible to intervene in developing human life from the moment of fertilisation, it is urgent to define the extent of its legal protection;
9. Having regard to the variety of ethical opinion on the question of using the embryo or the foetus or their tissues, and to the conflicts between values which arise;

10. Considering that human embryos and foetuses must be treated in all circumstances with the respect due to human dignity, and that use of materials and tissues therefrom must be strictly limited and regulated (see Appendix) to purposes which are clearly therapeutic and for which no other means exist;

11. Convinced that the use of embryos or foetuses and the removal of their tissues for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes are only justified if the principles and conditions specified in the Appendix to this recommendation are observed;

12. Considering that any exclusively national regulation of the question runs the risk of being ineffective as any activity in this field could be transferred to another country which did not enforce the same regulations;
13. Stressing the need for European co-operation,
14. Recommends that the Committee of Ministers:
A. Call on the governments of the member states:
(i) to investigate the rumours about a trade in dead embryos and foetuses circulating in the media, and to publish the results;

(ii) to limit the use of human embryos and foetuses and materials and tissues therefrom in an industrial context to purposes which are strictly the-rapeutic and for which no other means exist, according to the principles set out in the Appendix, and to bring their legislation into line with these principles or to enact rules in accordance therewith which should inter alia specify the conditions in which removal and use may be undertaken for a diagnostic or therapeutic purpose;
(iii) to forbid any creation of human embryos by fertilisation in vitro for the purposes of research during their life or after death;
(iv) to forbid all that could be considered as undesirable use or deviations of these techniques, including:
- the creation of identical human beings by cloning or any other method, whether for race selection purposes or not;
- the implantation of a human embryo in the uterus of another animal or the inverse;
- the fusion of human gametes with those of another animal (the hamster test for the study of male fertility could be regarded as an exception, under strict regulation);
- the creation of embryos from the sperm of different individuals;
- the fusion of embryos or any other operation which might produce chimeras;
- ectogenesis, or the production of an individual and autonomous human being outside the uterus of a female, i.e. in a laboratory;
- the creation of children from people of the same sex;
- choice of sex by genetic manipulation for non-therapeutic purposes;
- the creation of identical twins;
- research on viable human embryos;
- experimentation on living human embryos, whether viable or not;
- the maintenance of embryos in vitro beyond the 14th day after fertilisation (having deducted any time necessary for freezing);
(v) to provide appropriate sanctions to ensure the application of the rules enacted pursuant to this recommendation;
(vi) to create national registers of accredited medical centres authorised to carry out such techniques and to make use of them for scientific purposes;

(vii) to facilitate and encourage the creation of national multidisciplinary committees or commissions on artificial genetic material, human embryos and foetuses,-to guide and counsel the medical and scientific authorities, to follow and control the application of such techniques, and to authorise specific projects in the absence of concrete legislation or regulation;

B. Continue to study the problem relating to the use of human embryosus and foetal tissue for scientific purposes and prepare, on the basis of the points mentioned in sub-paragraphs 14.A (ii) to (vii), a European convention or any other suitable legal instrument which would also be open to accession by non-member countries of the Council of Europe;

15. Instructs its competent committees to prepare a report on the use of human embryos and foetuses in scientific research, taking into account the necessary balance between the principles of freedom of research and of respect for human life and other aspects of human rights.
