APPENDIX
Rules governing the use of human embryos or foetuses and the removal of their tissues for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes
A. Diagnostic purposes

i. No intervention for diagnostic purposes, other than those already authorised under national legislation, on the living embryo in vitro or in utero or the foetus whether inside or outside the uterus shall be permitted, unless its object is the well-being of the child to be born and the promotion of its development.
ii. The use of a dead embryo and foetus for diagnostic purposes (confirmation of a diagnosis in utero or search for the cause of a spontaneous termination of pregnancy) shall be permitted.
B. Therapeutic purposes

i. No intervention for therapeutic purposes on the living embryo in vitro or in utero or the foetus whether inside or outside the uterus shall be permitted unless its object is the well-being of the child to be born, i.e. to facilitate its development and birth.

ii. Therapy on embryos in vitro or in utero or on the foetus in utero shall not be permitted, unless it is for very clear and precisely diagnosed embryonic maladies, with grave or extremely bad prognosis, where no other solution is possible and therapy would offer reasonable guarantees of successful treatment of those illnesses.
iii. It shall be forbidden to keep embryos or foetuses alive artificially for the purpose of removing usable material.

iv. It would be desirable to create a list of those illnesses where therapy can be based on reliable means of diagnosis and reasonable guarantees of success. This list would be periodically up-dated to take account of new discoveries and scientific progress.
v. Therapy conducted on embryos and foetuses must never influence non-pathological hereditary characteristics, nor have racial selection as its aim.

vi. The use of dead embryos or foetuses must be an exceptional measure, justified in the present state of knowledge by the rare nature of the illness treated, the absence of any equally effective therapy and a manifest advantage (such as survival) for the person receiving treatment; it must comply with the following rules:

(a) the decision to terminate pregnancy and the conditions of termination (date, technique, etc) must under no circumstances be influenced by the possible or desired subsequent use of the embryo or foetus;

(b) any use of the embryo or foetus must be undertaken by highly qualified teams in approved hospitals or scientific centres supervised by the public authorities; to the extent that national legislation foresees, these centres must posses multi-disciplinary ethical committees;
(c) total independence between the medical team terminating the pregnancy and the team which might use the embryos or foetuses for therapeutic purposes must be guaranteed;
(d) embryos and foetuses may not be used without the consent of the parents or gamete donors where the latter's identity is known;
(e) the use of embryos, foetuses or their tissues for profit or remuneration shall not be allowed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dehumanising experiments on human embryos cheapen the concept of life and are a threat to other human rights within our society. They have implications for a general community that is only now becoming aware of the nature of the threat. I am aware-and evidence was given to us from a utilitarian aspect-that this philosophy of utilitarians permeates, to a certain extent, certain scientists and other areas of medicine. Such was the evidence given to us by Professor Peter Singer.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the building blocks of any civilised society would soon crumble if we were to concede that the end justifies the means and approve the concept of experimentation on some human subjects for the benefit of others. That is not a principle on which the law can reasonably or safely be founded. The ball now is in the court of the Government and, in particular, the court of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). This is not a matter to be left to the self-regulation of scientists or a medical ethics committee; it is a major question of public policy for government and parliaments in a democratic society to determine. The Parliament would betray its public trust were it not to act urgently on the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The inquiry just completed by the Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985 has been one of the most complex, controversial, emotive and technical that a committee could undertake. For this reason the Committee attempted to abide by scientific evidence and expertise in coming to its conclusions. I congratulate the secretariat staff for their help, particularly in the technical areas, as their background information was invaluable to us.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that the human embryo genetically is a new human life. The Committee took evidence from eminent scientists and medical and individual experts. We took evidence from government departments and social organisations throughout Australia. None attempted to argue that the human embryo was other than a developing human being. Many opinions were expressed about the value, respect and protection that should be afforded that embryo at various stages of its development, but there was little dissent regarding its future development into a human subject. From such evidence the Committee formed the opinion that the human embryo deserved respect and protection according to its status as human.

Over many years medical scientists relied on world bodies to set ethical guidelines to ensure constraints-bodies such as the World Health Organisation and the Council for International Organisations of Medical Science-as well as on several international codes. The Declaration of Helsinki is one such code which the Committee felt was appropriate to apply in this area. Its introduction states in part:

In the field of biomedical research a fundamental distinction must be recognised between medical research in which the aim is essentially diagnostic or therapeutic for a patient, and medical research, the essential object of which is purely scientific and without direct diagnostic or therapeutic value to the person subjected to the research.

The Committee did not pretend that this Declaration was specifically meant to cover embryos, but the Committee was of the opinion that the human embryo genetically was new human life developing as a distinct entity. As such, the Committee considered it appropriate that there be no experimental intervention that would frustrate the embryo's future development. Because the words `prohibited experimentation' in the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill caused so much confusion, the Committee took much trouble to clarify just what was meant. The clarification the Committee chose was taken from the Declaration of Helsinki, as I said. The Committee observed the distinction between therapeutic experimentation and non-therapeutic experimentation. Therapeutic experimentation is defined as experimentation of a diagnostic or curative value and non-therapeutic experimentation is that undertaken purely as an advancement in scientific or medical knowledge and of no diagnostic or curative value.

While the Committee acknowledges that there can be grey areas in which the intention of the scientist may be queried, the Committee believes that those cases can be submitted to an expert body which is able to assess the situation. As I have indicated, conflicting evidence was presented to the Committee as to the value, respect and protection that should be afforded the embryo at the various stages of its development. We were told that, unless non-therapeutic experimentation was able to be carried out on at least the pre-implantation stage of the embryo, knowledge regarding many medical problems such as thalassaemia and Down's syndrome would be considerably delayed or never attained. However, Professor Lejeune from Foundation Genesis explained that an abundance of cells relating to these medical problems is available in human beings after birth and there is no need to obtain such material from the early embryo.

Various committees, scientists and philosophers have indicated that the community should accept various marker events as being of such significance that respect and protection can vary during the developing stages of the embryo. I quote briefly from the Warnock report which stated:
One reference point in the development of the human individual is the formation of the primitive streak.
The Waller Committee considered that the marker event was:
. . . beyond the stage of implantation, which is completed 14 days after fertilisation.
Dr Jansen stated that the National Health and Medical Research Council had chosen implantation as the marker event. He said:
At that time the embryonic disc has not differentiated into various parts that could be called parts of an embryo.

Suggestions have been made that any type of experimentation should be permitted on embryos from fertilisation to the stage of implantation. The Committee could not understand the thinking behind suggestions that would allow destructive experimentation on an embryo during the stage of viability-that is, between fertilisation and implantation-but once the embryo has reached the stage beyond implantation and is no longer viable or able to develop to its full potential experimentation is no longer approved of.

However, to get back to the contention that the stage of implantation is a significant marker event in the development of the human embryo and that no additional respect and protection should be afforded the embryo following that event, in evidence on behalf of the National Health and Medical Research Council ethics committee Professor Richard Lovell stated:
It was put to us that when implantation is complete it is a definable landmark in the development of the foetus. It is now in place-it is talking to its mother.
Professor Lejeune stated:
There is no special landmark that we could use to tell us that there is a change in the status of the embryo . . . but there are only stages of its development.
Dr Trounson, when describing the Warnock and Waller committees, stated:
I do not see that there is a magical change between day 13 and day 14. It just happens to be an arbitrary time.

The Committee agreed with the majority of the evidence and believed that Dr Trounson was correct when he said that. We have therefore decided that the embryo of the human species from fertilisation should be regarded as a human subject for the purposes of biomedical ethics. The Committee recommended:
that the principle protecting the embryo from destructive non-therapeutic experimentation be adopted by the Senate in its consideration of this matter.

Because of the short time available to Committee members to debate this report I am unable to give any further detail, but I believed that it was crucial to the understanding of the Committee's report to deal with that particular area. There is great concern in the community regarding research in areas other than experimentation using embryos. I refer, for example, to cloning. It is because of these concerns that a Commonwealth statute should be established so that a national licensing body may follow its broad declarations of principles. As I indicated when I began my speech, the inquiry was a very complex and technical one and because time has not allowed me to go in detail into the other matters in the report I do commend its reading by all interested parties. It is essential that the report be read in full.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I make any comments on the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1986 and lead off for the minority or dissenting report, I wish to take the opportunity to thank our Chairman, Senator Michael Tate. I have had the pleasure of serving on previous committees with Senator Tate and as ever he has been tolerant and efficient and has guided this report through in under 12 months. In that time we have had a comprehensive examination of the material obtained from other inquiries, 270 submissions, nine public hearings and the evidence of 64 witnesses, so I think anyone reading the report can feel comfortable that we sought very wide information before coming to our conclusions. I think it should be said, too, that throughout the proceedings Senator Tate chaired with his usual grace. I place on record my appreciation for that, particularly as I, as one of the senators dissenting from the majority report, never felt at any time that the Committee or the Chair found that problematic. That is not to say that we agreed, but we did not become divisive about it. I would like also to thank the other members of the Committee. I endorse Senator Macklin's comments that we did a lot of learning on this Committee. In particular I would like to thank our secretarial staff, Dr Pippa Carron, the Secretary; Glenys Roper, a research officer; and Fiona Hendy, the steno-secretary. Their assistance in the Committee's work and our further demands due to the dissenting report was always willing, cheerful and helpful. I am pleased to acknowledge their contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: The minority report differs very significantly from the majority report-I will use those terms for clarification for those people listening-because it was the contention of those of us who wrote the minority report that the focus of this inquiry had to be on who should decide about embryos before any effort was made to address what should be decided. We felt very strongly that the in vitro fertilisation program is like any other program of medical treatment or health care. It involves a contract based on informed consent between the couple or the patient and the treating doctor or specialist. It is not a contract between a doctor and an embryo. The couple, either the gamete donors, that is the donors of egg and sperm, and/or the woman into whose uterus the embryo is placed, are the contracting persons. They are seeking treatment for their infertility and they understand after adequate counselling what is entailed in the IVF program, what will be required of them and what the outcomes are likely to be. Those outcomes go all the way from no successful implantation or successful implantation with no progress to full pregnancy, to a full term baby. Another outcome is a full term baby which may sometimes be deformed or abnormal. It is a risk laden treatment program, as any couple involved in it knows. As in any other area of medical treatment all reasonable steps to reduce the risks are part of responsible medical practice; that is, continuing research and experimentation on all phases and stages of the program is desirable to achieve optimal outcome for the couples. Logically this means that there has to be relevant research on human embryos.

We agree with the majority report's definition of an embryo, although we do comment in point D.14 that we accept that the word `embryo' should apply from the time of conception only so as to reduce confusion in the community as to what is being talked about. We also differ with the majority report in that we conclude that there is a marker event of such significance that differences of behaviour and regard may pertain to the embryo before and after that event. The majority report comments, and we agree, that the birth of a baby is a marker event of such significance that different things and different attitudes pertain to it prior to and after that event. We suggest that implantation and/or the emergence of the embryonic disk is a similar such marker event; that is, different attitudes, or different regard, can ascribe to the embryo prior to and after implantation. We also see the importance of the marker event not only in terms of what shall be done before and after but also, importantly, in terms of who shall decide. The marker event is critical in regard to the necessity for a woman to accept an embryo into her uterus for the development of that embryo. The marker event is significant and it is reinforced by the necessity of implantation.

We find it remarkable that the majority report concludes that a woman would have the right at that stage not to accept any embryo into her uterus, and yet disallows her to make choices prior to that significant event. We conclude that the right to decide at the time of implantation properly ascribes to her the right to decide prior to that stage. Senator Tate claimed in his remarks that our conclusions allow a woman full rights to destruction of the embryo in the petri dish. I would chide him for what I think is unnecessarily emotive language. We argue that it is the couple's or the woman's right to decide about the embryo and that many will decide for the full development of the embryo. Not all women who make decisions, or who have decision rights ascribed to them, are necessarily going to seek destruction of the embryo in the petri dish. In fact the evidence from IVF programs is that women and couples choose contrary to that. They are seeking a satisfactory implantation, a satisfactory pregnancy and the development of a full term baby. They are seeking pregnancy and childbirth, not the destruction of embryos.

We know that women going through the development of embryos or foetuses in their uteruses do make a variety of decisions. We know that our community is pluralist and I see no reason to suggest that it will not be pluralist about the decisions that women and/or couples will make about embryos. I would say, in support of our prior claim, that it is the parent's and/or the woman's right to decide and that those rights ascribe to decisions about the embryo.

I also remind people that the sort of embryo we are talking about need not necessarily be thought of as human in the way that we think of a child. On the front of the report there is a photograph of a four cell embryo magnified I think 300 times, and it is at that point barely visible to the naked eye. Even at about the fourteenth day of development an embryo has reached the size of only a speck of dust. How anyone can equate that to a fully developed child I do not understand. I do not disagree, neither does my colleague, Senator Zakharov, with the definition of an embryo or the understanding of its potential, but an embryo does not equate with a child.

For these reasons we conclude that the report deciding in terms of the Helsinki guidelines is inappropriate. Those guidelines mention volunteers, human beings, persons and subjects. None of those terms properly apply to an embryo. They properly apply to the subject-being the woman or the couple-and the ability to make choices, but they do not properly apply to embryos; nor does the description in the National Health and Medical Research Council guidelines regarding therapeutic research for children who are mentally retarded or dependent in some way apply. Again, a child does not equate with an embryo. If people wonder about this further I urge them to look at our dissenting report where we elaborate those points. We submit that as those guidelines do not clearly address embryos, the best thing might be that further decisions are taken to look more specifically at rights regarding embryos, if that is how people decide they want to go.

We also feel very strongly that the distinction between therapeutic and non-therapeutic experimentation, as in the majority report, is very vague, very confused, and I think could lead to considerable doubt about whether an experiment is non-therapeutic or therapeutic, and whether it is allowable. We conclude that we should allow the parents, the gamete donors, the woman into whose uterus the embryo will be replaced, to be the decision makers, to make decisions that parents have made over centuries regarding the development of their children, the decision to procreate or not. In so doing, and in structuring our report around this as the main focus, we avoid many of the contradictions that are inherent in the majority report. Principally, to argue that a woman may decide not to accept an embryo into her uterus, therefore guaranteeing that it will have to succumb, but not to allow her to take a decision that she might regard as responsible, given the counsel and advice of her treating doctors or other therapists that it may possibly lead to the destruction of the embryo, seems to me a very curious inconsistency.

This dissenting report is not saying that one can do anything one likes with embryos. In fact, we oppose such things as cloning and experimentation with human and animal gametes. We have very little difference with the conclusions drawn by the majority report about a national body and the importance of that, but we suggest that its priority requirement once established ought to go to a clarification that the parents, the gamete donors, or the woman into whose uterus the embryo will be replaced, are the principal decision makers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lest I run out of time, I thank the other members of the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985 for their ability to disagree amicably. I thank the Chairman for his contribution, particularly to the final draft, when the pressure of time was great. I also thank the secretariat for their excellent work in researching and organising very complex subject matter to make it readily accessible to members of the Committee. I thank Senator Crowley for her major contribution to our dissenting report and for her contribution to today's debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Before speaking to our dissent from the report, I would like to quote one of the recommendations of the Committee with which I am wholeheartedly in agreement, that is, that the Committee does not recommend the passage of the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985. Regrettably, however, I believe that some of the conclusions of the report do not diverge sufficiently from the intentions of that Bill and appear to accept much of its underlying philosophy. I believe that that philosophy is out of step with majority community attitudes, and I will expand on that later. At this point I report that the vast majority of the correspondence and other communications I received on the Bill before the Select Committee was set up saw the Bill as an attack on the in vitro fertilisation programs and in particular on the rights of parents who wish to have children through those programs. We have addressed that question, which the report dismisses as a result of misapprehension, at some length in the dissenting report and I will not take time to discuss it here.

The other fear expressed by many of my constituents, particularly women, was that legislation of this type, ostensibly to prohibit certain types of experiments on human embryos, might provide a basis or precedent for future legislation limiting the rights of women adequately to control their fertility. It was clear that some witnesses before the Committee regarded therapeutic abortion and even the use of intrauterine devices as requiring, in their value system, the same prohibitions they wished applied to human embryo experimentation. The fundamental reason for my dissent from the Committee's report is directed to the main emphasis and underlying philosophy of the whole report: It is embryo-centred rather than person-centred. Because of this priority, the report accords disproportionate rights to a group of cells-as few as four-while giving less than full rights of decision making to the potential parents of the potential child. Thus it ignores the priorities held, I believe, by the majority of our community that the born are clearly qualitatively different from the unborn; that the zygote, or early embryo, before implantation in the uterus is clearly qualitatively different from the potential human being after it has implanted in the uterus and thus gained the necessary conditions to survive and grow.
As the National Health and Medical Research Council Ethics Committee has said:
Historically the community has never accorded to early human embryos the degree of protection it has accorded to the later developing foetus and the still greater protection given later to the child.

Further, the average woman does not grieve when menstruation may signal the demise of an ovum fertilised in the previous two weeks. She may grieve for a miscarriage, but not to the extent that she does for the death of a baby or a child, when her grief will be felt also by family and friends. So society does not accord the same respect to the early embryo as it does to the neonate, let alone the adult. I believe that in this matter some members of the Committee have given undue weight to the arguments of some theologians and groups in the community whose commitment to human rights is focused on the unborn rather than the born, and who came before the Committee under a number of different titles.

This focus on the embryo has led the Committee in its report to assign the right of decision making to those with no direct relationship to the embryo. Our dissenting report recommends that the right to make decisions about the embryo rightly belongs to the mother or parents of that embryo in consultation with their doctors and/or other members of the IVF team. We say that this is what applies to embryos produced naturally, in vivo, and that there is no need to shift responsibility elsewhere just because the embryo spent a short time in a petri dish. If we say that some outside body has the right to make the decisions about the embryo in the petri dish, it is a small step in logic to say that an outside body should make decisions about the same embryo after implantation or about embryos in vivo at the same stage of development. I also hold that guardians are not required where there are responsible parents, as applies in this case.

Our advocacy of the prospective parents as decision makers has implications for a number of other sections of the report and these are spelt out in our dissent. Most importantly, it has implications for any legislative or other regulation of human embryo experimentation. The majority report bases its proposals for regulation on the Helsinki guidelines, which have been referred to earlier, yet the Helsinki signatories were not considering embryos, and I do not believe that the Committee has legitimately adopted the Helsinki guidelines as a precedent for its own. The NHMRC guidelines, made much more recently and recognised by their authors as not being the final word, are much more relevant to current needs. We recommend that any national body should support the creative aspect of reproductive technology and recognise the rights of gamete donors, or parents, and/or the woman in whose uterus the embryo is placed. These conclusions we have made about decision making have implications for other aspects of the terms of reference, such as the disposition of spare embryos, but time does not permit me to discuss them here.

I want briefly to refer to the matter of informed consent and the related question of the need for good counselling as part of the decision-making process. As a psychologist and an experienced counsellor I have listened with interest to criticisms of the counselling available to couples on IVF programs. I have discussed this with some of those couples, I have talked with counsellors at IVF units, and I have read their information sheets and consent forms. I believe that much of the criticism is ill-founded. Clients or patients are often in a state of aroused emotion while on the program, so it is easy to forget that they have been given realistic advice about the chances of successful pregnancy and to seek scapegoats if they are disappointed. It must be recognised that the level of counselling available, to my knowledge, is superior to that usually provided for elective surgery, for example, which also involves informed consent. IVF is a matter of choice, so consent is vital to the contract. Nobody is forced to enter an IVF program. That choice is in the hands of the prospective parents, and I believe it is denigrating them to suggest, as some witnesses have, that the couple, particularly the woman, is in some way being manipulated by the doctors and scientists. This is taking a very paternalistic or, in this context, maternalistic attitude to the couple and/or the woman.

In this brief time I will obviously not be able to speak of every aspect of the dissenting report. I hope that all honourable senators will take the time to read it. I hope that the Senate and the Government will consider very critically the Committee report and its implications for IVF programs and far beyond and at the hidden agendas which may be contained in it. Those implications include research into the causes of infertility, improved contraception, and simpler solutions for infertility, including ova freezing. I have concern that the community is not yet ready to make a final decision on the implications of this new technology and is not yet aware of the possible benefits as well as the hazards.

There is a danger that the Committee has given undue credence to a preponderance of socially conservative views given to it in evidence, views which I do not believe are held by the majority of the Australian community. I believe that we are at the beginning of community debate on these issues, not the end. We have found it hard in the past to remove outgrown draconian measures, such as corporal punishment for prisoners. Let us hasten slowly in this matter. I hope that both reports make a significant contribution to the community debate and sound regulation. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday during the debate a number of matters were raised by Senator Siddons and other honourable senators relating to the legislation before the Chair. Answers have been prepared for the convenience of honourable senators. It was asked why the Government was taxing intellectual property for the first time by this Bill. I point out that computer software, which is intellectual property, has always been subject to sales tax. When sold as part of goods it is subject to the same rate of tax as the carrying medium on which it is contained. However, when licensed separately from the carrying medium, it is argued that the software technically escapes sales tax. This Bill simply restores the sales tax position of computer software to what has always been intended. It is simply not correct to assert that this is a new tax on intellectual property.

SPEECH.PARA: The question was raised of whether multinationals can avoid liability to the tax by transferring software by electronic means. The Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), when introducing the Bill, announced that its provisions did not extend to the electronic transfer of software via satellite or the domestic telephone system. This is because such transfers do not ordinarily involve a carrying medium and, as explained, the amendments are designed to restore the intended operation of the sales tax law. If no carrying medium is involved there is no `goods' on which sales tax is payable. As the Minister indicated in his second reading speech, the Government is looking closely at this question and an announcement will be made as soon as the Government has completed its examination.

Another question raised concerned computer software used as aids to manufacture. The information I have shows that computers used exclusively and principally to operate manufacturing equipment presently qualify for sales tax exemption. The Bill does not alter this situation. The Bill does, however, treat two processes as manufacture for sales tax purposes. They are the copying or reproduction of a computer program or the conversion of a computer program to another language, code or notation so as to embody the program in goods. To the extent that machinery is used exclusively or principally in these processes it will qualify as an aid to manufacture and be exempt from sales tax. Similarly, if computer software is used exclusively or principally as an aid to manfacture, that is, to control, the production line, it will be exempt from sales tax.

Another question raised was whether goods containing computer software that are exported from Australia are subject to sales tax. I am informed that there is no, nor has there ever been any, liability to sales tax in relation to the export of goods from Australia that contain computer software. The Bill does not alter this position. Computer software developed for the export market and actually exported remains exempt from sales tax.

Another question raised was whether the development of a computer program is accepted as research and development for income tax purposes. The answer provided states that the mere development of a computer program does not of itself give rise to an entitlement to the 150 per cent income tax concession for research and development. A program could satisfy the requirements of the income tax law if it could be shown to be sufficiently innovative, for example, a new computer language. The program would also have to be intended for mass distribution. If software is developed to support a particular research and development project, the cost of developing that software would also qualify for the income tax concession as ancillary to research and development expenditure. Put simply, very little computer programming would qualify as research and development for income tax purposes.

It was stated during the debate that if imported master tapes are exempt from sales tax Australian manufacturers of software must be disadvantaged compared with their overseas counterparts. I am advised that imported master tapes that are to be used to produce copies for sale or licence are aids to manufacture and exempt from sales tax. Australian produced master tapes that are also to be used to produce copies for sale or licence are also aids to manufacture and therefore exempt from sales tax. Copies made from all master tapes-imported and locally produced-for sale or licence are, subject to the usual exemption, taxable. The price charged for the copies would reflect the cost of producing or acquiring the master tape. There is, therefore, no discriminatory sales tax treatment for Australian producers of software compared with their overseas counterparts.

The final question raised was what goods, other than software associated with copyright, are subject to sales tax. I am informed that where sound recordings or tapes or video cassettes are sold, the value of the copyright material has always been subject to sales tax.

—I repeat that the principle and integrity of the fringe benefits tax are not at issue and never have been. Indeed, I understand that if legislation attempted exhaustively to list the circumstances under which a liability would be triggered, legally it might well be limited to that list. So there is always some scope for interpretation, if you like, and as I understand it the Prime Minister had that in mind yesterday when he made the sort of statement to which Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle referred. But it is a question of there being at the margin some doubts or uncertainty in the minds of a number of people as to whether a particular type of benefit would be taxed and that is, as I understand it, what the Prime Minister intends to clarify.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr President, I have a supplementary question. For clarification, I ask the Minister whether we should anticipate that there will be a list of organisations and situations to which the fringe benefits tax will not be applied.
—Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle or anyone else can anticipate whatever she or he likes, but I am not going to anticipate anything until such time as the review has been completed.

—I ask a question of Senator Walsh as both Minister for Finance and Acting Minister for Resources and Energy. Has the Minister seen the annual report of the Tasmanian Hydro Electric Commission released last week in which it was admitted that the HEC forecast of power demand for 1986 was overstated by 18 per cent and that the growth rate of electricity usage was only about 1.5 per cent rather than the predicted 2.7 per cent? Can the Minister confirm that this Government's payments to Tasmania under the dams compensation package were based on the HEC's predictions of demand? What amount of compensation would have been necessary if the forecast had matched the outcome? Finally, can the lower usage justify the announced massive increase in HEC power charges and the advertising campaign which seems to contradict the concept of energy conservation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the last part of the question, about whether the lower usage of power can justify the massive increase in HEC charges, I think it is difficult to be definitive about that but, of course, the cause of the massive increase in charges is the gross errors in the forecasting of demand which the HEC made and which this Government pointed out to Mr Gray more than three years ago. I was personally involved in a good deal of this; I remember it quite well. This Government disputed the HEC demand forecasts, and Mr Gray stubbornly and stupidly backed the HEC up to the hilt. It has now been proved that the HEC was wrong.

ANSWER.PARA: The compensation-leaving aside the short term compensation which was paid-which the Commonwealth offered was based on the difference between the capital cost of providing 112 megawatts of power through the King and Anthony schemes, as I think the other two schemes were called, or 112 megawatts through the Gordon below Franklin dam. That was actuarially calculated as full compensation, spread out over 10 years, for the difference in that capital cost. As it turns out, with the record of the last three years, the demand forecasts of the Hydro Electric Commission, which were mindlessly accepted by Mr Gray and the Tasmanian Government, were grossly in excess of what actually occurred. Indeed, in 1985-86 the amount of power supplied averaged 950 megawatts, whereas the HEC forecast that by calendar year 1986 1,094 megawatts of energy would be consumed, which I think accounts for the percentage difference or overestimate to which Senator Coates referred. The Department of Resources and Energy in 1981 forecast an average load of 989 megawatts for 1985-86, which was subsequently revised downwards to 976 megawatts. So even the downward revision of the estimate of the Department of Resources and Energy was marginally above the actual consumption for that period, but, of course, it was vastly closer to the actual outcome than the estimate of the HEC. The HEC now concedes that after the 112-megawatt King and Anthony schemes which are now under construction, no additional capacity will be needed until at least the mid-1990s.

So, in short, Tasmania has really been overcompensated by the Commonwealth Government. Notwithstanding the generosity of the fiscal treatment which Tasmania has received from the Commonwealth Government, the people of Tasmania are still faced with a very serious fiscal problem which is directly attributable to the initial errors of the Hydro Electric Commission. But of course the State Government as the government of the State-it is the government of the State, not the Hydro Electric Commission-has to accept the responsibility and ought to be made to accept the responsibility for having mindlessly, stubbornly and stupidly accepted those overestimates and for failing to heed the superior advice which was offered to it by Commonwealth authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security and it relates to the Government's decision to defer consumer price index adjustments to pensions and benefits for six weeks from the 1 November due date. I ask the Minister whether he is aware of and approves of the fact that this measure will cut $53 from the income of single pensioners while pensioner couples will be $80 out of pocket two weeks before Christmas and at a time when 800,000 children are living in families below the poverty line. Furthermore, is he aware that in a recent Australian Council of Social Service survey of 11 pensioner categories all were found to be already several percentage points further below the poverty line than in March 1983, when the Hawke Government took office? Finally, in view of the Government's recent backdown on housing interest rates in the Australian Capital Territory, does the Minister agree that it would be both a matter of fairness and, even at this late stage, a matter of good political sense to reverse the decision delaying indexation increases, thereby taking that additional financial pressure off an already disadvantaged group of people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the fact that Senator Haines and her colleagues do not approve of that particular change made in the Budget. I am aware also that, despite their predictions, that particular change in the Budget has not been greeted with the furore and uproar that Senator Haines and her colleagues had anticipated. The figures that Senator Haines has produced-I do not have them at my fingertips-are in excess of the sorts of figures that I recall. However, I will not even go near misleading the Senate by giving my recollection; I will come back to Senator Haines with the exact details.

ANSWER.PARA: The decision that was made was made in a budgetary context because we believed we had to reduce outlays. Several choices had to be made. Most of them I did not like but they were made in difficult circumstances in an attempt to provide equity across the board. I have not seen the ACOSS surveys that Senator Haines talked about, but as ACOSS is a body which pleads the case of pensioners and other groups that it represents, or claims to represent, I understand that of course it will produce the sorts of figures to which Senator Haines referred. I accept that that is so but the simple fact of the matter is that if Senator Haines wants us to reverse that decision, a decision which would cost, I forget-

TALK.START.PARA: —A little over $100m.

—Just over $100m; Senator Haines may believe that this Cabinet, this Government and this country indeed can afford to take that decision. Alternatively, if she does not believe that, if she believes in the overall Budget parameters, she should suggest to us where else we should get that money from.
—Well, we have.

—I know. The alternative of the Democrats was to blow out the Budget deficit by just over $1,000m. The simple fact of the matter is that it is the easiest thing in the world to come into this place and say that it is perfectly all right to blow out the Budget deficit by $1,000m or $2,000m, or to make statements of that type, in the absolute certainty that they will never be in the position to have to carry out those promises. The decision was made in difficult economic circumstances in a difficult budgetary situation and, in fact, most of the pensioners in this country have accepted that the burden had to be spread across all groups in the community. Senator Haines may not agree with it. I know the Democrats will make a great performance of it next week, the week after, or whenever the legislation comes in, but the simple fact is that most people in this place have to make decisions and support decisions on the grounds that they have to be responsible for the consequences of their actions. That is something the Australian Democrats do not have to do and that is why they ask questions of this type.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Has the Minister seen reports of a speech made by Mr Graham Spurling, Managing Director of Mitsubishi Motors Australia Ltd, to a recent forum on university and business co-operation about the importance of attracting Japanese investment to Australia? If so, does the Minister agree with Mr Spurling that it is Japanese investment in particular which holds significant export advantages for Australia, presumably through a reduction in Japan's huge $US70 billion current account surplus?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen the media reports relating to Mr Spurling's remarks on Japanese investment and I endorse the thrust of what he said. In fact, the Government is actively in pursuit of investment from Japan. There is to be an investment mission next month to Japan in which I will take part. The purpose of that mission is to attract Japanese investment in export-oriented operations in Australia or to develop links between Australia and Japanese companies that can bring spin-offs for Australian companies through technology or access to world markets. The recent sharp fall in Australia's terms of trade has put more urgency into our need to develop closer links with Japan and export strengths in our own manufacturing and services sector.

ANSWER.PARA: Firstly, the Japanese links could provide new opportunities to mesh Australian manufacturing into wider international markets. Secondly, the devaluation of the Australian dollar against the yen by more than 50 per cent in the last 18 months has provided a substantial boost to the competitiveness of Australian manufacturing industry. Thirdly, Australia in recent years has achieved an impressive record of wage moderation and has greatly improved the industrial relations climate. Combined with the depreciation and enhanced taxation and investment incentives, this record makes Australia a much more attractive prospect for world class manufacturing operations.

In the latter part of Senator Maguire's question he asked me about Japanese interest in investment overseas. A study has been done for the Japanese Government-the so-called Mackawa report-which encourages Japanese investment overseas in view of the very strong situation of the yen and the Japanese economy generally. In that sense it is an opportune time for the Government to take an initiative in respect of joint ventures with Japanese companies.

The mission to which I referred will comprise members and associates in seven key sectors, predominantly from the private sector. Those sectors are automotive components; processed food; telecommunications; computer software; processed minerals; biotechnology; and wool processing and wool textiles. I might say that the Government, in establishing this mission, which arose from discussions between Prime Minister Nakasone and Prime Minister Hawke, is not seeking instant successes. It is just another step in the process of upgrading the international links of Australian industry in a medium to long term strategy. It is a mission aimed at attracting worthwhile investment in Australian enterprises to enhance their competitiveness and export potential. I add that it is the intention of the Japanese Government to have a return investment mission to Australia, I think in February next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer by saying that, in reply to a question from Senator Chaney, the Minister mentioned the word `confusion'. I have to say that it appears that many people are confused and concerned over the fringe benefits tax, including government officials. I ask: Does the Minister agree with the concern reportedly expressed by government officials that so-called administrative changes and exemptions will allow a truck to be driven through holes in the fringe benefits legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to set the record straight, I think it should be noted that the confusion to which I referred was the hopeless confusion in the ranks of the Opposition as to how it is going to get itself off this hook on which it has been impaled by the desperation of its temporary leader in struggling to protect his position from the assaults of the ratbag Right. The confusion was demonstrated by the statement on 26 September by Mr Tuckey, a member of the front bench, who confirmed that a coalition government will maintain a fringe benefits tax specifically in relation to cars, housing and education, whereas the temporary Leader of the Opposition has been running around saying that the fringe benefits tax will be repealed lock, stock and barrel. Every time he says that, either one of his own Liberal Party front benchers or one of the National Party leaders promptly contradicts him. In uncharacteristic fashion, they have had periodic outbursts of honesty and have said: `Of course fringe benefits will be taxed but we will tax them in a different way'. That is the confusion to which I referred.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the latter part of Senator Townley's question, I refer him to the answer I gave Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle that I am not going to attempt to prejudge the outcome of the review which the Prime Minister announced yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Community Services aware that many nursing home patients and their families in New South Wales are concerned at their inability to pay recently increased nursing home fees in New South Wales? Has the New South Wales branch of the Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes Association of Australia circularised relatives of nursing home patients on this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, concern has been expressed in New South Wales by patients in nursing homes and their relatives as a result of a circular letter put out by the Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes Association of Australia to patients and relatives in an attempt to influence the Government's decision-making process. I might add that this is not a new phenomenon. Ministers for Social Security and more recently in my time Ministers for Community Services and for Health from all parties have been subjected to this sort of treatment by the Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes Association of Australia. What has happened this year is that in New South Wales recently there were improvements in award wages and conditions provided for nurses, amongst whom are those working in nursing homes, and as a result the Department of Community Services, on looking at the situation, gave permission to the Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes Association of Australia to increase its fees across the board by some $5.10 a day, I think it was, in response to a request from the private nursing homes in New South Wales. Under normal circumstances these organisations would individually apply for increases in fees to the Department, which would look at their costs and give increases to the maximum fee they can charge in the normal process of events. We did this in recognition of the fact that they had increased costs and that we would have to take into account those increased costs. In other words, we are co-opera-ting with the nursing homes.

ANSWER.PARA: Equally, around this time every year Cabinet, of whichever party is in power, considers increases to the nursing home benefit. Normally that nursing home benefit is increased in November. On this occasion the Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes Association of Australia in New South Wales sent out form letters to patients and patients' staff. Three things could be inferred from that letter. First of all it claimed that the increases in costs were the result of actions of the Department of Community Services. That is not true. They were the result of increased costs, which were outside the power of the Department of Community Services, and of applications made to us by this very organisation. Secondly, the letter implied that the Government was not going to increase the nursing home benefit in New South Wales when Cabinet is about to consider those increases now. What I object to, and what previous Ministers of both political persuasions in the past have objected to, is the tactics used by these individuals. What they are doing is trying to frighten and exploit the fears of people in nursing homes and their relatives in order to gain more funds for themselves.

There are three groups of private nursing home proprietors in New South Wales and, indeed, in the whole of Australia. The first group consists of people who run good nursing homes, people who are concerned about the clients and patients for whom they care, who are out to make a living from their nursing homes-and no one can deny them that-but who would not consider exploiting their clients or patients to get such a living. The second group are in it only for the money. They are willing to do anything to gain more funds from the Government. This Government and previous governments have spent $1 billion on nursing homes in the community. The third group owns large numbers of nursing homes and has become extremely wealthy from exploiting the legislation we have in this community to cover nursing home benefits.

This Government is in the process of changing the system of funding nursing homes and it will continue to do so. We are in the process of changing the percentage of people in expensive nursing homes. Some private nursing home proprietors see that as a threat and the sort of action they are indulging in at the moment is part of their reaction to that threat. I, personally, have no time for such individuals nor will I in the future. This Government will not be dissuaded from changing the system of funding nursing homes by the actions of such individuals. I consider them ghouls; I consider them to be merely out to make money at the expense of some elderly, some disadvantaged and some people in the community who do not have as much knowledge as others. Neither I nor the Government will be moved from our changes. I wish that the relatives and the people involved will recognise this campaign for what it is; it is a campaign to get more money out of the public purse in order to line the pockets of people who have done very well in an industry which has the lowest rate of bankruptcies of any industry in this community, despite the fact of its experiencing difficult economic times in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. When did the Government decide to make the review of the fringe benefits tax announced yesterday? Did it result from a Cabinet decision or was it a political knee-jerk reaction of the Prime Minister on the run in Question Time yesterday?
—There was a ministerial meeting prior to yesterday's sitting of the House of Representatives.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education. Has concern been expressed by overseas students now in Australia about present increases in fees charged them and about future increases in those fees and, in particular, about their predictability? Has the Minister sympathy with the students? If so, what expression is she able to give to that sympathy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard expressions of concern from overseas students and their representatives-in fact I had a meeting with them today-and I do have some sympathy with some of the matters they have raised with me. The first thing to be clear about is the extent to which the overseas student charge has been increased. Students who commenced their study in higher education this year, or will commence it next year, will move from paying 35 per cent to 45 per cent of the full average cost of their course next year. That is the rate which will also apply to new students next year. Students who commenced study prior to 1986 will pay a 15 per cent fee increase in 1987 and this will bring the charge for them to an equivalent of 32 per cent of the full average cost. This lower rate for continuing students reflects the Government's concern that students who commence their studies without knowledge of the recent overseas student charge increases should not be deterred from continuing their studies. The Government has made no further decisions about any future increases in the level of the overseas student charge.

ANSWER.PARA: Another claim which is erroneously based is that overseas students will be liable for the higher education administration charge. This is true only in a technical sense. The overseas student charge will be reduced by $250, so in money terms the administration charge does not affect overseas students. Students have raised matters with me such as the possibility of staggering payments of the charge through the academic year instead of paying it on issue of the visa. They have also expressed their desire to have some stability and security with regard to the Government's future intentions with the charge, and I have undertaken to have discussions about both of these matters with the Government and to inform overseas students as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that the Australian Taxation Office is paying $474,000 in fringe benefits tax to itself this financial year? When the Government has professed that it wants employers to cash out employee perks, can the Minister explain why the Taxation Office has made no attempt to comply with the Government's wishes and cash out the benefits of its own staff?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Office has of the order of 16,000 employees; so even a member of the National Party of Australia should be able to work out that the fringe benefits tax liability of the Australian Taxation Office is about $30 per employee. In other words, the Taxation Office has not been rorting the tax system through the calculated conversion of what ought to be taxable as cash income into previously non-taxable and untaxed fringe benefits and perks. Around $30 per employee is the liability of the Australian Taxation Office. It is largely due to the provision of vehicles which are used by a large number of people at various times of the day and therefore it is not suitable for cashing out.

ANSWER.PARA: Those employers who, in collaboration with their employees-let us get this perfectly clear-over a number of years, have been into tax evasion do not deal in amounts of $20 or $30; they deal in amounts of thousands of dollars per employee for benefits which are clearly identifiable as being provided to specific employees. If those employers want to avoid fringe benefits tax liability they can cash out those benefits. By and large it is not a viable proposition for the Australian Public Service to cash out fringe benefits because it has not been into tax evasion in the same way as the people who are presently complaining about the fringe benefits tax and who are cranking up the puppet, who is presently the Leader of the Opposition, promising to repeal it--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the Minister to withdraw that expression.
—Very well, Mr President. I withdraw.

—I ask a supplementary question. Am I to take it from the Minister's answer that everyone in the Taxation Office gets a fringe benefit? Surely not every employee would get a fringe benefit to make sure that every person got $30.
—I think that question is too silly to deserve an answer.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NUCLEAR POWERED OR ARMED VESSELS: VISITS TO AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. It concerns the inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence relating to the accidental release of radiation from visiting nuclear powered or armed vessels in Australian ports and waters. Bearing in mind that between 1971 and 1976 nuclear powered warships were banned from Australian ports at the request of the McMahon Liberal Government, pending an environmental impact study-the results of which are still secret-and also bearing in mind the latest Soviet nuclear naval accident, should not the Government now impose a ban on the visits of nuclear armed and nuclear powered warships until the Senate inquiry is completed, adequate port safety plans to cope with possible accidents have been drawn up and exercises have been conducted in every Australian port likely to be visited by nuclear ships?
—I thought I had a note that covered the question that Senator Vallentine has just asked. If I have, I cannot find it at the moment, so I will refer that question to the Minister for Defence.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment aware that, under the proposal for a new woodchip export scheme based on Tasmania's southern forest concession, 8,400 hectares of rainforest on public land will be clear felled and replaced with eucalyptus, and that old growth forests in the Australian Newsprint Mills Ltd concession will be cut at a faster rate than at present? If so, can she assure the Parliament that an environmental impact statement will be carried out in accordance with the Government's commitment under clause 29 of the memorandum of understanding signed by the Federal and State governments before any woodchip export licence is granted to the consortium?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has been notified by the Tasmanian Minister for Forests, Mr Groom, of the Tasmanian Government's decision to accept a proposal by Huon Forests Products, a consortium led by Australian Newsprint Mills Ltd, for the utilisation of the southern forest resource. Mr Groom informed the Minister for Primary Industry that the project will not result in an increase in the volume of woodchips to be exported from Tasmania, as approved by the Commonwealth in December 1985. However, the Minister has not yet been able to receive full details of the project and an explanation of the way it relates to the management strategy outlined in the Tasmanian environmental impact statement. On receipt of those details an assessment will be made in accordance with clause 29 of the memorandum of understanding to determine the extent to which, if at all, the project differs significantly in environmental impact from that outlined in the environmental impact statement. Should that be the case, the proposal will be referred to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment for consideration under the provisions of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to rainforests, I remind honourable senators that the export of woodchips from pure rainforests, as defined in the memorandum of understanding, on Crown land is prohibited, pending the outcome of a State study and any Commonwealth environmental impact statement which may be necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Education seen a Press report in the Adelaide Advertiser of 3 October in which the State Leader of the Opposition, Mr Olsen, predicted that tertiary students would eventually have to meet the full cost of their studies? Can the Minister advise the Senate whether this will be the case, and do the comments by the South Australian Liberal leader show disagreement with the sentiments expressed by his Party at the National Council meeting earlier this year that a Federal Liberal government would introduce full cost fees for tertiary students? Can the Minister advise the Senate whether the South Australian Government has taken up Mr Olsen's suggestion that it should consider mounting a constitutional challenge against the reintroduction of fees?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not paid close attention to Mr Olsen's comments as reported in the Advertiser, but it is a well known fact, particularly in this place, that the Liberal Party, at its National Council meeting earlier this year, passed a resolution endorsing the imposition of full tertiary fees for tertiary students. Whether or not its National Party colleagues are in agreement with this policy is not a matter known to us. There are so many divisions of policy between the coalition partners and, indeed, amongst Liberal Party members that I suppose it is difficult to be clear on this point. But what is clear is that the Liberal-National parties have a policy of charging full tuition fees. So the only likelihood of Mr Olsen's prediction coming true-that is, of students being charged full tuition fees-is in the event of the very unlikely possibility of the election of a Liberal government.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the suggestion that there should be a constitutional challenge regarding the $250 administration charge, I assure the Senate that there is no substance to the claim that the imposition of this charge is inconsistent with the 1973 Commonwealth-State agreement. The Commonwealth-State agreement of 1973 was to the effect that the Commonwealth would take over full funding of higher education-that is, in universities and colleges of advanced education-on the condition that the institutions would not impose tuition fees. This prohibition to tertiary fees still applies. The section of the States grants Act relating to the prohibition of tuition fees will not be amended. I make it clear that the higher education charge is not a tuition fee. The $250 charge per student is a contribution that students will make to the administration costs incurred by institutions in providing to students services of a non-academic nature. I point out that my Department has received advice from the Attorney-General's Department which is in complete agreement with my position. So there is no basis to that challenge and there is no likelihood of full tuition fees being levied on Australian higher education students-except, as I said, in the very unlikely possibility of the Liberal Party being elected to government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the fact that if brewery workers drink free beer on their employers' premises, no fringe benefits tax is payable. Is the Minister aware that the Swan Brewery Co. Ltd in his State has decided to give a carton of beer to employees each week in an effort to prevent employees driving home after drinking at work? Can the Minister explain why the company's adoption of a socially responsible policy should transform a non-taxable work practice into a taxable fringe benefit?

—I know that many brewery workers have a drink. Some of my colleagues have reminded me that some people who are not brewery workers have been known to have a drink. I do not know what the tax provision was in respect of brewery workers. If Senator Messner wants an answer, I will refer the question to the Treasurer and get one.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation confirm reports that recently two domestic jet aircraft were on a collision course and nearly collided over the Great Australian Bight? Can the Minister inform the Senate what action has been taken by the Government to ensure that there is no repetition of this occurrence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will be aware that the aviation industry in Australia has an excellent air safety record. I think it is accepted that its record has no comparison with that of any other country in the world. It is way out in front in respect of air safety standards. However, despite that, there are from time to time departures from proper standards in respect of the movement of aircraft. One such incident occurred on 28 September, when two Australian Airlines A300 Airbus aircraft passed within approximately one mile of one another while flying at the same altitude over the Great Australian Bight. Considering the speed at which such aircraft fly, that is not a very great safety margin.

ANSWER.PARA: = It appears that one of the aircraft had requested and received permission from air traffic control staff to alter its original track to save fuel. The incident was promptly investigated by the Bureau of Air Safety and Department of Aviation staff. Instructions have now been issued to all air traffic controllers to obviate a repetition of the circumstances which led to the normal standards of separation of aircraft not being fully observed. The Department of Aviation is aware of its responsibilities and will certainly take every available step to make sure that there is no repetition of this incident.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: KAKADU NATIONAL PARK: WORLD HERITAGE LISTING

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment. I refer to the Government's decision to nominate stage 2 of the Kakadu National Park for World Heritage listing. I ask the Minister: Is it correct that Professor Ovington, the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, is to make a submission to the World Heritage Commission in Paris on 20 November 1986? If that is the case, would it not directly conflict with the procedures which were agreed to by the Commonwealth, State and Territory governments at the July 1984 meeting of the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers? That agreement makes it absolutely clear that the Commonwealth will not take unilateral action to nominate areas for World Heritage listing without the agreement of the States or Territories concerned. Finally, given this breach in the agreement, will the Government now reconsider its decision to nominate Kakadu stage 2 for World Heritage listing and consult fully with the Northern Territory Government regarding the nomination before any further decision is taken?

—I do not know of any developments which suggest that the Government will reconsider its decision to nominate Kakadu stage 2 for World Heritage listing. As to the procedures by which this decision was taken and the extent to which there have been discussions with the Northern Territory Government, I will have to take those matters on notice.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Territories. The Minister for Territories announced on Budget night that interest rates on all pre-1983 housing loans in the Australian Capital Territory would be increased to the maximum of 13.5 per cent, consistent with the Government's April 1986 housing package. Considerable public reaction to the announcement followed. On what basis does the Government justify its announcement last night that the Budget decision has been reviewed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Budget night there are scores of items to which changes are made in respect of charges, expenditure and income. From time to time, many of these matters receive some public reaction. Clearly, in the Australian Capital Territory genuine concern was expressed about one of the proposals, which was to increase to the current level of 13.5 per cent, the rate on loans which had been in existence for many years. As a result of representations by Senator Ryan, Mr Langmore and Mrs Kelly, the Government reviewed that decision. That is proper. Perhaps all the factors were not available at the time the Expenditure Review Committee was examining savings under its commitment to reduce the Budget deficit. The Government has seen fit to make some changes and to accommodate public reaction.

ANSWER.PARA: The decision not to proceed was taken because of the legal complexities involved combined with the view that the Government's adherence to the principle of not breaching contract obligations should outweigh the principle of minimising government assistance to those no longer in need. In my view the Government responded correctly to the representations that were made. The decision applies to all loans as a technical difficulty in an ordinance prevents increases in loans with variable interest rates. In response to Senator Giles, the Government has taken into account all of the difficulties that existed in this matter and has adhered to the old system rather than implementing the decision made on Budget night.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Community Services follows the question asked earlier today by one of his colleagues. I remind the Minister that in answer to Senator Childs he concentrated in rather unflattering terms on the revenue of nursing home proprietors while acknowledging that a series of recent awards and determinations in New South Wales had led to his Department approving extra fees of $35 weekly for 20,000 nursing home patients to cover the extra costs. Is it correct that, for these people, their pension and subsidies now fall short of charges approved by government by very large amounts, even up to $200 per week? Since many of these people have no extra sources of income and since their plight results, at least in part, from combinations of government freezes on benefits, extra costs of awards and so on and delays in pension upgrading, what action does the Minister or the Government intend to take to relieve the plight of nursing home patients? Will the Minister acknowledge the plight and helplessness in which many patients find themselves today and put this matter before his colleagues in any submission he makes to Cabinet?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 8 October, from Senator Chaney:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
