SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The inadequacy of the Prime Minister's undertaking to make administrative changes to the fringe benefits tax and the need for its repeal lock, stock and barrel.

The need for this urgency motion has been borne out by the questions asked in Question Time today and the failure of the Government to respond to them. It was quite clear from the answers given today by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, that he is unable to give the Senate quite basic information about the present state of the fringe benefits tax and what state it will be in on 28 October. We are presently 20 days away from the first payment which is required to be made under the Government's legislation and the Minister and the Government cannot tell us what the rules will be on that date for first payment. The best that Senator Walsh seemed to be able to do today was tell the Senate what the next government of Australia, the Liberal-National party government, would do. He made a few fanciful suggestions in that regard but the fact is that he was unable to tell us what his own Government proposes and on what basis people should be submitting their returns for this onerous new tax.

When this Government is defeated at the next election, as it inevitably will be, it will not be defeated so much because of the specifics of the fringe benefits tax but because of the contemptuous way that it has treated the people of Australia in so many areas, not least with respect to this tax. The sad reality is that this Government has treated with scorn and contempt anybody who has brought forward a concern about this tax and it has done that with gay abandon, whether the people coming forward be from the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party or the National Party of Australia, whether they are aged or infirm, whether they work for non-profit charitable organisations, and whether they are farmers or small businessmen. It does not matter who it is; this Government treats them with contempt. It was only yesterday that we saw some wavering by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the teeth of his obvious unpopularity on this issue. To this point-and we saw a repeat of it in the Senate today from Senator Walsh-we have had nothing but an abusive rejection of the very real practical difficulties which arise from this taxation measure. We can only hope that Senator Walsh is not in charge of the re-examination of the fringe benefits tax, because if he is I suspect it will be made more onerous over the next 20 days. So the people of Australia had better not wait with any great sense of hope about what the Government is doing. Again in his answers today he demonstrated his personal lack of concern for the problems of both substance and administration. He again demonstrated his contempt for the worries of the people of Australia, including those in the Opposition, small business, the residents of remote areas of Australia, those who work for non-profit organisations and so on.

We bring forward this motion in an atmosphere of complete confusion about where the Government is going on this tax. Only yesterday in the Senate, when the issue was raised by the Opposition, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, painfully tried to separate the issue of administration and the issue of the principle of the tax. It is quite clear from what occurred in the other place at the same time that the Prime Minister drew no such distinction, because whilst in an answer to a question in the other place the Acting Treasurer, Mr Hurford, made the statement that there were no announcements to be made about administrative changes, and that the Government would not be withdrawing or resiling one iota from the principles of the tax, it was very clear that the Prime Minister immediately afterwards was acknowledging that the tax has an ambit which goes beyond what he is prepared to defend in the Parliament.

The Prime Minister brought a new phrase into the discussion; he started talking about the unintended consequences of the legislation and about the fact that people were being caught who it was not expected or intended should be caught, and that this matter would be examined by the Government. I say quite simply to the Government that that is not a matter of administration; it is a matter of the scope of this tax and it is quite clear from the answers given yesterday in the House of Representatives that the Government is now raising doubts about the intended scope of this tax and what application it is to have in the future. This matter has been raised continuously this year. It was raised in the debate on the relevant legislation both in this place and in the House of Representatives, and all of these unintended consequences are matters which have been given a clear public airing.

I suppose the failure of the Government to act until today was explained by Senator Richardson on the radio this morning when he said that governments are never really keen to admit even the possibility of an error. Of course that is what the Prime Minister did yesterday. We are yet to have an admission from the Minister at the table, the Minister for Finance, although I hope we might get something a little more gracious by way of admission of error in his contribution to the debate a little later. But let me say that it is good that some part of the Government has admitted error, albeit rather late.

We have also heard continuously from Senator Walsh an attempt to throw the whole thing back on to the Opposition. I simply make the point that it is the Government which is governing this country. It might have only another year or so to do that-indeed it is quite clear that it has no more than a year or so-but for it to be claiming that the focus of attention at the moment should be on the policies of the Opposition when it made no announcement on the fringe benefits tax before the last election, had no tax policy before the last election and had nothing to guide the people of Australia, is nothing but a subterfuge and an attempt to escape the responsibilities of government. What John Howard has said about the fringe benefits tax has been said clearly and continuously since early this year. He made the point then that we would repeal the tax which was introduced by this Government, and as far as the question of abuses is concerned, the matters which Senator Walsh chooses to focus on, he said that any abuses in the tax area amounting to tax avoidance would not be permitted by a future coalition government. The detail of the way we will deal with that is a matter that we will put in our tax policy. Unlike the present Government we will not leave the people of Australia in the dark until after we have been elected to government. We will take them into our confidence, but we do not believe that that obligation is on us now.

It is quite clear, as we were told in Question Time today, that at a meeting of Ministers before Question Time, clearly without consultation with officials, the Government made a decision to review the fringe benefits tax. There is clearly no knowledge within the Administration of how that is going to be undertaken. The Minister has been unable to tell us the principles which will be followed. We have no idea what the outcome will be and we have no idea of what the limits of the review will be. We have nothing but confusion. When we invited the Minister to give the taxpayers and the people of Australia some guidance today in Question Time he was unable to do so.

This is the fourth time the Opposition has raised this matter by way of an urgency debate this year. We raised it first on 9 April, when we sought the abandonment of the fringe benefits tax because of its threats to jobs in the car industry and in other industries. On 30 April we put forward a modified proposal, again in the interests of protecting employment, to obtain the support of the Australian Democrats for at least some modification of the fringe benefits tax. A motion was carried by this Senate and again, of course, it was ignored by the Government. On 20 August this year in the Senate we sought the repeal and the abandonment of the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax. Again, the combined weight of numbers from the Government, with its supporters in the Australian Democrats, prevented the carriage of that motion.

Those motions and the debates have been brought forward time and again by the Opposition, just as we brought forward these critical issues in the debate on the legislation itself. The Government has chosen to ignore it and substantially the Australian Democrats have chosen to support the Government in its promotion of this tax. Jobs are being lost in the automotive industry, in the mines which have been closed, in small businesses and of course we have the tremendous concern of so many people not just about the administrative complexity but about the extraordinarily wide impact of this tax.

The Opposition has clearly drawn the attention of the Government to the wider community application of this legislation and to the sorts of tax rorts which the Government tries to focus on in its debate. That is all we ever hear from Senator Walsh. I draw his attention to the debate in the Senate on the Bill itself, to the amendments moved by Senator Peter Baume in particular which sought to exempt some of those non-business activities which occur in Australia and which will be taxed, and to the opposition which he and his colleagues gave to those exemptions being made. That is important to note because it is as a result of this Government's resistance to the facts which were put before it that the tax is now being applied to such non-profit organisations as the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, the sporting clubs, the National Trust, the schools which are run by so many voluntary organisations and non-profit organisations, and so on. There are cases of extraordinary personal hardship which this tax imposes. That issue was put before the Prime Minister in a question yesterday and he had the gall to suggest that it was a matter which had come to his attention only over the previous days. What Mrs Sullivan, ex-Senator Martin from this place, drew to the Prime Minister's attention in the House of Representatives yesterday was that even quadriplegics and others suffering the after-effects of strokes, as well as people who are too old to look after themselves, and who have people living in with them to prevent their being institutionalised, would be forced to pay a tax to the Commonwealth because of those arrangements. The Prime Minister's reply is one which is fascinating but which simply cannot be believed. He said that these were matters which had been brought to his attention in the last few days. He went on to say that these were not the sorts of situations that the fringe benefits tax was intended to encompass.

I am sure that you, Madam Acting Deputy President, and every other senator in this place, know of examples of that sort and have known about them for months. I would be very surprised if you yourself had not drawn these matters to the attention of your colleagues and sought their guidance on what might be done about it. There was at least one very notorious case that received a great deal of publicity in our State of Western Australia. I draw attention to the case of pensioner Margaret Plozza, a woman of 78 years of age who is crippled but determined to keep herself out of an institution. She has somebody living in who is receiving some payment and also receiving bed and meals as part of the deal for looking after Mrs Plozza and preventing her from being institutionalised.

We heard the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) saying today that the Government was deeply concerned about the cost of institutions and the cost of nursing homes and anxious to prevent people from having to enter nursing homes. Yet when Mrs Plozza's case was taken up by an ex-service organisation and guidance was sought, the advice-this was widely publicised in the media in Western Australia-was that she would have to pay the tax because it was an employer-employee relationship and a fringe benefit was being supplied. This woman of 78 years of age is trying to keep herself out of an institution by having somebody live in for a reward. The value of that person's bed and meals is the subject of a taxation assessment which Mrs Plozza will have to pay. That is an example which came forward in September, and the Prime Minister tells us that this is news which has come to him over recent days.

I refer to the correspondence which so many of us have had with senior Ministers in this Government about these sorts of issues. I quote from the correspondence that was produced in the House of Representatives yesterday by Mr Peter Coleman, who wrote to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 5 June this year on behalf of a quadriplegic who needed frequent assistance and who had a live-in being paid a post-tax wage of $140 a week and who was provided with a rent-free room and two free meals each day. That specific example was just one of many drawn to the attention of the Government. Yet in those circumstances we find the Prime Minister saying that all this has emerged only in the last few days and that these matters were not meant to be caught by the tax. The response, which is instructive, received from the Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Hurford) and addressed to Mr Peter Coleman, stated in part:

The Government received a number of representations seeking exemption from the tax. However, after very carefully considering them, it decided that for reasons of equity it would not widen the field of exemption beyond that announced on 19 September 1985 for religious institutions. Even that single exemption was very tightly drafted in the Bill introduced into the Parliament.

I have put some of the very limited time I have to debate this motion into the question of how individuals are being affected by the fringe benefits tax. The whole tenor of the endless debates we have had in this place has been for the Government simply to talk about this being a matter of tax rorts when in fact there is a whole range of Australians who are in the Mrs Plozza category, in the category of the quadriplegic whose case was taken up by Mr Coleman, in the category of the RSPCA whose concerns have been raised in the Parliament, in the category of the schools whose concerns have been raised in the Parliament, and who are not engaged in any form of tax rort but who are being subjected to highly punitive new taxation by this Government.

The concern of this Opposition is that we have a tax the scope of which is absolutely absurd. We believe that it is not a reparable situation. To suggest that in some way this tax is principled is to turn the word principled upon its head. This tax represents a gutless government's attempt to escape the odium of collecting fringe benefits tax in any other way than lumbering it on to employers and organisations which it thought would not have the electoral clout to resist a new and punishing degree of taxation. The fact that there are problems with this tax has been raised loudly and by many. It has been raised by us in Parliament; it has been raised outside the Parliament by many people, including the Leader of the Government in the Senate. When we get the Minister for Finance standing up in five minutes time and in his usual abusive way claiming that anyone who objects to the fringe benefits tax is in some way engaging in tax rorts, I will remind him that Senator Button, who bustled from this place a few minutes ago, himself described the paper work and the technicalities as being beyond him and as being horrifying. We have a series of Labor leaders who have used words which I would not be prepared to use in this place in describing this tax. Yet, in five minutes time we will have Senator Walsh telling us that the only reason to object to this tax is if one is trying to protect people who are up to tax rorts. There is nothing more absurd than the way this debate has been conducted in the Senate, and there is no person who has been more absurd in his contribution than Senator Walsh. In finalising my comments on why I believe that this Government is in low odour because of its abusiveness, I remind the Senate of the fact that when Labor Premier Burke of Western Australia raised objections to the tax, Senator Walsh said:
However, annoying though it may be that some members of the Western Australian Government are suckers for sob stories from habitual tax evaders who want to continue their tax evading habits . . .

I quote that merely to show the tone of the debate in this place about the fringe benefits tax. We object to the tax both in principle and because of the clumsiness and weight of its administration. The reasons in principle were outlined by John Howard again yesterday. He referred to the unbelievable complexity of the legislation and to the fact that there are 139 pages of legislation, 35 pages of definition in the legislation, 176 pages of explanatory memorandums, two booklets of 69 pages, 14 rulings of 115 pages and so on. In the context of the Government's commitment to simplify the tax system this tax is an absurdity.

Another thing that is wrong with the tax is that it involves the principle of obliging people to bear the tax obligations of others. That clearly makes it wrong. It is clearly a tax which discriminates against the remote areas of Australia. Senator Walsh and the Government should be prepared to admit that the considerations which apply to the remote areas of Australia, including the remote areas of Senator Walsh's home State of Western Australia, produce provisions for employees which can in no way be regarded as tax rorts or tax minimisation arrangements.

Finally, the objection in principle that we have to this tax is that it is a clear and obvious fetter on the productive sectors of the community when we should be encouraging economic growth. This tax, in the words of so many people who are in government, both from the Labor and Liberal side and people who are in administration and business, is cumbersome in its administration. It is inducing a contempt for the law. It is a bad tax because it is so administratively complex. On administrative grounds alone it should be repealed. In our view this is not the time to be tinkering at the edges. This is the time to be throwing out this tax-lock, stock and barrel.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point has been made that on a technicality Opposition members have been able to escape repudiating their own Leader by voting for an amendment which would have become the motion and which they all know is true. They all know that John Howard said in 1980 that it is absolutely unfair, unconscionable and intolerable that a minority of Australians should be able to avoid taxation by taking some of their income in cash and some in kind, thereby forcing all other Australians to pay more tax than they would otherwise have to pay.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion moved by Senator Chaney says essentially that yesterday's statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is inadequate. The only undertaking that would satisfy the ratbag Right and its captives in the Parliamentary Liberal Party is one which would open up the tax system to massive rorting of the type which ran wild when John Howard was Treasurer of Australia. One of the leaders of the ratbag Right, or New Right-I refer to Mr Hay-delivered his ultimatum in the first week in August. In response to questions asking whether he or his organisation was asking that the fringe benefits tax be modified, amended or improved administratively in some way or another, he said: `We want it abolished. We will settle for nothing less'. I note that the same gentleman now wants the Department of Communications abolished. I am not sure whether he wants to replace it with a department of propaganda and public enlightenment.

In 1980 Mr Howard laid the principle on the line when he said that it is unconscionable that some Australians should have to pay more tax than they would otherwise have to pay because other Australians escape tax through the device of taking some of their income in cash and some in kind. What Mr Howard said when he was door-stopped yesterday was the absolute reverse. He said that the principle of taxing fringe benefits is wrong. He has succumbed to the ultimatum issued by the New Right in the first week in August. Only last week Mr Powell, the executive director, I think his title is, of the Australian Chamber of Manufactures-not the secretary of some trade union which is seen as being extremist or left wing, or even a member of the Australian Labor Party, but the executive director of the Chamber of Manufactures-described the New Right as having fascist tendencies. Of course, he is absolutely right. It does have fascist tendencies. The theme which the New Right has been playing up and down Australia for the last six or nine months is that the parliamentary system and the parliamentary parties have failed. The theme is that the parliamentary system has failed Australia and that issues have to be settled by protests and demonstrations. That is undoubtedly a fascist approach to the resolution of political problems and political conflict, and I entirely endorse Mr Powell's comments.

Senator Chaney repeated something, which I must say is becoming tiresome, from the group which has succumbed to the ultimatum of the New Right and which, because it has succumbed to that ultimatum, seeks to perpetuate abuses of the taxation law. He referred to the alleged effects on the motor vehicle industry. The alleged effects on the motor vehicle industry are grossly exaggerated, but I will overlook that for the time being.

Let us delve a bit deeper into this question. If motor vehicle sales were to be lower because the provision of a motor vehicle was no longer a mechanism for evading income tax it would mean that significant numbers of motor vehicles have been sold even though there was no functional, economic need for them. They would have been sold not because there was a functional, economic need for them but because their provision was a mechanism for evading taxation. Taking the assumptions of the critics of the tax at their face value, because of that Australia's scarce capital would have been misdirected away from productive investment, which would have led to self-sustaining, economic growth, into tax havens which just fostered unnecessary consumption. To the extent that their argument is valid, it is a powerful argument, on the grounds of economic efficiency, resource allocation and investment allocation, for doing precisely what this Government is doing. (Quorum formed) To the extent that that argument is true and that the taxing of perks has led to a decline in motor vehicle sales, what is really being said is that, because of the existence of a tax loophole and a tax haven, motor vehicle sales were being maintained at a level above that for which there was any functional, economic need. In other words, scarce capital investment was being misdirected into areas where there was no economic purpose in the investment other than tax evasion. Of course, that is one of the things that have been wrong with this country for a very long time.

Under a succession of irresponsible coalition governments the fundamentals of the Australian economy have been allowed to drift, and drift into trouble. The last Liberal Government was elected with an unemployment level of around 160,000, inflation in double figures and growth at a very low level. It was in office for seven years and when it left office unemployment was around 650,000, growth was negative and inflation was still at 10 per cent. In the meantime, the structure of the Australian economy had deteriorated very significantly because of the sorts of investment policies which the then Government followed and because, as a substitute for having any effective wages policy, it deliberately maintained an overvalued Australian dollar.

This Government had turned the economy around from that trough into which John Howard, as Treasurer, had taken it. In the last 12 months or so we have had a massive turn-around in the terms of trade which has given us severe problems with our external account. The Opposition's answer to that problem is to bring back the free boozy lunch, to pay pensions to millionaires and to continue to provide tax free perks. That is the Opposition's answer to the economic problems which now confront Australia because of a combination of decades of coalition Government neglect and a recent very sharp and adverse deterioration in our terms of trade.

The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) is clinging precariously by his fingernails to the leadership of the Opposition. Of course, it is a matter of common knowledge that the plots are again being hatched in the parliamentary Liberal Party for a challenge and a replacement for Mr Howard before the end of the 1986 calendar year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.

And so he went on. Then the interviewer, George Negus, asked:
What kind of action?
Mr Carlton said:
We'll indicate that when we publish our tax policy.
Mr Negus asked:
Will it be a tax?
Mr Carlton replied:
And we'll say exactly what it is then George.
Mr Negus asked:
Will it be a tax?
Mr Carlton said:
I'm not prepared to go into it any more at this stage.
As if that was not sufficiently obfuscatory, later in the interview Mr Negus said:
I'll try once more-under a Howard-led National/Liberal Party federal government in Australia at whatever time would there be a tax on fringe benefits?

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on!

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I rise to support the Opposition's matter of urgency which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The inadequacy of the Prime Minister's undertaking to make administrative changes to the fringe benefits tax and the need for its repeal lock stock and barrel.

I recall my words when the fringe benefits tax legislation was introduced into the Senate in May this year. At that time I said that the history of tax legislation was a fascinating study in how governments could operate at their inefficient worst. Four months on that situation has not changed for the better. In fact if it is possible it has become even more of a nightmare. People expect governments to govern and the tax reform package of which the FBT was a part took years of expensive contemplation and negotiation. It culminated in the National Taxation Summit supposedly involving the Government's best experts. Admittedly, the tax summit started as an on-the-run policy, a decision of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who, at the time, neglected to tell the Treasurer (Mr Keating) what he was doing. Obviously things do not change with the times. Nevertheless the tax package was sold to the Australian community as a definite revamp of the taxation system.

The Opposition agreed that the tax system in Australia was long overdue for reform, and it still believes this. However, when the Government determines one policy one week and changes its mind about it the next, one cannot blame the Opposition and the community at large for becoming cynical and jaundiced about the whole thing. How does the Government justify this change of heart? It pretends that it was not aware of the anomalies it has just discovered might exist in the application of the fringe benefits tax. The Government cannot possibly claim, as the Prime Minister tried yesterday in the other place, that it was unaware that the fringe benefits tax would hit innocent, unintended victims. The Opposition has brought this matter to the attention of the Parliament, the Government and the people time and again. As Senator Chaney said, the Opposition brought it to the attention of the Parliament some four times. The Prime Minister and the clock collector would have had to do nothing but read the Hansards when the legislation was being debated both in the Senate and in the other chamber to know the flaws in the legislation and the Opposition's total rejection of it.

The Government was warned that charities such as the National Trust of Australia would be adversely affected. The Government was warned that organisations such as the Royal Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals would be liable to pay fringe benefits tax. The Government was warned that safety awards given to employees to encourage safety in the work place would be taxed; that presbyteries and manses would be deemed fringe benefits and taxed; that sporting clubs would be liable for the fringe benefits tax on non-cash prizes; that schools would be liable for the fringe benefits tax on housing for residential staff; that Defence Force personnel would be unfairly hit. The list could go on, as did the debate.

Opposition speaker after Opposition speaker, both here and in the other place, tried to tell this Government what a mess it was creating. I could cite statistic after statistic detailing the people who are being affected, but it seems that this Government does not give a damn about them. It knows who will be hit and it has done nothing about it. The Government was aware of specific cases of elderly, crippled, house-bound invalids who had live-in help for whom they were now liable to pay tax. It knew about them and other similar cases where live-in help was required. What was its answer? I quote from a letter from the Minister Assisting the Treasurer, Chris Hurford:
. . . The Government had received a number of representations seeking exemption from the tax, but for reasons of equity, would not widen the field of exemption beyond that for religious institutions.

That is how much the Government really cares about who it hurts and how it hurts. Are the crippled, housebound elderly the tax rorters that the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, keeps telling us about? What about remote area workers such as miners and farmers, whose children might get sick suddenly? If the company doctor treats the child, that service becomes a fringe benefit. Is that a rort or a rip-off? If it is not, why is it deemed to be a fringe benefit? What about employers who send their staff home by taxi if they work late at night? They are liable for the fringe benefits tax. What about the farmer in northern New South Wales who lives 40 miles out of town? He has a cottage in which a pensioner lives rent free. By any standards the cottage is uninhabitable-any standards, that is, except those of the Australian Taxation Office, which has recently determined that the farmer who owns the cottage is liable to pay fringe benefits tax.

Are these the fat, cigar smoking tax rorters who sit in their gold-plated offices for whom this Government would have us believe the fringe benefits tax was designed? If the Government has been unable or unwilling to see the true effects of FBT, one wonders why it bothered to retain so many experts, both on its personal staff and in its departments, to look at the anomalies such as those I have just mentioned.

The Opposition tried to tell the Government what damage it would do to business. It tried to explain that the administration of the fringe benefits tax on cars would be horrendous; that people would spend innumerable hours trying to calculate their business and private expenses. We now have a tax that applies to cars used for business purposes. We were told that the tax on company cars was to stop the rip-off of the tax system. Has the Government considered how motor dealers will afford to pay the fringe benefits tax on cars that are taken home by their staff? One small motor dealer near my home town employs one salesman. For the past two years, with the rural slump, the yard has made no profit, but because this salesman takes home a car the motor dealer will be liable for about $1,200 a year in additional tax. That dealer has only one salesman and he does not sell expensive cars-the type that the Treasurer has recently bought.

Let us consider this example: A businessman travels overseas on business. He gets his wife to drive him to the airport in the car provided by the company. She then returns home and the car sits in the garage until he returns. That becomes a fringe benefit. But if the same businessman drives his car to work, parks it in the company car park and catches a taxi to the airport, his employer is not liable for the tax on the car because it is sitting in the car park and not in the employee's garage. That is how petty this legislation is, and that is why only its total abolition will suffice.

People in industry and taxation accountants have tried, as we all have, to tell the Government about the problems. But still Government members do not listen-no, not them. Why should they? They believe their own hype machine that the Prime Minister is `charisma plus'. Old `Silver'! They believe that Australia has the world's so-called best Treasurer--

TALK.START.PARA: —Heigh ho Silver!

—Heigh ho! He is riding the rest of us into the ground. The Opposition was told we were creating unnecessary fear and panic in the community when we raised this issue previously; that the fringe benefits tax was not difficult to calculate and only tax rorters would be affected; that by protesting against the fringe benefits tax we were protecting tax cheats and frauds. The problem for the Government is that it could not really decide what it wanted in regard to the fringe benefits tax. Did it want to raise more money? Was it trying to make a serious attempt at revenue redistribution? Did it believe that massive tax evasion and rorts had been taking place? That would seem to be one of the fundamental dilemmas for the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems that the Government could not, and still cannot, decide what the fringe benefits tax will do for the community. For example, during the fringe benefits tax debate which took place in this chamber in June, a Government senator told us that the tax was an attempt to redistribute the tax burden among those people who have to pay tax. The original estimates in regard to the FBT were that it would raise $320m in 1986-87. But as recently as this morning, on an Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio program, we heard Senator Richardson claim that the fringe benefits tax would raise $700m, the implication being that that made it a good thing. It is a pity that the rest of his Party cannot see things as clearly as he obviously does. For example, we all heard Senator Button's honest confession last week that the administration of FBT was horrifying. On Monday the Deputy Leader of the Labor Party in Queensland, Tom Burns, called it `sheer stupidity' and `administrative bull' expletive deleted. The Victorian Premier, John Cain, said in August that there were some difficulties with the administration of the tax. In August New South Wales Premier Unsworth called it an `administrative nightmare'. It is strange that he is able to see the problems in the legislation but that his Federal colleagues cannot.

What must the community do in the meantime while the economic gurus in the Government decide how to fix up the mess they have created for themselves, administratively and electorally? How grateful the rest of Australia must be to the Queensland Government for calling an election. I for one do not believe that this Government would have said a thing about reviewing the tax if it did not see the prospect of defeat at the ballot box. After all, the Government is counting on another 18 months to be able to convince the public how good the tax is. The Government foolishly believes that the bitterness and anger caused by the fringe benefits tax will fade in time. But, of course, in Queensland it does not have 18 months, so it has had to promise something now.

The Prime Minister and his Ministers in this chamber can carry on as much as they like about not knowing about the anomalies that the tax would create, but the Opposition knows, and the people in the community know, that the Government has been aware of them all along. Not one person in the community who is affected by the fringe benefits tax has not written or is not writing to the Government or the media to tell them about it. The Prime Minister and his Government are starting to panic. Members of the public no longer look to the Prime Minister as their hero. They do not believe in him, and they do not believe in his Government either. Who can blame them?

On the same day that the Government admitted that there may be some problems with the fringe benefits tax, that it is an administrative nightmare, other Ministers warned farmers that they will be liable for gaol sentences if they do not pay up. For weeks we on this side of the chamber have been attempting to get answers from the Government about how people are to calculate the tax. During the last sitting week I asked the Minister for Finance how people should calculate and record car usage. His answers conflicted with the statements of both the Treasurer and the Treasury. Confusion abounds everywhere. Only last Friday Treasurer Keating wrote to members of Caucus telling them to get out and defend the fringe benefits tax because he was frightened that the Opposition has some dastardly plan in store. One has to feel sorry for the clock collector. It seems that, every time he goes overseas to try to shore up confidence in the Australian economy, his Prime Minister decides to try his hand at Treasury matters.

What did Treasurer Keating say in August about the proposed change of plans? He said: `It's a furphy, a total furphy. The Government is not going to change this tax. We didn't fight for this thing to see it squandered by some pressure group getting in touch with the Labor Leader's office'. A few days later he said: `There are not going to be any administrative changes'. That was in August. But how times have changed.

Let me mention a few things about the Australian Democrats. They must be in a bit of a dizzy turn, too, at the moment. At last they have come up against another party that changes its mind on policy more often than they do. Where were the Democrats when the elderly cripples sought exemption from the fringe benefits tax? Where were the Democrats when the Opposition was telling the Government about another anomaly concerning the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals?

Where was the rural expert, Senator Macklin, when the Opposition was trying to tell the Government about the anomalies affecting primary industry-the cost of rental accommodation for workers and the cost of meat, fuel and elec- tricity? Where was the economic expert, Senator Siddons, when complaints about the fringe benefits tax on cars and business were raised? It was Senator Siddons who claimed that it was the Democrats who worked out this supposedly very simple formula that we are currently stuck with. Perhaps all the employers and employees in the community who may be listening to this debate today and who are as confused about log book keeping as the Treasurer is would like to contact Senator Siddons and have it all explained to them. There is no doubt that the motion moved by Senator Chaney today is the correct one. It refers to:
The inadequacy of the Prime Minister's undertaking to make administrative changes to the fringe benefits tax and the need for its repeal lock stock and barrel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This urgency motion moved today by Senator Chaney on the question of fringe benefits tax is really part of a plan by the Opposition to destroy or to sabotage the income tax cuts that are to start on 1 December for the great majority of pay as you earn taxpayers. The fringe benefits tax is part of this Government's strategy to crack down on tax avoidance in the Australian community, and the revenue from the tax will be earmarked for those very significant personal income tax cuts that are to begin on 1 December 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: Members of the Liberal Party, in dealing with taxation, want a return to the past. They want a return to the golden age of tax avoidance in Australia when taxation was regarded as being voluntary for the wealthy. Every time we on this side of the Senate try to hit tax avoidance in the community, members of the Liberal Party and the National Party try to block us. On every occasion the Opposition has opposed the key elements of the Government's taxation package. It has opposed the fringe benefits tax, it has opposed the disallowance of entertainment expenses and it has opposed the introduction of the capital gains tax. Those measures were and are key elements in financing the Governments overall taxation reform package. That package redistributes the tax burden; it does not increase it. The extra revenues received in the form of the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax and from the disallowance of entertainment expenses are to be paid out as income tax cuts to many thousands of Australian pay as you earn taxpayers on 1 December this year. On every occasion the Opposition has taken the opport- unity to oppose the revenue measures in this Government's taxation package. It has opposed the fringe benefits tax which, as I have pointed out, is integral to the financing of the personal income tax reductions. Members of the Liberal Party and the National Party want to preserve the tax privileges for the few but deny significant personal income tax cuts to the many. That is what it is all about.

The fringe benefits tax is a key element in financing the package, as I have already pointed out. In the current financial year $325m will be collected by the fringe benefits tax to help finance the personal income tax reductions. A further $575m will be collected next financial year-1986-87-to help finance personal income tax reductions in the community. They are very large sums indeed. When added to the $330m accruing to the Government next financial year as a result of disallowing the free or tax subsidised lunch, they amount to very significant sums and major contributors to the Government's tax cuts. Of course, clearly there could be no significant personal income tax cuts in the community if, as Mr Howard wanted, the fringe benefits tax were thrown out lock, stock and barrel. It just would not be possible to get the revenue to finance those income tax reductions if a major source of revenue such as the fringe benefits tax-$575m next year-were to be thrown out lock, stock and barrel. The fact is, as I pointed out, that the Opposition is trying to sabotage the personal income tax reductions for Australian taxpayers later this year.

Let me get the fringe benefits tax debate into some perspective. There has not been very much perspective this afternoon from Opposition spokespersons. For example, only 11 per cent of taxpayers will be affected by it. I am not talking about 91 per cent, 81 per cent or 71 per cent. The fact is that only 11 per cent of taxpayers will be affected by it and they will be the people who will be paying higher levels of tax to help finance personal income tax reductions for others. The tax on fringe benefits is an equitable and fair tax. It will help restore the ability to pay principle to the Australian taxation system. Previously, persons receiving all of their remuneration in the form of wages and salaries paid tax on the whole of their income, whereas persons receiving substantial fringe benefits within their total remuneration package paid taxation on only the cash element of their remuneration. So, a very inequitable situation existed before the advent of this tax in Australia. Two persons with the same total remuneration were paying vastly different amounts of taxation under the system the Liberal Party and the National Party want to perpetuate in Australia.

Under the Fraser-Howard Government there was a proliferation of fringe benefit payments in a very short period. The very rapid growth in the number of payments and the number of persons receiving them clearly had very little to do with economic change in the Australian community; rather, the sheer rapidity of the growth of fringe benefits can be demonstrated to have been a tax avoidance mechanism. Various items were paid for by employers. Private school fees for children were being paid by employers. We had employer provided travel and holidays and employer provided contributions towards medical fees. We had the so-called company car. What a misnomer that is. Vehicles were made available for the private use of employees, but meanwhile taxpayers in general had to allow a company tax deduction for the purchase of those motor vehicles. They were actually subsidised by the taxpayer through the company tax system as tax deductions but provided for private use by employees. What a misnomer that is.

We had the growth of companies known as remuneration consultants in the larger capital cities under the Liberal Party Government. These grew up very rapidly. I must say that I found very little social benefit stemming from their activities because what they were aiming to do was to find ways around the income tax laws, to devise remuneration packages outside the income tax system. That was their rationale. They aimed to beat the publicly made laws of this country and to develop non-taxed forms of remuneration. The result was rather startling. There are examples available to this Government which show that up to 40 per cent of the total remuneration for some top executives in business came in non-cash form, that is, in a non-taxed form. When 40 per cent of a total remuneration package is being paid in this way, I think it is very clear that the term `fringe benefit' is a misnomer. When 40 per cent of total remuneration is in that form it is hardly a fringe benefit. Members of the Liberal Party perpetuated a system under which that type of person received 40 per cent of his remuneration in a non-tax form and paid income tax on only 60 per cent of the total, whereas somebody receiving the equivalent total remuneration in the form of wages and salaries paid tax on 100 per cent of his income. That really conflicts with the principle of horizontal equity which, broadly stated, suggests that persons in similar economic circumstances should be paying similar amounts of taxation. Those cases clearly do not conform with the principle of horizontal equity.

I recall hearing in this chamber earlier this year Senator Chaney trying to lecture Government members on the horizontal equity principle. I think he was talking about family allowances or the dependent spouse rebate. He suggested that the horizontal equity principle was very important in the taxation area but clearly he chooses to adhere to that principle only when it suits him. He certainly does not adhere to the principle of horizontal equity when discussing the taxation of persons who receive their remuneration in the form of salaries compared with the taxation of persons who receive their remuneration in a non-cash form. That is the great inconsistency in Senator Chaney's position.

Let us keep this debate on the question of the fringe benefits tax in perspective and look at what has been going on in the Australian community in terms of the payment of these benefits. An Australian Bureau of Statistics employment benefits survey reveals what has been happening in the Australian community. For example, in just one 12-month period there was an 18.1 per cent increase in the number of Australians receiving entertainment allowances and an 11 per cent increase in the number of Australians having their medical insurance contributions paid by their employers. The Australian economy did not change by 11 per cent in one year and it certainly did not change by 18 per cent in one year. Clearly those increased payments were a form of tax avoidance. The other thing which must be kept in perspective about fringe benefits and their taxation is how those benefits are disproportionately available to the most privileged sections of the Australian community, to the wealthiest groups. Again I refer to an Australian Bureau of Statistics employment benefit survey. The most recent one available is dated August last year, and it shows, for example, that some 7.1 per cent of Australian employees received some form of transportation fringe benefit. Turning that around, that suggests that over 92 per cent of Australian employees did not get a transportation fringe benefit. Let us look at the income levels involved in the payment of transportation fringe benefits. For example, compared with the 7.1 per cent of the community getting those benefits, of those earning incomes of below $200 a week only 3.3 per cent received a transportation fringe benefit. That is less than half the average figure. If we look at the highest income category in the Bureau's statistics, we see that rather than 7.1 per cent of those earning above $560 a week getting a transportation fringe benefit, the figure is 18.8 per cent. Clearly those fringe benefits-essentially the availability of company cars-were highly skewed to the wealthiest and those in the highest income groups in the Australian community. No doubt that is one of the reasons why the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia, which both speak for privilege in this country, are making such a fuss about the fringe benefits tax.

As I have pointed out, the taxation of fringe benefits is very important in financing the Government's taxation reductions to be introduced on 1 December. We could not bring in significant reductions in personal income tax without this very important tax on fringe benefits. As a result of that package, on 1 December the tax free threshold-that is, the amount of income exempt from income tax-will not be $4,595 as it is at the moment; it will be increased to $5,100. That is one of the changes for the great bulk of Australian taxpayers being financed by the introduction of the fringe benefits tax. We will also be paralleling that with reductions in marginal income tax rates. For example, the 46 per cent rate will be reduced on 1 December to 43 per cent, going down further on 1 July next year to 40c in the dollar-a tremendous reduction in that personal income tax rate. The top marginal rate-currently 60c in the dollar, which is the rate that this Government inherited from the Fraser-Howard Government-will be going down to 55c in the dollar on 1 December and to 49c in the dollar on 1 July next.

The result of those changes is quite interesting. For example, on 1 December a person with a taxable income of $400 a week will receive a tax cut of $5.10 and a person with a taxable income of $300 a week will receive a tax cut of $3.75. Our package will restore integrity to the Australian tax system. It will have more respect because it will be more profoundly based on the ability to pay principle. The Opposition would abandon our tax measures which crack down on tax avoidance. It would abandon the fringe benefits tax and, as a result, would jeopardise these significant and substantial personal income tax reductions for many people in Australia. The Liberals and the Nationals have absolutely no credibility on the question of taxation reform in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —What kind of integrity is being restored to a tax system when the Government promises tax cuts in September and then defers them to December, particularly after those cuts were part of the so-called deal we have just heard Senator Maguire talk about? It has been in a mess since the Government introduced it five months or so ago. TALK.START.PARA: —`Silver' has, but his colleague hasn't.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us get clear the basic ground rules for this tax. This is a tax on people, on small businesses and on farmers who may well be suffering losses at present, but this Government does not care about that. It has no concern for these people and it is only the fear of electoral defeat, including the inevitability of electoral defeat in Queensland, as my colleague said a few minutes ago, that has prompted the Government to look into these unintended consequences, as the Government calls them, of the fringe benefits tax. Let us recognise that not only did Senator Walsh not have any effective defence of the fringe benefits tax, but Senator Siddons of the Australian Democrats also had his customary two bob each way. I remind the Senate that if it had not been for Senator Siddons and his Australian Democrats this fringe benefits tax would not have existed. The Democrats should never be allowed to forget that. It is all very well for Senator Siddons to say now that there are problems and that something should be done about them. The fact is that he and his Australian Democrats sided with this Government to bring in this iniquitous tax.

Senator Walsh responded to the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, who made a very cogent argument about the severe and disastrous impact of this tax on those sections of the community which are least capable of looking after themselves. Senator Chaney pointed out that there are serious problems involving quadriplegics and people requiring assistance of a continuing nature, and that the tax hits them as well. Surely not even Senator Walsh could ignore that, but unfortunately he did. His only response was to say that by bringing up these matters the Opposition wanted to bring back the boozy lunch and pay pensions to millionaires.

TALK.START.PARA: —Totally irrelevant.

—As Senator Chaney said, it was totally irrelevant and in fact demeaning of him and of the Senate. This is a massively serious situation, as at last the Prime Minister is admitting, and it is one that deserves a serious answer. We did not get one in this place from the Minister in charge. Five months after we pointed out the real problem that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) now admits exist, there has been no response of any substance. That is the essential point. The bulk of the problems that the Prime Minister is now admitting are unintended consequences-in other words, he has fallen over his own feet-
—He is a slow learner.

—He is a very slow learner. The bulk of these, either in outline or in specific terms, were pointed out to him at the time. SPEECH.PARA: The structural defects in the tax are clearly evident from a letter written by the Minister Assisting the Treasurer, Mr Hurford-currently the Acting Treasurer-to one of our colleagues in the House of Representatives. The Government received a number of representations seeking exemption from the tax. However, after very carefully considering them, it decided that for reasons of equity it would not widen the field of exemption beyond that announced on 19 September 1985 for religious institutions. Even that single exemption was very tightly drafted in the Bill introduced into the Parliament.

Let us look at the way the Prime Minister behaved yesterday in the House of Representatives when he started to give ground, when he, if you like, created the first hole in the dike. What an extraordinary statement for the Prime Minister to make. He accused the Opposition of being derelict in its duty in not having raised these matters before. `Why has the Government not heard about them?', he said. `Is the Opposition derelict in its duty? The letter I just quoted related to representations made by the Opposition on 5 June. The speech I referred to that I had made about the National Trust was on 2 June. The examples go on and on of representations made not only by the Opposition but also by concerned people who are massively worried about the impact of this fringe benefits tax. It is curious that 10 minutes after the Acting Treasurer assured the House of Representatives yesterday that there would be no changes, Mr Hawke said that the Government would have to remove some unintended consequences.

That is the simple reality of what has happened. But what do we get when we come into the Senate and discuss this serious question of how we fix up this mess? All we get is the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) attacking the Opposition, trying to make political points rather than dealing with a matter which is of major concern to millions of Australians, who either directly or indirectly will be or have been affected by the incidence of this tax. I am particularly concerned about those who are either losing their jobs or are losing benefits which are of major significance particularly to those on lower incomes, who will no longer receive some of these benefits because their employers can no longer afford to give them to them now that they are being taxed. Is it not curious that the Minister for Finance decided to quote what the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, said six years ago on the question of accommodation in remote areas of Queensland to try to demonstrate that somehow the Opposition did not know where it was on this matter? The Opposition knows only too well where it is on this matter and where it has been on this matter. I can assure the Senate that we have a very determined view of what will happen on this matter when we are in government. There will certainly be a withdrawal of this tax. It is to be withdrawn lock, stock and barrel. But the reality is, as the Leader of the Opposition has said, that abuses involving tax avoidance will be dealt with. However, let us hear how the Australian Labor Party responded six years ago to the question of fringe benefits. I quote from Mr Hayden, the then Leader of the Labor Party who is still a member of Caucus and a senior Minister:

The concession given to subsidised housing at development townships and sites is a legitimate one . . . it is important for all workers on development sites throughout Australia to recognise that their living standards could be severely reduced and taxation payments substantially increased if the Government proceeds with its present intention to tax subsidised housing.

Six years ago the then Government listened to what Mr Hayden had to say. All I say to the Government at this stage is that, for heavens sake, it should get its house in order and stop going back in time and trying to make political points. It should try to fix up what is a serious mess. It should try to fix up the 139 pages of legislation, the 176 pages of explanatory memorandum, the two booklets of 69 pages, the 14 rulings of 115 pages, the pamphlets, the Press releases and the videos. A television mini-series will probably be needed next. We are now to have more changes. How on earth will the taxpayers of Australia possibly cope with this tax within 20 days and have their tax returns in? As the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has said, if they do not get their tax returns in they will go to gaol. That kind of threat is the only coherent response we are getting from this Government to a matter which has caused widespread concern among the community, a matter which was brought to the attention of this Government by the Opposition months ago and on which the Government must now act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly defend the fringe benefits tax and reject the utter hypocrisy and whingeing of the Opposition in calling for its repeal. Senator Chaney should be ashamed of himself for his tactics of using 78-year-old pensioners and quadriplegics, not because the Opposition cares about them, but in order to support the interest groups it has always supported-the already wealthy and pri-vileged in this community who have benefited overall more than anyone else by the absence of a fringe benefits tax until now. It is interesting that Senator Messner is not speaking in this debate as he is the Opposition spokesperson on taxation. Perhaps it is no wonder. It was he who pointed out that the Opposition could not justify supporting only the popular aspects of the tax package and opposing the unpopular aspects. The Opposition has repeatedly admitted the existence of fringe benefits rorts and rip-offs, yet has consistently refused to eliminate them. Moreover, it has positively hindered the Government's attempts to stop the fraud. Mr Howard just offers a whingeing chorus against the alleged mountains of paper work.

SPEECH.PARA: Not long ago, in May, the shadow Treasurer was interviewed on the Carleton-Walsh Report and asked whether the Government was not morally right to impose a tax on fringe benefits. Mr Carlton, MP, responded:
Yes I think the Government is quite morally right to clamp down on things that are beyond the pale. No question about that.

Then there were the comments last year by the President of the Liberal Party of Australia, John Valder, a Howard supporter, on what he thought was a confidential video interview. He said that he regarded the growth of fringe benefits as a disease and that he thought it was good that the Labor Party was doing all the hard work in cleaning it up so that the future coalition government could benefit. That is shocking hypocrisy on the part of the Liberal Party, but it shows its real attitude to the fringe benefits tax as being necessary.

I emphasise that the principle is that non-cash benefits should be just as taxable as cash benefits. That is all that this is about. One cannot have it any other way. Mr Howard is on record as saying much the same thing. The trouble is that employees have almost never declared such benefits in the past and employers have almost never reported them in group certificates. The necessary records must be kept, whoever is responsible for paying the tax. So the excess paperwork argument cannot be sustained. The root of the problem was that as well as legitimate fringe benefits, which still ought to have been taxable as they had a private value, there were those which were provided because some people were prepared to rort and abuse. The result was that those who did not have the lurks and perks had been asked to subsidise the taxation system. It is very telling that those who are complaining most about the fringe benefits tax are also the loudest in calling for a bigger cut in the deficit, cuts to wages and cuts to welfare payments.

One of the main whinges about the fringe benefits tax is that it removes incentives. What a lot of nonsense. Do we need a system that provides incentives through tax evasion? It should be remembered that the fringe benefits tax is part of an overall tax reform in which incentives will be provided through the reduction in income tax rates. The opponents of the fringe benefits tax should also remember that the fringe benefits tax is optional. The benefits in kind can be replaced by cash over which the employee can have total control. Senator Siddons in his speech said that the fringe benefits tax was a tax that the employee should be paying and not the employer. It is imposed on the employer because it is administratively simpler and because it involves a mere fraction of the number of people who would otherwise have to deal with the tax. If the employee were to pay the tax records would still have to be kept so that the employee could be advised on his or her group certificate how much of the fringe benefits were taxable. Fewer records and calculations are required under the Government's method of imposing the tax because each business need bother only with the total fringe benefits for all employees rather than have to allocate specific amounts to each individual. I repeat: The value of non-cash fringe benefits can be cashed out anyway so that no fringe benefits tax need be bothered about.

Some opponents of the tax have raised the question of the taxing of non-business activities, such as the National Trust being taxed on accommodation provided free or at concessional rates to people who care for buildings. The point is that such accommodation is still a private benefit and ought not to be a substitute for income. There is an alternative for organisations such as the National Trust: They could pay for the benefits provided in the normal way and charge a rent in exchange. There are alternatives to the payment of this tax. However, if people want to continue to provide free or concessional accommodation, they pay the fringe benefits tax accordingly. Other misleading claims have been made, especially about the taxing of the provision of occasional services or goods to an employee. People who make those misleading claims ignore the fact that there is an exemption for the first $200 worth if the aggregate taxable value of free or discounted goods and services provided to an employee per year. There is a lot of misrepresentation about this whole issue.

If the fringe benefits tax were to be repealed, as is asked for by the Opposition in its urgency motion today, what would then happen? There would be a legitimisation of even greater tax evasion. Business would no longer bother paying salaries to people at all. It would just pay all their bills, not only for their cars, school fees and holidays but also their grocery and electricity bills. This would reduce the amount of income taxable salary to a minimum. So, not only would there be no revenue from the fringe benefits tax, but also there would be vastly reduced income tax, as less salary would be paid, being replaced by more untaxed fringe benefits. So a repeal of the fringe benefits tax is just not on.

There is gross exaggeration about the paperwork required for this tax. A lot of nonsense is talked about log books for motor vehicle usage and there is a lot of confusion. Of course, this confusion is aided by the Opposition and its mates in the New Right. There is confusion about the fringe benefits tax and the substantiation requirements for tax deductions. As far as substantiation is concerned, I think we would all agree-we should, anyway-that a person who wants to have a tax deduction for business expenses, such as a car, should have to justify that with the proper records. As far as the fringe benefits tax is concerned, this is a different issue from substantiation; it concerns benefits provided by an employer to an employee-if a fringe benefit is provided, for instance, for the private and not the business use of a car, one must expect to have to distinguish between the private and the business use, again with proper records. In any case, no log book is necessary for the substantiation of a tax deduction if there is low business use or if one of the available formulae is chosen.

As far as the fringe benefits tax is concerned, the operation of a log book is optional but if it is used most people will have to make only one entry per day. A lot of nonsense is spoken about multiple entries, the need for an entry for every business trip in a day. If a person is using his or her car for business uninterrupted all day, only one entry is needed. More than one entry is needed only if private use of that vehicle occurs during the day. So all this talk about 15 minutes being required every day for keeping a log book is just nonsense. Thirty seconds or sixty seconds is more like the requirement.

In conclusion, the well-to-do people in this country, with the support of the Liberal and National Parties, merely want to continue evading their taxation and side-stepping their responsibilities to the Australian community. This Labor Government has made a commitment to tax reform and it will stick to that commitment. It must be remembered that this is a total tax package involving tax reform which will bring relief to pay as you earn workers and to the better off, the higher income earners on the very much lower marginal rates, who will also get benefits which they never acknowledge as being provided in this tax package, such as no longer having to pay tax on share dividends. The imputation provision is a very big benefit for business and for those who are better off in this country. The business people of this country should not complain about having to keep some records in exchange for these benefits. I wholeheartedly support the fringe benefits tax and oppose the urgency motion moved by the Opposition.
