DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 October, on motion by Senator Coates:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations to the Senate. I joined the Committee in the course of its compiling of the report. I was amazed at the obvious total disorganisation within the Public Service. The report outlines a remarkable story of the Public Service growing like Topsy, bypassing the normal reporting procedures and proliferating in an uncontrolled and an unaccountable way.

SPEECH.PARA: Not all non-statutory bodies are of this type, thank heavens. In particular, the incorporated bodies conform fully to their rules of incorporation, and usually fulfil their objective in a responsible manner. The only reservation the Committee makes about the operation of these incorporated but non-statutory organisations is that in the past there have been instances of these organisations either spawning or entering into association with other organisations whose powers exceed those of the non-statutory body. This has led to a large number of anomalies. This was originally raised by the Auditor-General in connection with the operation of Asia Dairy Industries. This report reveals an extraordinary level of incompetence, an extraordinary lack of accountability and an extraordinary financial mess among the non-incorporated statutory bodies.

Non-statutory bodies spent nearly $2,000m last year-something for the Coalition Waste Watch Committee to look at. Of this, the taxpayer funded around $300m, at best guess. At best guess was all the Committee could achieve because more than a quarter of all non-statutory bodies did not know what they spent. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) might like to look at this in more detail.

Perhaps the most interesting finding of the Committee was that most of those departments which deal most directly with the public lack committees for consulting public opinion. The worse offenders seem to be those who support the more underprivileged. The departments which supported the fewest consultative committees were Aboriginal Affairs, Communications, Social Security, Veterans' Affairs, Treasury, and Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Some of those departments with the fewest consultative committees are the departments which deal most closely with people in need, such as the Department of Social Security. They would seem to be the ones who would profit most from close ties with the community they serve and an understanding of their clients. Public feedback is vital when there is significant client contact or when commercial services are provided, as in the case of the Department of Communications.

In the United Kingdom, volunteers on users' councils keep such bodies as the Post Office in touch with community needs, and with community attitudes to the service they provide. This is a useful model for what can be done. I believe the idea should be taken up within the Australian Public Service. A very small secretariat can service such a group for a fraction of the cost of a single advertising campaign of the type which was involved in such spendthrift programs as Priority One: Young Australia. These groups can examine and report publicly on any aspect of a department's or an authority's operations which directly affects the public. This means management has a very strong incentive to identify problem areas quickly, and to provide a more effective service to the public. People's needs become the starting point for improvements. The ongoing nature of this scrutiny helps to create an atmosphere of co-operation. After a little while the initial defensiveness breaks down and better administration can result. If departments and authorities know that they are under effective and continuing scrutiny they will squeeze the most from available resources.

I was shocked that a large number of non-statutory bodies were mentioned in the report as not reporting to Parliament or even reported on to Parliament. Waste and inefficiency are best tackled by creating a climate in which better decisions are made in a more timely fashion. There will be no incentive to use inefficiency as a pretext for building new empires. Many non-statutory bodies seem to be part of the Public Service empire-building activities. Departments are already putting more effort into training and information collection and processing as a result of freedom of information legislation. The greater the access that the media and public have to relevant material, the better procedures become to avoid appeals against poor decisions.

It is extremely important-and this report starts the process-that we know what bodies we can appeal to and what are the structures within the Public Service. This report is just one part of the analysis of the structures of the Public Service. It is not just an ordinary tree like a business organisation; it consists of a whole lot of statutory bodies, non-statutory bodies, companies, interdepartmental committees-IDCs-and a framework of interrelating operations. Until the Parliament and the people of Australia understand the structure and the operations of the Public Service we will not know how to operate and use that particular resource effectively. We need to upgrade both the process of reporting and the process of providing service to the public. We must make certain that systems that we set up are, in fact, fully controlled and well audited.

Another major deficiency the Committee found with non-statutory bodies was this lack of defined reporting procedures. The Committee recommends that the reporting procedures be defined the moment the body is set up. Indeed, I would recommend that there also be community consultative committees for bodies which deal a lot with the public, that they report directly to the public rather than internally to the Department or to the Minister, and that there should also be at least annual reporting to Parliament in all cases where a body acquires any type of autonomy. Ministers will start taking more interest in the administration and the system within their departments if they think that the deficiencies they may have previously ignored will be aired publicly.

I believe that this report is yet another milestone in the move to try to open up the Public Service and to provide open government and open public service to the Australian community. Those in senior administrative positions will no longer turn a blind eye because of the added risk of exposure, and individuals will take responsibility for their action if, and only if, organisations or committees such as the Standing Committee of Finance and Government Operations continue their detailed scrutiny of these areas. All public servants will then strive for maximum effectiveness in the employment of resources. In this way we will have greater accountability and greater efficiency overall in the Public Service. We will also probably cut down considerably on the proliferation of non-statutory bodies if they are no longer seen to be a way around the normal rules of Public Service accountability to the Parliament and to the public. We must have open government, and the only way to achieve that is by constant vigilance. I commend the Committee's vigilance in bringing this report to the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations I would like to say a few words in relation to this report on non-statutory bodies which the Chairman, Senator Coates, tabled yesterday on our behalf. I support his remarks and those of Senator Vigor, who is also a member of the Committee. In many ways this report on non-statutory bodies is a path-finding report. I believe it deserves very widespread reading, both inside and outside the Parliament, because it deals with a range of government organisations about which I think all of us know very little indeed. As our Chairman said when tabling the report yesterday, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, since it commenced its work into statutory bodies in 1977-in that context I pay tribute to one of my predecessors on the Committee, former Senator Peter Rae-has tabled a number of reports on the activities of Commonwealth statutory authorities and certain other Commonwealth Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: While undertaking those investigations it became very clear to members of the Committee that they, and indeed the Parliament and the wider community, knew very little about the activities of another very large group of government bodies, namely, the so-called non-statutory bodies, or NSBs. The Senate will recall that in 1983 the Committee sought and received from the Senate a reference to investigate and report on the activities of those bodies. The Committee produced an interim report in October 1984 and the report tabled yesterday is a follow-up to that report. It is a much more detailed and investigative report and reveals some very interesting facts, although as a committee we fully recognise that perhaps there are some doubts about the authenticity of all the information contained in the report because of the difficulty we had as a committee in obtaining information on non-statutory bodies. One of the problems in that context was the very question of defining a non-statutory body. That is something the Committee has addressed in this report and I think it will be of ongoing future benefit.

Despite those difficulties we had in this investigation, as the Chairman said, we did gain considerable insight into non-statutory body activities for the year we were looking at, 1984-85. Through the information supplied to us by the various government departments, we identified a total of 598 of these non-statutory bodies, which provided completed questionnaires. All departments except the Department of Finance have some non-statutory bodies attached to them. In that sense the information that has come forward is very helpful. We found some disturbing facts along the way as well. First of all, as I have already mentioned, there was a lack of knowledge by members of parliament about the activities and the existence of non-statutory bodies. In fact, there was a lack of knowledge by many Ministers of non-statutory bodies within their portfolios, and a lack of information within the departments generally as to even what was a non-statutory body and what might be the responsibilities and accountabilities of such bodies.

We found evidence of a great lack of reporting by non-statutory bodies. For example, we found that only 54-less than 10 per cent-of the 598 non-statutory bodies we surveyed had published or tabled in the Parliament an annual report for the 1984-85 financial year, although there were other bodies that had produced reports other than annual reports during that time. The information coming forward and available to the Parliament and to the wider public from non-statutory bodies is very much lacking. Disturbingly, we found a considerable lack of cost identification in terms of the operation of these bodies. That lack of cost identification was not a matter just for the non-statutory bodies but, indeed, for the departments within whose portfolios the bodies resided. Given the existence of such a huge number of non-statutory bodies-we have probably understated the real number-I think it is absolutely essential, for cost and accountability reasons, that a great deal of effort now be put into improving the financial accountability and financial information provided by those bodies.

As I have said, related to that we did find a lack of knowledge of the accountablity of these bodies in terms of what really were their responsibilities, their role in the total scheme of things, to whom they should be reporting and to whom they should be fully accountable. We had problems defining non-statutory bodies. We have made some recommendations in this report which I think will be helpful in sorting that out. As I said, our data is not infallible. To readers of the report-my parliamentary colleagues and others-I would caution placing too much weight on particular figures, but the trend and overall direction of information in the report I think are very helpful.

We have made a key recommendation that a central register of non-statutory bodies be created and maintained by some co-ordinating department and that that register be established by 30 June 1987. At the moment there is no register of NSBs at all and that is a very considerable problem if we are to keep track of the existence of NSBs, their accountability, their actions and so on. I regard that recommendation as a very important one, provided-I think this can be achieved-that it does not create a whole new bureaucracy and a whole new cost structure in itself. I think the register can be maintained without that happening.

The Audit Office has a system of allocating time to various tasks undertaken by officers. I turn to one problem I noticed this year. Electronic Counter terminals for Post Offices (CP 2078). Tender. DC: AP71. Inquiries, W. Birdjan, tel. (03) 668 1729.

Let me quote from a letter from that company's Managing Director to the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy):

Our technical staff who have had, collectively, over 150 years' experience in designing, implementing and managing network development projects considerably larger in scope and performance than the Australia Post requirements, quite frankly regard CP 2078 as hopelessly inadequate unless its purpose is simply to, de facto, place the control and conduct of this work in the hands of the Commonwealth Bank.

There should be a full examination of the types of activities within Australia Post that I have described. I believe that the discontinuance of the efficiency audit, whatever the reasons given, was quite unreasonable and that it should be completed. I request the Government to ask the Auditor-General to look at some of the aspects of Australia Post, details of which I have given--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —This package contains two Bills, the Australian Institute of Sport Bill 1986 and the Australian Institute of Sport (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1986. It is interesting to note that the Institute of Sport, which is what these Bills are all about, has come about through a bipartisan effort. The late Hon. Frank Stewart was, I suppose, mainly responsible for its establishment and then the Hon. Bob Ellicott really brought it to fruition in about 1980. The Institute of Sport itself has the support of all the parties in this Parliament. Let me say that right from the start, even though we are opposing this legislation and an amendment to the second reading motion is being circulated in my name. When this legislation was debated in the House of Representatives, the speakers on our side all made the point that we are not against the Institute of Sport in what it is doing and what it is trying to achieve. We do have problems with this legislation because we are not in agreement with the setting up of another statutory authority. The Australian Sports Commission is quite willing and quite able to do the job which has been set for this newly-created statutory authority.

SPEECH.PARA: The Institute has had its problems; there is no doubt about that. As a matter of fact, last year the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) was the subject in the other place of a censure motion because of problems with the Institute of Sport. Accountability was certainly very slack. That was pointed out by the speakers in the other place when it was debated. It ended up with a censure motion being moved against the Minister over the bad way in which it was being run and the lack of accountability. Interestingly, there is still a problem there. As I understand it, as recently as a month ago there was a further police investigation into the Institute and the actions of some members or a member of the Institute; so all is not well. The Minister must bear a lot of the responsibility for the failure to tighten up the place and run it as well as it should. While that is going on one cannot have good morale amongst the people out there. We have young people training at the Institute and we have people training them. There are people there who are going to represent us on the various sporting fields of the world. We expect them to do well, we expect them to give of their best. While this uncertainty about administration is going on, it can only cast a pall over them. It is hoped that that investigation bears fruit shortly and the whole sorry state of affairs gets tidied up.

Having said that, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has brought these Bills before the Parliament. As I said, the Government is setting up another statutory authority and we see no reason for that whatsoever. We have the Australian Sports Commission, to which there are good people appointed who are quite willing and able to take over the running of the Australian Institute of Sport without setting up another statutory authority. That is the reason we are moving our amendment. Already we have had a debate on the Australian Sports Aid Foundation legislation. We opposed that as it would have set up something which was not necessary and indeed such a foundation would leave itself open to accusations of political usage as far as donations channelled towards it are concerned. As I said at the outset, the Institute of Sport is there. It has all-party support and it has had all-party support from its foundation. We wish it well and we hope that its internal problems can be tidied up as soon as possible. We do not see the necessity for another statutory corporation as the Sports Commission can do the job. To give effect to those thoughts, I move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Australian Institute of Sport Bill:
Leave out all words after `That', insert:

`the Senate is of the opinion that this Bill should not be proceeded with as it does nothing more than add to the burgeoning number of statutory authorities already in existence when the functions of the proposed Institute of Sport could well be performed by an existing body'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Institute of Sport Bill 1986 and the Australian Institute of Sport (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1986 place the Australian Institute of Sport, as a public company, in liquidation and recreate it as a government statutory authority. The Government's reason for the change is to give greater parliamentary supervision over the public moneys invested in the Institute. I think it is extremely important to have greater parliamentary supervision and not merely ministerial supervision as the present legislation provides. The Australian Democrats will be moving a number of amendments to the Bills in the Committee stage, the effect of which will be to give the Parliament a much greater supervisory role. We will not be supporting the Opposition's amendment to the second reading, which basically guts the Bills and throws the proposal out.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is extremely important to keep the Australian Institute of Sport in existence. It fulfils a very important role in producing a climate of excellence in Australian sport, in training sportsmen and sportswomen for world events and in developing a consciousness of excellence in sport over a wide range of different sports. However, the Institute has had a number of management hiccups. Its management must be improved without producing a bureaucratic empire-building process. It is important for Australia to have a centre of excellence such as the Australian Institute of Sport which serves both the officials of sports and the athletes who stay there.

The Opposition has supported the need for greater control and accountability to the Government and to the Parliament and I hope that it will support the amendments which the Democrats will be moving to strengthen even more the process of control by the Parliament of this organisation's activities. To oppose and throw out the Bills would not be an effective way of managing this type of operation because the Institute will carry on in its current form under the ordinance under which it was set up. So really it is an empty argument to say that if the Bills were thrown out it would result in any saving.

The Institute offers a highly specialised and professional service to people in sport. It must be an autonomous organisation and must not end up being tied up in complex sport politics which surround the administrative structure of the Sports Commission. The Australian Institute of Sport Bill gives the Institute a change in status. Instead of reporting through an Australian Capital Territory ordinance the Institute will have full statutory powers under the new legislation which the Bills will set up. The change in status and the greater accountability to Parliament will hopefully cure some of the problems and the excesses which were identified in the Price Waterhouse audit last November which left the management of the AIS in some degree of low morale.

I believe it is important not only to improve the standard of competitors in various sports but also to support those officials, coaches, referees, umpires and linesmen-who need training in the proper operation of the `nuts and bolts' activities involved in running sport effectively. Indeed programs such as the national training centre program and the visiting athletes program should allow more athletes to benefit from the skills and knowledge which are available at the Australian Institute of Sport.

The Democrats welcome the intention of the Institute to reduce its involvement at a community level, particularly through the satellite coaches program and the identification of athletes and sports officials directly through operations of the Institute, and for it to become more involved in joint ventures with State organisations and other institutions such as sporting organisations which can act as spotters for the type of talent that we must find to bring the most excellent sportsmen and sportswomen in Australia under the Institute's care. It was the Institute moving out to try to form a broad pyramid in each of the sports and offering services directly to people in each of the States that resulted in the overlap of the Sports Commission and the Institute. I believe it is very important for the Institute to work with corresponding State bodies and organisations to fulfil those roles and to concentrate on the sports medicine and sports development programs which I think in the long run will give Australia a competitive edge and a sense of excellence in international sport.

I now come to the amendments which the Democrats will be moving in the Committee stage. We believe it is important that not only should the Institute develop people's talents but also that it should be involved in the process of recognising talent. We wish the Bill to be as broad as possible, so our first amendment is based on the recognition of talent as well as development of talent in people in sports. As I said earlier, we believe that the Institute should be involved with sport in the broadest possible way. Not only should the players who compete in a sport be involved in training but also the officials, umpires and referees. That is the subject of the second amendment we will be moving.

Our third and fourth amendments are based on the need to report to Parliament. Particularly we are seeking to have any ministerial directive that is given to the Institute reported to each House of Parliament within five sitting days of that directive being given by the Minister. The next amendment basically states that we want the Institute to operate on a triennial rolling plan. We want to know three years ahead what the Institute of Sport is doing and we want that plan updated each year. We want that to be the basis of a reporting structure to Parliament. The Government seems to believe that such organisations can operate on a year to year basis or even triennium to triennium basis. However, it is very difficult to manage an organisation such as this, or a university or any other organisation, that involves continuing programs on a year to year strategic plan. It is not really a strategic plan if it is not going to be a rolling plan.

The second last amendment we will move at the Committee stage deals with the Board. Basically, we wish to incorporate into the Bill the requirement for equal opportunity, for affirmative action. We are saying that appointments to the Board shall be such that its members shall consist as far as practicable of equal numbers of men and women. It seems very reasonable that as our community is made up approximately equally of men and women, their involvement in sport and their views should be equally represented on the board of such an organisation. This is a model of the type of amendments we will be moving an amendment to to similar Bills in the future. We are also very concerned about the Chairman of the Board having special status. The Government has insisted in the Bill that the Chairman of the Board shall have a casting vote in the case of an equal vote. We believe that it is much more reasonable to follow the normal practice where in the case of equality of votes the question before the Board shall be resolved in the negative.

These are very simple administrative changes. The Democrats support the basic thrust of making the Australian Institute of Sport a strong and independent body. We support its continued existence and we wish it luck and every success in trying to make Australian sportsmen and sportswomen develop sufficiently to be able to compete on an equal footing and to do better than people from all over the world. We believe that the Institute is fulfilling an important role for Australians and for Australian sport. We believe that the Bill, with the amendments we will move at the Committee stage, will produce a stable administrative environment and a good reporting structure of which both the Government and this Parliament can be proud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Institute of Sport Bill 1986 and the Australian Institute of Sport (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1986 represent the next chapter in the saga of the Australian Institute of Sport. They transfer it from being a company to a statutory authority, and that is the reason why the Opposition is opposing the Bills. We do not see the need to create another statutory authority. We have created enough of them. I remember objecting previously to the Australian Sports Commission. We received that body per kind favour of the Australian Democrats voting with the Labor Government. That Commission now has 20 Board members who do not have enough to do. It could adequately supervise the activities of the Australian Institute of Sport.

SPEECH.PARA: The administration of sport in Australia is quite gravely fractured between the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism, the Australian Institute of Sport, the Australian Sports Commission and the Sports Aid Fund. People have to traipse to many different offices whenever they want to carry out negotiations with the Federal Government concerning the administration of sport. The original concept of the Australian Institute of Sport, I suppose, derived from a figment of the imagination of Mr Whitlam and his Government. After an Olympic Games in which Australian athletes performed well but had not won many medals I remember much criticism to the effect that we did not have same kind of government commitment to athletes as the Eastern bloc countries have, where sportsmen are just another branch of the Public Service and where all their training, dietary needs, income, in fact all their wants, are looked after. They are trained specifically for sport and given a healthy dose of drugs to go about it, too. It was felt that this kind of system would be beneficial to Australia. So the idea of the Australian Institute of Sport was conceived.

The Institute has had its ups and downs. I notice that they were referred to as hiccups by Senator Vigor when he was talking about them, but they were a little more than that. When the Institute started it was quiescent for a number of years. It stood as a threatening body which had all the other sporting bodies in Australia worried about what its activities were to be and how it would interfere with them. That was about eight years ago. About six years ago it was resuscitated. Its main troubles were discovered just last year and it had to be investigated by Price Waterhouse, I think. It found that there had been excessive staff spending, excessive expenditure on meals for staff in restaurants and on other entertaining, excessive travel expenditure, excessive expenditure on furniture, excessive allowances, or higher duties, as they were called. There is a very dubious spot merit fund. It had some very shaky tender procedures. It was no wonder that at that stage it ran into a budget deficit, a shortfall that was quite serious at the time.

Yet the Government claims that the Australian Institute of Sport is vital to the development of sport in Australia and that it will be responsible for a re-emergence of Australia's pre- eminence in sport. What sport is the Government talking about? Is it talking about, say, the Davis Cup? Australia has a proud history of many years of doing well in the Davis Cup and winning world championships in other areas. Just last week we won the semi-final to go into the challenge round of the Davis Cup. One of our players, Wally Masur, has a connection with the Australian Institute of Sport but he did not actually play in the semi-final. The Government cannot be talking about tennis, although I know that it has quite a commitment to tennis coaching. It could not be talking about the world golf championship which Australia won just last week with a team which I am sure had no connection whatsoever with the Australian Institute. Australia lays claim to being the world champions in rugby at the moment. There is one country which plays rugby which Australia is having some difficulty in playing. One could not really claim to be the world champions unless one had beaten that country. We have a pre-eminent position in the world in rugby league.

How much did the Australian Institute of Sport contribute towards winning the America's Cup? It was a completely private show the whole time. It is a ridiculous claim that the Australian Institute will put Australia back into a position of pre-eminence. I dare say that we had better not talk too much about cricket at the moment. The Australian team is competing in India. I do not think the Institute has much to do with creating pre-eminent cricketers in Australia. Australian rules, an enormous and expanding sport-expanding even in Queensland-has no connection with the Australian Institute of Sport. Maybe the socceroos and the hockey teams have a connection. We have a world champion in boxing on our doorstep right now. I am sure that he has never heard of the Australian Institute of Sport. So I wonder what sports the Government is talking about.

I know that the Government has a big commitment to track and field, gymnastics and swimming. I suppose that is predicated on the theory that only the Government can afford to bring world famous coaches to Australia to coach these people. I suppose that is applying the theory that only the Government can run the post office and the railways. I do not subscribe to that theory or to the theory that only the Government can bring these world class coaches to Australia. When the Institute was originally proposed Franz Stampfl was the coach whom the Government was talking about bringing here. The Government says now that without the Institute we could not do it.

The functions of the Institute have been defined in the legislation. They are quite extensive and have been expanded to quite a considerable degree. They include program development and implementation and the management and development of facilities. The raising of money for the Institute is defined as are the powers of the Institute, the provision of scholarships, commercial sponsorship, which I will talk about in a minute, marketing and community access facilities. In regard to sponsorship, I can imagine this Government looking around seeing the wonderful sport that is organised in Australia today and all the advertising and money that goes into it and being very keen to get its hands on that sort of money. I am sure that was the genesis of the Sports Aid Foundation. I am certain that it is the intention of the Government that the money that goes into the sponsorship of sport will be a recognised business expense for advertising only if it goes through the Sports Aid Foundation. That stage has not been reached yet, but I am sure that it is the aim of the Government.

Once the sponsorship funds are in the hands of the Minister he would be able to decide just what sports were sponsored. That would take it out of the hands of the people who wanted to sponsor a particular sport. Only the sports the Minister thought were deserving would be sponsored. I can imagine that the sort of sports that would attract the Minister may not be the sports that would attract the funds, and the funds would fall off. In addition one could expect a delineation of which companies could sponsor which sport. For example, would breweries and tobacco companies be allowed to sponsor sport? What would happen if the prevailing winds of public opinion were suddenly that tobacco companies should not sponsor sport? An awful lot of money could be lost to sport.

One of the aims of the Institute now is to decentralise sport. But sport was always decentralised in this country. The Institute tended to centralise it. The Institute was to be a home of the elite. It was to bring them all to Canberra and finish their training. Now the Government's policy is to decentralise sport. I remember that one of the early fears was that certain sports would be specialised to certain places. For example, Perth was noted for its hockey. So there was a definite move to make Perth the hockey capital of Australia. That meant that any kids in the east who wanted elite coaching in hockey would have had to go to Perth to get it. Similarly, Townsville was to be made the swimming capital of Australia. So any kids in Perth who wanted to concentrate on swimming would have had to go to Townsville. This is ridiculous bureaucratic thinking. Instead we should be leaving our States to run their own sports. Fortunately, the idea must have been strangled at birth because it did not eventuate. However, I know it was a phase the Government went through. Throughout history sportsmen have had to travel to get the best coaching. That is normal. It happens with music and the arts. One has to go to where the best coaches are. The important thing to note is that it was all done free for the Government, and free of the Government, too. It did not have to be done.

The Institute's role is being expanded in regard to the elite sportsman. It is now to include recreation. It is to include safety, which no one can argue with. It is being expanded to include fitness for the disabled. I am not against fitness for the disabled. The Australian disabled have put in some world class performances around the world. Perhaps the best use we could make of the Institute of Sport is to look after our disabled and leave our elite sportsmen to the devices which have been supplied for them by sporting bodies over many years.

Sports medicine is to take a big role in the expanded activities of the Institute of Sport. Sports medicine is a very big and expanding area. It will cost a lot of money, but it will be well worth it all the way. It all started well before there ever was an Australian Institute of Sport. I am rather pleased to say that I had a pioneering role in sports medicine. Sports medicine is the medicine of the healthy. It is teaching people how not to overstress their bodies, how not to get injured, how to be able to get back on the field next week. If one has star athletes one does not want them off the field injured all the time. It is very hard if one is organising sport and the tickets have all been sold when suddenly the star cannot go on because of some minor injury or illness. This has all been done free for government in the past. I see a burgeoning and controlling role for sports medicine which will interfere with the administration of sporting bodies in Australia. When we think of the differences in sports medicine needed, in, say, boxing, tennis, rugby and track and field, we realise that they are all vastly different areas that need different kinds of specialised care. The Australian Institute of Sport will try to fill that role when it does not have a hope of doing it. In fact, it can only give a restricted advisory and probably controlling service which will be a nitpicking nuisance to everybody and a great cost to the people. The Australian Institute of Sport has an expanding role which will get bigger, as happens with all government instrumentalities. This Government has chosen a statutory corporation to control this expanding body and will ignore the role that could be played by the Australian Sports Commission.

Turning to the administration of sport, I was fortunate enough to hold a senior executive position with a major Australian sporting body for many years. We were responsible for local administration and organisation, metropolitan organisation, intrastate organisation, interstate organisation, national organisation and international competition and organisation, in addition to junior development and organisation for the veterans, one of whom I happen to be now. This sort of administration for each sport involves an enormous amount of work and an enormous number of people. Currently it is all done free in Australia by voluntary workers who are very hard to replace. It has all been self-financing and we have had coaching at all levels. Participants in just about all sports need coaching at all levels. The Australian Institute is supposed to be looking after only the elite sportsmen. But even elite sportsmen need different coaches for different parts of their game, or different events that they have to go into, and it is virtually impossible to say `Here is the athletics coach' or `Here is the gymnastics coach'. We need a great many specialised coaches in different areas.

No doubt certain sports in Australia are very supportive of the role and activities of the Australian Institute of Sport. I can imagine that, because they are drinking at the public trough and having a good time whereas other sports are excluded. I think we will now see an explosion of sport whereby different sporting bodies want their activities defined as a sport so that they can get into the public trough also. This will not be good for Australian sport. Could white water canoeing be classified as a national sport? The canoeists classify themselves as such, and there are international competitions in this sort of thing. I do not know whether they would be coached in Canberra but I imagine that everybody from white water canoeists to the West Preston old boys poker school will be applying for sports status in Australia.

It is obvious that sports administration in Australia is quite fractured today among the Department, the Institute, the Sports Commission and the Sports Aid Foundation. I do not believe that a statutory corporation will be the answer. I can remember predicting in the debate on the Australian Sports Commission that these problems would occur. They have occurred and the Government is now taking this action to fix them. I can promise honourable senators that this action will not fix them, because sports administration is too diverse and too specialised to be handled by a body such as this. It will cause disruption to sport in Australia. I have named the sports that I am sure do not have any connection whatsoever with the Australian Institute. At the moment in most of those sports we have world pre-eminence. I have looked at the amendments to be moved by the Australian Democrats. One of them could have some merit but it will not fit in with what is proposed by the Government. We must reject the Bill. I support the amendment that was moved earlier by Senator Collard.

I mention particularly the work of coaches at the Institute. Many people do not realise the long hours these gentlemen and ladies work. Senator Sheil has mentioned the raising of money by the Institute by appropriate means. I do not see that as a bad thing; it is doing that at the moment. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Alice Springs to Darwin Railway-Fringe Benefits Tax-Australian Security: Visit of Mysoon Shaath-National Drug Offensive-Australian Parliamentary Disarmament Forum

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to take up two distinct but very important issues which are of national significance and worthy of serious debate. One of those issues is the fringe benefits tax. There is no doubt that that issue is being treated very seriously by the Australian community. Even the Federal Government is coming to the realisation that there are grave problems and consequences flowing from this tax. That is something about which I will say something later.

SPEECH.PARA: The other issue of national significance, which unfortunately has been receiving no constructive attention from the Federal Government, is the proposed Alice Springs to Darwin rail link. Only yesterday in the chamber the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) ranted about this project and described Canadian Pacific Railway Corporation as being involved in a shonky report on the viability of the railway. Senator Walsh seems to be increasingly incapable of discussing, debating or considering this project in a rational and sensible way. While one can commiserate with the Minister, as he must have rather a lot on his mind these days with his Government's fortunes declining and facing the certainty of defeat at the next election, one cannot excuse his flippant and off-hand dismissal of the Alice Springs to Darwin line when he clearly has not objectively studied the facts. Cold hard facts are not the sorts of matters Senator Walsh tends to address when he answers the questions his obliging colleagues ask about matters so dear to his heart, such as the rail project.

In the interests of setting the matter straight, I wish this evening to state the facts, as I have endeavoured to do before. As early as 1911 the Commonwealth accepted an obligation to build the line and that obligation was confirmed in 1949 when Commonwealth legislation made it clear that the Commonwealth was committed to building and paying for the line. In 1982 the former Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, pledged that the line would be built by 1988. The then Opposition, in the lead-up to the 1983 Federal election under the leadership of Mr Hawke, made an unequivocal pledge that it would build the line and, indeed, Australian Labor Party spokesmen went so far as to say that only a Labor government could be trusted to build the line. After its election, the Labor Government immediately repudiated its pledge and came back with an offer which required the Northern Territory Government to find 40 per cent of the total cost of the line. That the Territory Government rejected this offer should come as no surprise, for the Territory was justified in pressing its case that the Commonwealth should meet its obligation. Of course, as far as the Territory was concerned, it was a case of where the money would come from.

The result was that the Commonwealth completely walked away from that obligation. In order to demonstrate that it was justified, the Federal Government set up the Independent Economic Inquiry into Transport Services to the Northern Territory, which investigated the feasibility of the line. The inquiry was headed by Mr David Hill. We hear of him now as being in charge of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. He was then the head of the New South Wales Rail Authority, an organisation which consistently records huge losses. Not surprisingly, Mr Hill found that the line was not viable within the terms of reference of his inquiry, but it is worth considering that specifically excluded from the terms of reference of the inquiry was an assessment of the defence implications or benefits of the railway. Only weeks after Hill's findings were announced came the publication of a document from three respected defence studies specialists, including Dr Desmond Ball, of the Australian National University's Strategic and Defence Studies Centre. The document deals specifically with the defence implications of the Alice Springs-Darwin railway. Those specialists concluded that it was essential as a means of transportation of personnel and equipment in the event of any northern defence threat. Indeed, if one looks at the development of the Tindal Royal Australian Air Force base and sees the enormous development that has taken place there-it will be the home base for the FA18 fighter squadron in the not too distant future-with the new roads and new housing, one can see the benefit of a railway to service that very important defence link.

Leaving aside that glaring omission from the terms of reference, there were a number of other inadequacies in the Hill study which were subsequently revealed when the papers of the inquiry were made available under the Freedom of Information Act. It should be noted that there were no detailed working papers prepared by the Hill inquiry. The inquiry made no independent assessment or projection of the likely task traffic. There was no justification for the particular methodological approach adopted by the inquiry. No analysis or assessment was made of the adequacy of critical cost assumptions for design and operating standards. No social audit methodology was developed, despite the clear statement that this was to be a social audit inquiry. Mining traffic forecasts were arbitrarily downgraded without any consultation with the Northern Territory Government, despite the fact that the inquiry stated that forecasts were based on the Northern Territory Government's submission. A major failing of the inquiry was its failure to cost the national benefits of the railway and its reliance only on corridor benefits. The list goes on.

The Northern Territory Government was entitled to be appalled at the cynicism of the Hill report and the Federal Government, which welcomed the report with open arms. The Northern Territory Government very properly engaged the consultants of the Canadian Pacific Railway Corporation, a world-renowned company the reputation of which is beyond dispute. It carries 85 million tonnes of traffic per annum in North America. Its expertise is unquestionable and, most importantly and in stark contrast with Mr Hill's outfit, Canadian Pacific makes a profit. The railway authority of which Mr Hill was chairman has lost some $800m per annum and relies on Commonwealth funds for its survival. Canadian Pacific conducted a truly independent inquiry into the economic feasibility of the line and concluded that in strictly economic terms the railway extension is viable for a broad range of traffic forecasts and provided sound justifications and bases upon which it reached this conclusion.

In the course of Senator Walsh's attack yesterday he criticised the Canadian Pacific report as shonky and made a number of other allegations which are simply incorrect. Firstly, his statement that the Northern Territory intended to flog off housing to a private institution was wrong. No such decision has been made by the Northern Territory Government. The Northern Territory Government has not yet made any decision by way of raising finance and there is no prospect or intention of selling off houses. What Senator Walsh said yesterday was a repeat of the stories put about by ALP persons in the Territory. It is irresponsible of the Minister to repeat allegations which are unnecessary, unhelpful, and which have caused considerable distress to a number of Northern Territory citizens. In repeating the allegations, Senator Walsh's behaviour is unacceptable. Senator Walsh also claimed that the so-called proposed investment was not rational. The facts are that the Northern Territory Government's whole approach to the railway-this has been stressed time and time again in public statements by the Chief Minister-has been that the investment, if it is to be made, should be done on an entirely rational basis. If there have been any irrational decisions, surely they have been the decisions taken by the Federal Government in its investments in other railways.

Canadian Pacific rationally analysed the costing of the railway and found a number of savings over and above the estimated cost of the project as projected by Hill. These savings are, firstly, a $97m to $117m evaluation of savings beyond the Alice Springs-Darwin corridor within which rail construction will take place; secondly, $109m to $141m modification of track design and construction schedule; thirdly, $40m-elimination of non-economic passenger services from passenger evaluation; fourthly, $30m to $40m-improved estimation of road maintenance cost savings; fifthly, $13m to $32m-salvage of track-laying equipment and welding plant at the end of the construction period; sixthly, $8m to $11m- consideration of change from three-man to two-man crews on freight trains; and seventhly, $246m-alternative forecasts of the initial tonnage, annual growth and average distance on each tonne of freight that is moved.

The Canadian Pacific report in present term values using a 7 per cent discount rate estimates that the project would provide a real return of $54m to $264m depending on traffic projections. Does that sound like a careless, irrational or shonky analysis? As I have said, Senator Walsh said that the Canadian Pacific report contained three wrong assumptions. The first was that all traffic would travel the length of the line. He is wrong. The report bases traffic estimates on goods travelling an average of just over 1,000 kilometres when the line is around 1,400 kilometres. Secondly, he claimed that the report was based on the assumption that all south-north traffic would use the rail over road. Again he is wrong. The calculations were based upon an 80-20 split with rail carrying 80 per cent. That figure is achieved by the east-west Pacific rail link. That is a fair enough comparison.

Senator Walsh stated that the report took into account alleged benefits to the rest of the railway system in Australia. On that he is right, but he cannot seriously believe that the benefits are merely alleged. They will definitely exist and are relevant. It is only natural that once the line is in place the option will be available for freight to be sent direct by rail from Sydney, Melbourne or any other eastern port and so the rail systems of the eastern States will benefit from the increased traffic. There are also savings on road maintenance which will flow from an increased reliance on rail traffic. If the Minister does not understand the real economic benefits which will flow from this project that reflects poorly on his capacity to grasp fairly simple economic facts. His comments yesterday, as I said earlier, were irresponsible and economic nonsense.

The Northern Territory Government's railway executive group which was charged with the task of coming up with an honest appraisal of the ways in which the project could be funded had done just that. The group examined freight forecasting, construction, surveying and land acquisition considerations and operations and maintenance as well as financial evaluation. The group reported recently to the Northern Territory Cabinet and on the basis of its report the Northern Territory Government is pledged to going ahead with the project and financing it with private investments from companies involved in the transport, construction, freight forwarding and finance areas.

I would have thought that Senator Walsh, who is so averse to the Federal Government providing any funds for the project in spite of its obligations to do so, would have applauded the initiative and self-reliance which the Northern Territory Government is showing in regard to this project. The Northern Territory is not going to be left behind simply because the Commonwealth is not prepared to meet its responsibilities. Other projects are going ahead at a great pace in the Northern Territory.

I have already indicated that the gas pipeline which Senator Walsh dismissed as a pie in the sky is almost complete. This is a massive project whereby natural gas is being brought from Central Australia and is supplying towns along the Stuart Highway to Darwin. That pipeline will supply the new Darwin power house with gas. It is an immense private enterprise-Northern Territory Government project and, as I understand it, it has received no contribution from the Federal Government. The free trade zone, which is being developed, is attracting interest from Hong Kong and other Asian nations and, in conjunction with the rail link, will make Darwin a major port in the Pacific. Rather than constantly harping on about the Northern Territory, Senator Walsh would be well advised to take a leaf out of its book and get his Government to show the same initiative and encouragement for development of industry as is happening in the Northern Territory.

That leads me to the second matter on which I wish to speak very briefly which is the anti-investment, anti-business and anti-enterprise policies which this Federal Government clearly favours. I refer specifically to the fringe benefits tax. I have a petition which was presented in the Senate today from some 1,868 Territory people and which opposes the introduction of this inequitable tax. Like hundreds of thousands of Australians, these petitioners know that, in spite of the claims of the Federal Treasurer (Mr Keating) that the tax is intended to catch the tax cheats, it is really penalising small business and imposing ridiculous burdens in pen-pushing and form-filling on Australians who are more interested in getting on with the job.

The petition calls for the rescission of the fringe benefits tax. The fringe benefits tax will, firstly, increase both personal and company taxation, secondly, undermine employment levels through reducing profitability and international competitiveness of industry, thirdly, result in price increases, fourthly, force employers to withdraw voluntary incentives to employees paid over and above existing payments, and, fifthly, endanger stable industrial relations because of the potential for forced withdrawal of fringe benefits. Yesterday even the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) conceded that the anomalies in the tax and the paperwork involved would mean that a review of the situation is called for. No doubt the Prime Minister has made this announcement with one eye on the Queensland election.

The petition presented to the Senate this morning was drawn up and circulated by a group of concerned organisations in the Northern Territory. The organisations include the Northern Territory Confederation of Industry and Commerce, the Master Builders Association of the Northern Territory, the Motor Traders Association of the Northern Territory, the Northern Territory Branch of the Australian Mines and Metals Association, the Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association, the Northern Territory Branch of the Australian Small Business Association, the Real Estate Institute of the Northern Territory and the Northern Territory Chamber of Mines together with many hundreds of indivi-duals. These organisations also arranged for a comprehensive survey to be conducted to establish in dollars-and-cents terms the impact of the FBT on the private sector. The form and subsequent analysis were undertaken by an economist employed by the Department of the Chief Minister.

The outcome of the survey showed that longstanding award provisions are now deemed to be fringe benefits taxable in the hands of the employer. These provisions are awards of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and were not introduced or contemplated as tax avoidance schemes. The sample, being 13.2 per cent of the private sector work force, was reliable. The benefits subject to the new taxation are estimated at $60m, and so tax would be about $26m. The highest tax payable was estimated at $1,451 in the mining industry and the lowest was $258 per employee in the pastoral industry. The weighted average came to $755 per employee. All this represents an increase in private sector costs of some 5 per cent. The report looked at the administration problems and found that all Northern Territory employer organisations are encountering massive difficulties in advising their members as to the interpretation of the legislation. We have certainly heard plenty about that in the Senate particularly in the last few days. I can imagine the problems of employer organisations now that the whole matter is under review. Not only is the Northern Territory having problems; everyone in Australia is having them.

The administrative burden will impose as yet unknown operation costs while government has been forced to create an infrastructure which will destroy any revenue generation originally intended. The report's final conclusion is that the tax is unable to be consistently interpreted and is therefore unworkable and unenforceable. It may be that the Federal Government is on the verge of discovering this for itself. In the meantime I understand that officers of the Australian Taxation Office in the Northern Territory, in their zeal to enforce the tax, are adopting rather overbearing measures. It seems that they are so keen that they are harassing business people through phone calls and in some instances visits to business premises where, according to the Small Business Council, they are demanding that individuals fill out fringe benefits tax registration forms.

I have placed a series of questions on the Notice Paper regarding these alleged standover tactics. I sincerely hope that any instances identified are not condoned by the Minister and that he takes appropriate action to put an end to this practice. The concern of the petitioners that I have mentioned is shared by thousands across the country. I commend all of those who are telling the Federal Government in no uncertain terms what they think of its fringe benefits tax.

To date, precise information on Mr Kazak's contribution is unavailable, but that it will be promoting the PLO cause is surely likely.

These developments require a detailed explanation by the Hawke Government. If Mysoon Shaath's visit to Australia represents a shift in the Government's policy, after many years of bipartisan policy that members of known terrorist organisations, including the PLO and its affiliates, not be allowed entry to Australia, the Australian people have a fundamental right to be told of this policy shift. The Australian people also have the fundamental right to be told why their taxes are being given in the form of grants to such organisations as the PLO or its affiliates. A fundamental responsibility of any government is to maximise the security of its people. It appears that, either through a deliberate policy shift or through inefficient intelligence or administration, the Government is not adequately fulfilling this responsibility. If our visa and other arrangements with New Zealand or any other country are weakening our security against the arrival of terrorists or members of terrorist organisations in Australia, the loopholes must be closed immediately. It is not just Australian citizens who appear to be being put at increased risk. World leaders and other notable figures frequently visit Australia. Next week, the Prime Minister of India, Rajiv Gandhi, will visit us. A few weeks later the Pontiff will visit. Both these leaders have already been the subject of assassination attempts in their own countries. It is absolutely essential that Australia's security arrangements for visits such as these be, and be seen to be, at their highest level. The Mysoon Shaath episode raises doubts in this regard. I call on the Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, who is at the table, to assure the Senate that she will arrange to have this matter reviewed as a matter of urgency and of the highest priority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having had time to read the Hansard record of the answer given by the Minister for Community Services, Senator Grimes, to Senator Devlin yesterday regarding my criticism of the national drug offensive, I can only presume that it is one of those occasions of which Senator Grimes availed himself, to quote him, `when people sometimes make statements in the heat of the moment that they may later regret'. I hope that he has now regretted the answer he gave Senator Devlin yesterday. Yesterday Senator Grimes claimed that I had claimed that We Help Ourselves-which is one of the organisations at the street level in New South Wales-had received nothing when in fact it had received $104,000. He stated that I had also claimed that GROW, which is another organisation dealing with drugs at the street level, had received nothing. Senator Grimes said:

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, it claimed $33,000.
In regard to the Opposition's task force on drugs, he stated:

The task force claimed that only the New South Wales Government contributed to the cost of life education mobile vans, whereas both the State and Federal governments provided $782,000 under the campaign.

Senator Grimes has, I very firmly believe, misled the Senate. I will choose one of four agencies to explain what I mean. Let us look at We Help Ourselves. In 1984-85 that organisation received $20,800 in grants. In 1985-86 it received $125,414 as a result of State ministerial approval in November 1985. This much larger sum included one-off payments for repairs and maintenance and money for a new half-way house, as well as increased recurrent funds for two additional staff. However, following the National Drug Summit and Mr Hawke's statement of a State and Federal commitment to spend $100m over a period of three years'. We Help Ourselves received an allocation for the 1986-87 financial year of only $104,373. That is very close to Senator Grimes's $104,000. He claimed that that organisation received that amount under the drug offensive. I believe that is a dreadful attempt to mislead the Senate. There is no way that yearly recurrent grants can be considered as money granted as a result of the national drug offensive. I can assure the Senate that the feeling at the street level in New South Wales where our survey was done is running very high.

The non-government organisations have virtually been ignored. Only $2m of the $8m that has been granted this year has gone to non-government bodies. Government bodies have received $6m. Almost half of that $2m has gone to one of those non-government organisations. The sum of $6m has gone to government bodies. Of course, those bodies are usually funded by State or Federal departments. Indeed, NADA-the Network of Alcohol and Drug Agencies, which is the umbrella group for 90 per cent of the non-government organisations in this area-wrote to the New South Wales Minister for Health, Mr Anderson, as soon as he took up his new portfolio and asked him to meet with a delegation from the executive of that organisation to discuss the needs of the agencies in the community and the needs of the users. There has been no acknowledgment at all of the letter by that Minister for Health. Senator Grimes, in his answer yesterday, said something which is obviously not the case. He said:

The task force claimed that only the New South Wales Government contributed to the cost of life education mobile vans, whereas both the State and Federal governments provided $782,000 under the campaign.

This is obviously not the case. Indeed, to quote the task force, it said that life education centre mobiles did indeed receive funding for new vans. Senator Grimes says that we claimed that no money was received. Obviously, that is an error that the Minister has made, I hope not deliberately.

Finally, Senator Grimes-I believe in a very childish way-attempted to connect my criticisms of the handing out of grants in the State of New South Wales as a result of that survey to the way things were carried out in my home State. Indeed, just the opposite occurred. Money in my State was given to street level organisations. It was given to the Lions Club, the Salvation Army and other street level organisations. This is in direct contrast to the State of New South Wales, where the William Booth Institute of the Salvation Army at Darlinghurst was refused, as was Mancare. Neither of those Salvation Army organisations received anything.

I have risen in the adjournment debate purely to put the facts in Hansard. I let Senator Grimes know that I would be doing this but he has not chosen to come into the Senate. I do not know whether he has been too busy to do so but perhaps he has been. I am not claiming that he did not come in by choice, but it is wrong for the Government to claim that recurrent funds being given to organisations at the street level are indeed moneys from the drug offensive. People working in those areas cannot and will not be hoodwinked. For the Government to attempt to hoodwink the Australian people generally is, I believe, wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to refer to the Australian Parliamentary Disarmament Forum which was held on the Friday immediately following the last sitting week of the Parliament, including the records that have been kept of that meeting, and briefly I thank all those associated with the Parliament who enabled it to take place. The Forum was organised by the Parliamentary Disarmament Group, which consists of members and senators from all parties and of which I happen to be one of the co-convenors. My fellow co-convenors from the other parties asked me to co-ordinate the arrangements for this forum, which I was happy to do. You, Mr President, together with Madam Speaker, addressed us at the Forum and Madam Speaker opened the Forum.

SPEECH.PARA: Our guests that day were the five ambassadors representing in Australia the five nuclear armed nations-the United States, the Soviet Union, China, France and Great Britain. These five ambassadors made arrangements, in accepting our invitation, for three additional delegates each to attend with them. These delegates included experts in disarmament and arms control who came especially from home capitals to be at the Forum and make contributions. The program for the day was set out and circulated to many members of Parliament. I seek leave to have the program incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The procedure throughout the day was for each ambassador in turn to give a 20-minute presentation of his own nation's approach to peace, disarmament and security and for that to be followed by 30 minutes of questions from the members of parliament who were present. Thirty-five members of parliament participated in the day's proceedings and there was a very lively exchange of questions and answers of real substance. Some 70 observers, representative of the Australian public, were able to be present at our invitation. They ranged from secretaries of departments and heads of defence services to year 11 students from schools, but with a wide representation of peace groups and other community groups, such as the National Federation of Women, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and various party representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: During the Forum we ensured that we kept a careful record of all that was said. Hansard has already produced the first proofs of the record of the whole day and the proof version amounts to some 140 pages. We hope to make it available, on a responsible cost basis, to all interested members of the Australian public and inquirers from overseas. Secondly, we made arrangements for the whole day to be filmed to enable television programs to be produced and, in particular to enable the production of six video cassettes, one being a collage of the day and the other five being individual programs based on the five sessions because the five ambassadors, together with their delegations, presented in turn their country's position and then faced questions, doing so in the order of Great Britain, France, China, the Soviet Union and the United States. We hope that in this, the International Year of Peace, we achieved on that day a greater understanding between the representatives of those nations and the members and senators of the Australian Parliament on the issues before us in this area. We hope also that the records I have referred to will be useful and beneficial over the coming years, especially to young Australians in schools and in other places who may view the videos of the day's events.

Finally, I would like specifically to thank all those in Parliament House who assisted this Forum. It was a Forum in which some 35 members and senators participated but in fact more than 100 members and senators, in addition, gave us direct letters and statements of well wishes and apologies because although they were unable to attend they supported what we were doing. We were delighted at this enormous amount of interest in the Forum. On every aspect we gained support from everyone in Parliament House, from yourself down, Mr President, in regard to the arrangements that were made for our meeting in Senate Committee rooms 1 and 2, including the necessary security arrangements and television and media facilities. The Senate attendants were magnificent in the way they prepared the room. I have to place on record that some Senate attendants arranged the room from 3 a.m. to 6 a.m. because a Senate Estimates committee sat in the room until 3 o'clock in the morning. The whole day's proceedings were enormously facilitated by everybody. Fortunately not one incident detracted from the day.

I conclude by summing up in a few sentences my own evaluation of the substantial findings which arose from the day's dialogue. Interested members of parliament and the public will be able to refer to the full Hansard record on these matters. In trying to evaluate the day's proceedings, I suggest that three most significant arms control and disarmament matters were referred to. Two of them amounted to good news. First, there was almost universal support for the achievement of significant reductions in the level of armaments, and we all look to these words being made good by action. There was cautious optimism towards this being achieved in the short term. Secondly, the forum believed that a comprehensive chemical weapons ban ought to be achieved and is likely to be achieved in the coming 12 months. There was a difference of views on the third and most insistent matter, unanimously agreed to by members of parliament, that a world wide comprehensive nuclear test ban be achieved. This was not the view of the nuclear armed nations that came before us on that day. I am sure that Australians, Australian parliamentarians and Australian governments will continue to press for this goal until we gain the assent of the nuclear armed nations. We see this as an achievable and beneficial outcome.
I thank the Senate for this chance to note that this was a most significant day in the history of this Parliament and one which we all believe was worthwhile.
